PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of the Nullarbor Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned oppose the attempts by the Federal Government to World Heritage List the Nullarbor Region.
In doing so, we condemn the State and Federal Government for failing to consult with the residents of the Nullarbor in relation to the listing proposal.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Waste
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That residents of Pontypool, Wales, have been exposed to unreasonable health risks by the incineration in their environment of toxic waste products including polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs);

That it is unacceptable for the Australian Government to permit the Western Australian Government to dispose of such toxic waste products by exporting them to Pontypool, Liverpool, or other overseas venues;
That it behoves the Australian governments to compel the producers of such waste products to meet the costs of disposal in Australia.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Antarctica: Huskies
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is no scientific evidence which shows that huskies are:
1.A threat to Antarctica's fauna including seal and penguin colonies.
2.Linked to disease among other animals in the region.
3.Disease carriers because of a failure in the strict quarantine methods used when introducing a new dog.
4.Inferior to fuel driven vehicles in terms of efficiency of transport and impose greater damage on the environment compared to fuel driven vehicles.
Australia's signature on an international agreement will end a significant Australian tradition of using husky dogs in Antarctica by requiring the removal of all huskies presently in Antarctica.

Recognising that since 1898 huskies have supported Antarctic expeditions, have continued to be of value to scientists carrying out research and are an intrinsic part of the Australian presence in Antarctica your petitioners call upon the Government to reverse its decision concerning the huskies in Antarctica and allow them to remain in Antarctica.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of Australia. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that 219 hectares of reserved forest in the Apollo Bay water catchment forest in the Otways Rainforests, Victoria has been set aside as a flora reserve, but the rest of this catchment may be cleared for logging.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners humbly pray that this catchment may be wholly set aside as a National Estate to protect this unique rainforest.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to notice given at the last day of sitting, on behalf of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, I now withdraw the Business of the Senate Notice of Motion standing in my name for three sitting days after today for the disallowance of the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No.58 and made under the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981. As foreshadowed yesterday, because of the interest and importance of this instrument I seek leave to make a statement about the Committee's actions.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has recently concluded its scrutiny of the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1992 No.58, made under the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981. I reported to the Senate on 26 May 1992 on our concerns with this instrument, when on behalf of the Committee I gave notice of a motion of disallowance in respect of the regulations. Also, at giving of notices yesterday I incorporated in Hansard the correspondence of the Committee with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) on this matter. However, this instrument raised issues of such interest and importance that the Committee considered that a more detailed statement should be made.

PARA.TAB: The regulations were very short, substituting a new regulation 9 which provided that the standard of proof required before the Federal Police Disciplinary Tribunal is proof beyond all reasonable doubt. The only other substantive provision, which was not an amendment of the principal regulations, provided that the amendment extends to proceedings or matters which arose before the regulations commenced.

The explanatory statement which accompanied the regulations advised that the previous regulation 9 was replaced by the new regulation 9 to the same effect because it was understood that the previous regulation was invalid. No details of the putative invalidity were provided.

The Committee considered the instrument and decided to write to the Minister about three matters. Firstly, we wished to know why the previous regulation 9, which had apparently been in operation for seven years, was invalid. The Committee assumed that it was because it lacked the authority expressly inserted in section 76(4)(aa) of the parent Act in 1987. Secondly, the Committee asked for an assurance that the application of the new regulation 9 to proceedings which arose before this provision was made did not operate retrospectively in a prejudicial fashion. Such retrospectivity, unless it affects only the Commonwealth, is invalid under section 48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and is also a breach of personal liberties.

Thirdly, and most importantly, the Committee was concerned at the adoption of the criminal, rather than the lesser civil, standard of proof before the Disciplinary Tribunal. In its letter to the Minister the Committee observed that, given the nature of the relevant proceedings, the rights of the public may be better protected by the civil standard of proof, which is the balance of probabilities, rather than the criminal standard of proof beyond reasonable doubt.

The Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, replied promptly to our concerns, confirming that the Committee was correct in its assumption that there was no authority for regulation 9 until the amendment of the Act in 1987. Also, there was no prejudicial retrospectivity. The new provision applied only to AFP officers facing charges and technically the effect of the amendment was to provide a higher standard of proof in the future, to the benefit of those officers.

With respect to the standard of proof, the Minister advised that the purpose of the amendment was to rectify the invalidity of the standard in use since 1985, not to implement a new policy decision. The reason for the criminal standard of proof was that penalties imposed as a result of disciplinary proceedings can have practical consequences as severe as any criminal sentence short of imprisonment. In addition, many acts constituting a breach of discipline in the AFP would also be crimes. This was particularly significant, even in groups subject to disciplinary regimes, because of the confrontational character of much police interaction with the public.

Also, where a crime is suspected and a prosecution initiated, any disciplinary proceedings are suspended for the duration of the prosecution. The prospect of a lesser standard of proof would inevitably discourage pursuit of criminal investigations. The Minister concluded by pointing out that the lower standard of proof could harm a member in ambiguous circumstances and that complaints against police may be not only an avenue of redress for the genuinely aggrieved but also a means for dishonest persons to raise doubts about police evidence or avenge themselves on an AFP member.

The Committee accepted the advice of the Minister about the invalidity and the retrospectivity. However, while it regarded the Minister's explanations about the standard of proof as persuasive, the Committee decided to take advantage of the opportunity to hear the views of the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

Accordingly, the Committee was briefed by the Ombudsman, Mr Alan Cameron, and by other senior officials of the Ombudsman's office, Sue Pidgeon and John Taylor. The Ombudsman pointed out that when the police complaints regime was originally proposed, the Australian Law Reform Commission suggested that the civil standard of proof then in operation before the Police Appeal Board should continue. This was a flexible, or floating standard, the degree of seriousness of the charge affecting whether the issue had been proved to the satisfaction of the Tribunal. The criminal standard prevented disciplinary authorities from pressing action where reasonable satisfaction was felt, but not beyond reasonable doubt. This encouraged an undue measure of caution when disciplinary proceedings are in prospect.

The Ombudsman also advised that, among the States, only South Australia now had a criminal standard of proof; the rest had the floating civil standard. While the Minister was correct in noting that there should be rigorous pursuit of any criminal aspects, an alternative of disciplinary proceedings at a lesser standard of proof and lesser punishments was better than no action at all. The criminal standard may be defensible when a member's career is at stake, but there is a much weaker case for this in less serious complaints. The higher standard of proof tended to undermine public confidence in the complaints procedure if action were pressed in only a small proportion of cases.

The Committee was therefore faced with the dilemma of deciding, as the Ombudsman expressed it, the fine balance between the rights of AFP members under inquiry and the capacity under the legislation for a thorough and impartial investigation of alleged offences. Here the Committee had two compelling but conflicting arguments. On the one hand, the criminal standard of proof beyond reasonable doubt gave a high level of protection to individual police officers under investigation, while giving a lesser standard of protection to the broader interests of the public. On the other hand, the civil standard of proof on the balance of probabilities provides reduced protection for the individuals concerned but ensures greater protection for the broader public interest.

After considerable discussion, the Committee took its usual course of action in cases where there is a difference between reasonable people about sensitive issues of personal and other rights; that is, that where there are two or more conflicting sets of rights to be protected, then the Committee will not insist on amendment of the relevant delegated legislation. Instead, as in this case, it will simply point out to the executive law maker the existence of the dilemma. Here, the Committee sent to the Minister a copy of a paper presented to us by the Ombudsman, `The standard of proof in police disciplinary matters', observing that its quality was such that it should be taken into account in any future review of this aspect of the regulations.
Notice withdrawn.

Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill seeks to amend the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Act 1990 which obliges all employers with an annual national payroll of $200,000 or more to spend the equivalent of one per cent of their payroll on what is called `eligible training activities'. From 1 July this year that figure of one per cent will increase to 1.5 per cent. This is in fact a payroll tax of 1.5 per cent on every employer in Australia with six employees or more. In this climate, it is ludicrous to even contemplate continuing with a thing like this.

PARA.TAB: The Bill itself seeks to allow employers to include in their eligible training programs full time students at or above year 10 or its equivalent who are under 21 years of age and who are participating in a work experience program. It makes similar provision for full time teachers seeking experience in industries. The Liberal and National parties will not oppose the amendments proposed in this Bill, on the basis that there is no purpose in voting against something which will make less objectionable a lousy piece of legislation which is fundamentally flawed.

The training guarantee levy, of course, is an unnecessary impost. As pointed out very clearly in Fightback, it is one of the taxes on business which will be repealed by a Hewson government. If it were not so serious, it would in fact be a joke to have a levy in Australia at this stage. It must have been dreamt up by a committee of pseudo academics who are totally remote from the people and who have no understanding whatsoever of the real world. That remark, I think, could squarely be placed as an adequate description of this Labor Government today.

The business sector has always either trained people or sought trained people from other similar organisations, whether they be in the private or public sector. I can only assume that when this training guarantee levy was proposed the idea was that it would preclude people from actually going out and doing that. This is where this Government is remote from the real world, because it will continue.

What has happened is that a whole new non-productive industry has started up in this country, which I doubt will contribute one iota to Australia becoming a clever country. I know that that particular point will be debated, but the sad thing about it is that it will never be known. I think that in itself is a failing of this legislation.

I have canvassed a number of businesses and have had varying responses, almost what one would call a straw poll. It seems to me that the responses have broken into two quite distinct groups. One group states that it has always engaged in training and the levy will make no difference to it whatsoever. In other words, all the levy does is quantify what these people do because of the particular business they are in. Add it all up and it comes in above the one per cent and, as from 1 July, the 1.5 per cent.

The other and much larger group, mainly in the small business sector, claims it does not need to train. To avoid paying the Government the levy those people dream up, with a lot of lateral thinking, ingenious ways of engaging in training programs and, if they can, enjoying themselves at the same time. This is clearly a waste of resources—scarce resources—as the money wasted on useless programs could be better spent on improving the efficiency of the particular organisation.

I and, I know, some of my colleagues have participated in giving addresses to structured training programs. In Australia they have taken the place of seminars. The point I would like to make is that, as long as the companies pay their fees for their particular people, it does not really matter whether they turn up or not. They have satisfied the Act. As long as the money is paid, they have done the job. Of course, this has become a subculture industry in this country.

One business told me it decided to engage an expert on stress to accompany its members to a delightful resort on the Sunshine Coast of Queensland for a weekend, simply to satisfy this ridiculous training levy requirement. I might say that the report I got was worth repeating. Everybody had a wonderful time, including the expert on stress. No-one took it very seriously. They played a lot of golf; they did the requisite couple of hours lecture.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sowada knows about this. She is aware of this sort of thing going on as well. No-one, as I said, was meant to take it very seriously, except one person who did. That person now insists on taking a 10-minute break every hour to relieve stress. I might say that that person's work colleagues have ganged up and are now demanding that that particular person be given the sack because he is not carrying his weight.

PARA.TAB: I mentioned earlier that we have yet another non-productive service industry that has grown up around the training levy. Those doing the training are also obliged to engage in training programs—the trainers have to get the trainers in. This shows how these things grow at an exponential rate; it indicates how silly the whole thing can be.

In March this year I asked the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) a series of questions on notice in relation to the requirements to spend money under the training levy. I asked what training programs the Department of Administrative Services provided for electoral staff. This is pretty close to home—it applies to our own electoral staff. I asked: in 1990-91, what was the nature of each program? When was the program held and at what venue? Was the program specific to the duties of electoral staff? What was the cost of each program? There were a number of other questions as well.

The answers that came back were quite interesting. I will summarise them; I will not go into the detail. Among other things, 62 computer user courses were conducted between 2 July 1990 and 28 June 1991 in the West Block building in Canberra. General office skills courses were conducted over the period in question in Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide, Perth and Hobart. I would have thought that one of the important things when engaging staff is a training program. Elected members or senators either engage in a training program with their own staff or employ people who have experience and they learn, one from the other.

However, the interesting thing about it was that the total cost to the taxpayers of this country over that period was around $700,000. I believe—and I do not think many people would not agree with me—that that is an absolute disgrace, and it is only indicative of the situation. That was taxpayers' money spent by the Department of Administrative Services on courses for our staff members.

What happens in the private sector? In this climate, the private sector cannot afford to pay that sort of ludicrous amount of money. As mentioned earlier, the guarantee levy is yet another tax on business. It is a payroll tax of 1.5 per cent on any business which has six employees or more. The limit is $200,000 per annum in payroll—it is indexed—and that equates on average weekly earnings to six or seven employees.

In the last few years we have seen record unemployment brought about by this Government because of its policies. It is the recession that, honourable senators might recall, we had to have. I know that the Government gets very tired of us repeating that, but repeat it we will, over and over again, so that the people of Australia do not forget why there are one million people out of work and why over 30 per cent of young people cannot find jobs.

The whole thrust of the Hewson Fightback package—the Liberal-National Party program—to recover the Australian economy is geared to fixing the problems brought about by the failed policies of this Labor Government. The major way of doing that is to remove the input taxes which apply to business. The only way we can get Australia back on track is to revitalise the private sector. We cannot have phoney jobs in the public sector because the country cannot afford it. Unless we have a growing, vital private sector which provides the wealth to pay for the public sector, the public sector itself will collapse. We cannot afford to pay for the infrastructure—education, social welfare payments for those in genuine need, health and all the other things—if the private sector is in trouble, and it is in trouble, with record bankruptcies.

The thrust of Fightback is to remove those seven major input taxes, which include sales tax, fuel excise, payroll tax—a tax on employment—and the training guarantee levy that we are debating here today. The claim is made that by the turn of the century this will create some 2 million new jobs. How will that happen? If we remove the input taxes on business we make our businesses more competitive—not only in relation to the export market, which is essential, but also in relation to our import replacement industries. We cannot continue to go down the track of increasing our current account deficit and of increasing the amount of money that we owe to overseas people without the country collapsing.

Once we become more competitive on the export market and once we make our import replacement industries more competitive, industry will respond. When industry responds, it will mean more real jobs—not phoney or bandaid jobs. That is the only way that this country will get its economy back on track. The Government knows it and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) knows it, but he spends his time bucketing the Opposition because we have brought out a package that appeals to the Australian people. In fact, it is the only hope for the future of this country.

The One Nation package has gone nowhere. Everyone knows that. It had a few Keynesian-type programs which were based on infrastructure. No-one would have disagreed with those if, in the process, they had made us a more efficient economy. But the One Nation package had no imagination or depth, and it will not do anything for the long term future of the unemployed in this country, particularly our young people. As I mentioned earlier, we will not be opposing this Bill on the grounds that we believe that it improves the legislation which, in itself, is fundamentally flawed. Because the Bill does improve the legislation, we see no point in opposing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to discuss today the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1992. The Australian Democrats will not oppose this legislation. Introduced in 1990, the training guarantee legislation imposes a minimum requirement on employers set at a percentage of an employer's annual national payroll. Currently, employers with a payroll in excess of $200,000 per annum pay one per cent of their payroll on structured training—and this is indexed to average weekly earnings. However, after July this year, this minimum expenditure will increase to 1.5 per cent. This applies to both the private and public sectors. Any shortfalls in funding are paid to the Australian Taxation Office and contribute towards additional training funding and not consolidated revenue.

PARA.TAB: I commend the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990 as a means of increasing the level of skills and knowledge in Australia's work force. It is inappropriate for industry to rely on the public education system to train workers or to poach trained staff from other employers. The aim of the TGL is to ensure a more equitable redistribution of costs of training across all employers in Australia. It encourages businesses to meet their training responsibilities thus contributing to a more highly skilled work force and a more productive working environment.

The changes to the Act that are before the Senate today are mainly technical and incorporate recommendations contained in the Finn report, otherwise known as Young People's Participation in Post Compulsory Education and Training. The report sets new national targets for young people's participation in post secondary compulsory education and training while recommending change to facilitate the convergence of general and vocational education. The review emphasises the need for flexible training pathways to equip Australia for the twenty-first century. Integral to this is work place productivity and the update of skills and knowledge through training.

The training guarantee legislation was introduced to facilitate this process by ensuring that a guaranteed percentage of all of an employer's payroll is spent on training. As Australia crawls out of recession, the attainment of skills and high levels of competence is necessary to our future well-being. Increasingly, career progression will be related to the attainment of high levels of competence, and the effects of award restructuring will be multiskilling, and more creative and adaptive workers.

The success of business and industry in this country will depend on the skills of employees and employers' willingness to invest in quality training schemes. Business profits from a more competent and, thus, more efficient work force. In return, however, business must contribute to the development of these skills. The training guarantee enables such a contribution to be made.

In line with the recommendations of the Finn report, clauses 7 and 8 amend section 27 of the principal Act to expand the definition of an `eligible training program'. The amendments provide for a period of work experience and practise for students and teachers to be an eligible training program. This amendment is consistent with recommendation 8.3 of the Finn report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Commonwealth Government should allow employer expenditure on industrial experience programs for students and teachers as valid expenditure for the purposes of the Training Guarantee Legislation.

A vital link exists between careers, education and industry. The success of careers education is inextricably connected to industry interest. Employers ultimately benefit from the provision of good career education when they hire employees who are familiar with their requirements, and are hopefully committed to the career they have chosen. The Finn report notes:
Industry has a particular responsibility for the provision of workplace experience for both teachers and students.

The amendments specify that in this provision students must be enrolled full time at a higher education institution, TAFE or a school, and must be above the level of year 10 or its equivalent. The students must also be under 21 years of age, thus emphasising the importance of vocational training for young people. Once these young people attain various levels of competency we are not to quash their hopes by offering exploitative and unfair wage levels that denigrate their skills and performance.

PARA.TAB: The debate over the last week reveals the Government's nebulous policy on this issue of youth wages. If the confusion over the youth job summit is any indication, the Government's commitment to young Australians is, indeed, questionable. I might add that I find Minister Beazley's suggestion that young people should not necessarily be represented at the summit offensive, as would any young person in the Australian community.

It is this Government's lack of understanding about the issues confronting youth and its belated attempts to do anything about them which have led to drastic and unprecedented levels of youth unemployment. If the youth summit is to have any credibility at all, it must be more than simply a talkfest for big government, big business and big unions. There must be input from young people, the very people who will be affected by the kind of wage levels that the Government is proposing.

Subsection 27(1) specifies that there must be an agreement between a teacher and the training institution, and the training institution and the provider of work experience. This agreement must specify the terms and conditions under which the teacher undertakes the work experience or practice, and the teacher must be a full time employee of the school or institutions at the time of agreement.The second reading speech claims that this is `consistent with the aim of encouraging teachers to acquire industry experience and knowledge'. This amendment also quells some of the criticism industry associations have had about the perceived lack of experience of teachers in careers outside that of teaching.

There is also a need for a nationalisation and coordination of careers education structures. According to the Finn report, this would encourage increased employer expenditure on industrial experience programs for teachers and students. Experience in industry for teachers and students offers an exciting contribution to the development of an enhanced and efficient work force. I believe this to be a valid and progressive use of the training guarantee levy.

Clause 5 amends section 25 of the Act, inserting a further provision as to the meaning of eligible training expenditure and programs. This includes an amendment that expenditure on goods and services, of which training is the central purpose, is to be provided within 13 months from the time the expenditure is incurred. This time limit can, however, be extended by the Commissioner.

Clause 6 amends section 26 of the principal Act to provide for eligible training expenditure for travel in relation to an eligible training program. This is based on the number of kilometres travelled at a prescribed rate by a motor vehicle enabling an employee to attend an eligible training program.

Sections of the business community continue to have reservations about the TGL. The Business Council of Australia contends that the scheme is an impediment to flexibility in training rather than a stimulus to training overall. The BCA's alternative to the training guarantee levy allowed the Minister discretion over whether or not to accept a company's training guarantee. The alternative did not entail compliance on the part of the company, unlike the current legislation. It is this very compulsion that is necessary to prevent managers and employers from shirking their training obligations.

The TGL, however, should not allow managers and top administrators to usurp the benefits of the training levy. We have all heard anecdotes about big business and small business using their training allocation as rorts. Large training organisations have sprung up in the past two years ever ready to take advantage of the training expenditure allocation to cater for the needs of middle and high managers instead of lower level workers. To counteract these rumours and to impress on the business and wider community the importance of the TGL, it is necessary to investigate these claims and moreover to scrutinise the allocation of training expenditure moneys in this country.

The then Minister, the Hon. John Dawkins, indicated in his second reading speech on the Training Guarantee Bill in 1990 the intention of the Government to monitor this legislation and to review the scheme four years into its operation. I would argue that a comprehensive review of this legislation is warranted. It is essential that we determine how equitably training is allocated amongst the work force, and we must consider factors such as the participation rates of disadvantaged groups such as women, Aboriginals and disabled people.

We also have concerns, as I said earlier, about the possible rorting of the training guarantee levy as there does seem to have been a proliferation of schemes, rorts and other devices which enable businesses to spend this money in a way which could not actually be said to improve the training level and skills of their workers. There have been a number of claims made in the media—a number of claims have been made to me personally—and I do believe that this training guarantee levy needs to be very carefully scrutinised when the Government undertakes its review over the next couple of years or so. At this stage we do support the training guarantee levy but we would need to be very strongly convinced, over the coming years, that the rorts that have been identified by many sectors of business and certainly in this Parliament have been cleared up to ensure that the training guarantee levy does exactly what it has set out to do.

Surveys such as the training expenditure survey conducted by the ABS do not give an in-depth insight into the nature of training in our work force. It is fundamental to the success of the legislation and to meet our economic goals that a national training scheme be effective and beyond reproach. We need to be wary given that some businesses may see the levy as `an onerous regulatory cost that business has to bear', to quote the Metal Trades Industry Association. For this reason the definition of eligible schemes must be irreproachable and the possibility of rorts totally eliminated.

We are assured that funds collected by the Taxation Office will be placed in a separate trust account which is set up for the purposes of additional training for the Australian work force. A breakdown and wide circulation of this information would be appropriate. It is important that the Government be accountable for these funds, which are apparently distributed to the States and Territories after costs.

The Democrats support the Bill today, with a caution: we are acutely aware of the key role training has to play in boosting our country's productivity; however, it must be done correctly. The development of increased training pathways and more flexible delivery arrangements is essential to our economic well-being and should be encouraged through legislation such as the TGL. Employer expenditure on training is projected to grow over the five years from 1990 by 35 per cent. Important, too, is that the legislation be effective and provide the much needed boost to industry and business that the Government claims it will.

To this extent, as I said earlier, we will be looking very closely at the operation of the Act over the coming months and hope that the Government does something to clarify and clear up the many concerns that have been raised about rorting of the TGL in the business and wider community. The Australian Democrats look forward to a review of the scheme over the coming years and commend this Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, this is another attempt by the Government to get its training guarantee legislation into good order. I do not agree that a review of the legislation would be of any value whatsoever. I suggest that the review be abandoned and, if the Government is serious about finding jobs for people in this community, that it stop taxing the people who are most likely to be able to provide them. The increase to 1.5 per cent of earnings will only mean that people will put off employees to enable them to survive and continue in operation. Employers will not want to do this, but they will be forced to do so as a consequence of the Government's actions.

PARA.TAB: This levy descended upon business on 1 July 1990 and has now operated for two years. Just listening to the Democrats speak about the levy, it is clear that there are so many problems with it that a review to try to put it in order would be a further waste of money. It should be abandoned. It is interesting to read the second reading speech which was incorporated by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) when the Bill was introduced, because it indicates that the Government actually knows that there is a problem. If only it could see its way clear to try to solve it. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme was introduced as part of the Government's policy over the last several years to develop the appropriate environment in which Australian industry can become more competitive internationally. A fundamental step in this process is the development of a highly skilled workforce which can adapt quickly to major changes in the economy.

If only it was actually doing something to try to achieve those objectives. The legislation that we are dealing with today—the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1992—is an amendment in response to a document by the Australian Education Council review committee which was entitled Young People's Participation in Post-Compulsory Education and Training. The amendment allows the scheme to be extended to include training programs for full time students and work experience students who are less than 21 years of age, and, if the scheme is going to exist, they of course should be included in it.

PARA.TAB: So we are not opposing this amendment; we did oppose the Bill originally, but this at least adds to the people who, hopefully, will get some benefit out of it. It is effectively an increase in the tax that business has to pay. We keep talking about training. It seems almost as if the Government thinks that, if we talk about training for long enough, people will forget that there are people out there without jobs. But training for what? If the Government could tell us the jobs that are available for which people do not have the skills, it would get a more positive response, but that is not the case. Like the summit, it is a device to try to hide the fact that there are people out there in the community who are actually suffering. There are cases where no member of the family has employment. There seems to be no comprehension of the stress that it places on families to have one of their members unemployed—and, in many cases, more than one. There is stress on marriages and on relationships between parents and children, and all the Government seems to do is to manufacture devices to keep down the apparent number of those out of work.

A person is not counted as being out of work if he or she is doing some voluntary work. One is not counted as being out of work if one's spouse is still in employment. It really makes one wonder just how many more than one million Australians are out of work. The Government keeps putting people into training programs and fancy schemes and hopes that the numbers will go away. They will not go away, though, until people have meaningful jobs, and the problem will not be solved in the way that this Bill attempts to do so.

The scheme has failed. I will briefly mention the areas in which I believe it has failed. The cost of record keeping has increased markedly, and these increases have been for the people who have had their own training programs over a long period. These people are now required to keep extensive records for the Tax Office and there are dozens of stories—anywhere you go you will hear this—from people who have run very good training programs in the past. The cost of record keeping has increased and in many cases has reduced, as a consequence, the actual expenditure on the training of individuals; they have had to divert resources into keeping records for the Tax Office.

Secondly, it has been brought to the attention of some companies that the actual level of expenditure is greatly in excess of the minimum amount, and so these companies have been able to cut the cost to their businesses by reducing the amount of money they had been spending on training. Prior to that, these companies were happy to spend a certain amount. Now that the Government tells them that a lesser amount is appropriate, and in light of the cost of keeping records, the amount of money spent on training has actually been reduced. It has become a tax on jobs and has inhibited employment.

Why does the Labor Party always get this sort of thing so wrong? It tries to talk about the right solutions but never gets it right. The bureaucratisation of the training process is amazing. It has become so formalised. Earlier, I think Senator Parer went through the schemes that operate and the programs that have been run. Who has actually benefited from them? There has been no answer. As long as the Government has a list of numbers, a list of the amounts of money that make it look on paper as though it is doing something, it thinks it will all be all right. It will not be all right.

The Australian newspaper on 30 April of this year reported that the Tax Office had collected $3.7m from 1,500 employers who had failed to meet their level of training expenditure in the year 1990-91 but that virtually none of the $3.7m would be spent on training. It would be spent between the Tax Office, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the National Training Board to cover administration costs. Let the Minister, when he responds to this Bill, tell us that that is not the case and give us an itemised breakdown of that $3.7m. Let us be told that that is not correct and that none of it was spent on administration—that it was actually spent on programs designed to get young people into work.

I have referred to the fact that people have cut down on the actual amounts spent on training as they cannot afford to continue to do so. Reference has been made today to the proliferation of fringe training companies, to the training related meetings and to the events which have been manufactured, quite within the law and quite properly, to enable people to spend this money in a way which is attractive to their employees but which has very little to do with increasing the skills of the work force. I think that is a great pity indeed.

Market research by the Tax Office has shown that many large companies have reduced their expenditure. The President of the Australian Institute of Training and Development was reported in the Australian Financial Review on 29 April this year as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: In the past companies that invested four to five per cent of payroll are now cutting back to one per cent. They were probably the people who are actually achieving training programs that were worthwhile.

PARA.TAB: We have heard reference this morning to the expensive conferences that some managing directors have been able to attend, possibly of very great value to them. But I wonder whether this is the way we should be achieving that, if it actually meets the objectives. Sending managing directors to expensive conferences may be very worth while but it is not going to influence unemployed youth to feel that money is being spent wisely in terms of getting people into their first job, and that is what we should be aiming for.

I will also continue to criticise the lack of the exemption mechanism to take into account the structure of specific industries. What money should a farmer have to try to find to spend on training an itinerant fruit picker or a shearer? There does not seem to be any comprehension of the nature of some industries. It is just a blanket, across the board tax. Things like this make people realise that it really is a payroll tax, that it is only made to look as though it is training because of the name of the Bill rather than anything within it that is helping young people, in particular, to get their first job.

It is a pity that we do not have time to discuss this in more detail. There are other Bills in this two-week program of a similar nature, taxing business. The superannuation legislation is yet to come. I would tell the Government to focus on jobs and not all these words that try to make it look as though it is doing something. The Minister, whom I quoted earlier, indicates that the Government is aware of the problem. Let us get down to finding real solutions to the problem of unemployment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill increases the scope of an eligible training program as recommended by the 1991 Finn report of the Australian Education Council Review. The Bill provides for work experience and practice for students and teachers to be included in an eligible training program of an employer, and this we welcome.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the original training levy has not revolutionised business, industry or training development in Australia. Granted, training spending has increased. A figure of $700m has been estimated to have been spent by industry and a high level of compliance has been achieved. The great shame is that the training guarantee levy, with all its related Bills, and this one before us today, has produced a training scheme that does nothing to change the old ways or bring about the so-called `clever country'. Australian industry is not more competitive, nor has distribution of the training effort become more equitable amongst employers.

In the absence of any requirement to distribute the training expenditure amongst different categories of employees, the TGEAA may be satisfied by spending one per cent of annual national payroll to enable the managing director to enjoy an overseas conference at an exotic conference site, whilst spending nothing on any other employee. John Dymond, in the journal Taxation in Australia of February 1992, writes:

SPEECH.PARA: Australian industry has long had a reputation for devoting significant resources toward executive conferences, whilst spending little or no money on improving the skills of the general workforce.

The Bill before us today does attempt in part to correct this bias by recognising the vocational and general education of young people by allowing the work experience and practice for students and teachers to be included in an eligible training program of an employer.

PARA.TAB: The Bill's requirement of the type of youth to whom it is applicable is very specific. This is where I have problems with the amendment. Full time students at or above year 10 of the New South Wales system or its equivalent who are under 21 years of age may qualify. I query this cut-off age of 21. With the Government emphasis on students continuing to year 12, many students are not entering vocational studies until after that age. I will use the Tasmanian situation as an example—my home State. The average age of our matriculation or year 12 students is 18. Add a possible four-year course of study to that and we have an age of 22. Thus, under this Bill, final year trainees in many cases would be over 21 and would not be eligible for the work experience claim by the employers.

One particular area of training which will be affected is teacher training. At the University of Tasmania, teacher training is a four-year course at the Launceston campus or a one-year diploma course after a preliminary degree at the Hobart campus. At both campuses, final year students participate in two major extended practical sessions of several weeks each, with the practical sessions seen as the major component of their final year of study. Considering the educational structure in Tasmania, it would be very rare to have a final year student under the age of 21 in these courses. Final year students are often regarded by the host schools as an asset to the normal teaching staff. However, under the present structure of this Bill I can see a situation developing where the younger students will be preferred and the training institutions will find it difficult to place these final year students, particularly those who are over 21. I believe that a better proposal, and one more in line with the proposals contained in the Finn report, would have been to target full time students who commenced study under the age of 21 and to allow the work experience to be included as part of the employer's levy until their course of study was completed. I hope that the Government can see fit to make this amendment. In this way, no final year students will be disadvantaged, their full training will be accounted for and youth will have been encouraged thereby to train. This would be a more correct interpretation of recommendation 8.3 of the Finn report, which targets the training of youth in full time study but which does not—I must emphasise—install an upper age limit of 21.

Despite the training levy and now this one limited concession towards vocational training, Australia will remain and is expected to remain one of the least skilled countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development unless there is a definite change. We must bring about some change. But change will come about only when Australia changes the government at the next election and the coalition introduces its Fightback program, which amongst many other proposals will abolish this iniquitous training tax that is far too narrowly based and does not benefit the entire community. No longer will Australia be described as it was by the Deveson committee as `arguably at the back of the pack'.

Meanwhile, until the next election this country and its business community will be inflicted with a tax which has significantly increased the burden on small business. The Training Guarantee Act provides for the maintenance of records of an extremely burdensome nature.

In fact, given that expenditure incurred in developing and administering accounting and information systems in relation to eligible training programs qualifies as eligible training expenditure, an employer's liability to training can be met in large part simply by adhering to the onerous requirements relating to the recording of eligible training programs. In fact, the Act states that an `employer must keep records that record and explain all transactions and other acts engaged in by the employer' and that these records must be maintained for at least five years.

But the recording is so cumbersome that one large private teaching institution I know of with a staff of over 100 teachers has reduced the teaching load of one of its senior staff members and has appointed him as a staff development officer purely to supervise the Training Guarantee Act. He is not a trainer. His sole role is supervisory. He is finding that he is spending a minimum of three to four hours a week supervising this and maintaining the records. This is not the conclusion of the recording process that needs to be maintained because those records from this teacher are then channelled to the school accountant who must assign a dollar value to the training that has occurred.

This institution, like many other good employers, has as a demonstrable, historical fact regularly spent several times its minimum training requirement on its teachers over the years well before the levy was introduced. Many of these good employers have voiced the opinion that if, they simply post external training invoices to a training account in the general ledger and then find that this general ledger balance exceeds the minimum training expenditure amount, they would have satisfied their liability to training and need not do any more.

But that is not so—the Taxation Commissioner will not allow this attitude. The official response at this stage is that very full and extremely accurate records must be maintained to support the minimum training requirement. This position is made worse in that the Commissioner considers that every employer who fails to record eligible training expenditure in excess of the minimum training requirement will still be committing an offence, despite the fact that he might have exceeded it many times, if he does not keep the detailed records of how and when that training took place, its nature and who was involved. It appears that the Commissioner is taking the same bureaucratic inequitable view of the Training Guarantee Act as he took with the substantiation rules of division 3F of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

It has been noted by several writers that the objects of the Training Guarantee Act would be better served if all training programs were, say, submitted to a registered industry training body or the National Training Board for approval.Mr David Edwards of the Victorian Chamber of Commerce states that, while training schemes are beneficial, the Federal Government should be using the carrot rather than the stick approach. Mr Edwards believes that it is wrong to promote training as a form of taxation with tax penalties and believes that employers should be offered tax incentives to train staff.

In summing up, I would like this chamber to note that this Government's attitude to training can best be seen by what is happening to the shortfall that has been lodged by employers who have not spent the required one per cent on training. I repeat the comments made earlier in this debate by my colleague Senator Reid: although the Australian Taxation Office has collected $3.7m from such employers under the training guarantee levy, it is expected that virtually none of the $3.7m is likely to be spent on training.

We have been informed that the money is to be divided up amongst three authorities—the Tax Office, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the National Training Board—to cover administrative costs. It is not surprising, therefore, that a Liberal-National Party coalition government will abolish this inequitable and anti-business training tax which does nothing to substantially improve the level of training. We believe that the carrot rather than the stick approach should be used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1992 seeks to amend the operation of the training guarantee levy which the Labor Government inflicted upon business in this country two years ago. The Bill will allow an employer to include work experience for students and teachers in an eligible training program. The Bill also makes some amendments and technical clarifications.

PARA.TAB: Although these changes do improve the principal Act, the original legislation was very poorly thought out and was drafted in excessive haste. I do not oppose this Bill, but it is important that the Senate be aware of just how unhelpful the training guarantee levy actually is.

The Federal Government's increasing resort to compulsion in the training area is counterproductive. Some firms spend much more than the current one per cent and, indeed, the proposed 1 1/2 per cent on training. An example is the Tweed River fruit processors on the north coast of New South Wales who spend 8 1/2 per cent on training.

Some firms are finding that they actually spend more than the compulsory level and have actually reduced their spending on training. The Managing Director of Drake International Ltd, Mr Rod Urwin, said last year:
At least 35 per cent of companies have cut back; around 50 per cent find they are spending roughly the same amount.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, this legislation, with its huge bureaucratic framework, really is aimed at only about 15 per cent. The General Manager of the Sydney branch of the Australian Organisation for Quality, Mr Len King, has noted:

PARA.TAB: There is a lot of evidence that smaller companies are not reacting; they are waiting for the problem to go away. The scheme has forced a lot of companies to assess how much they were spending, and the word has gone down: we are spending too much.

SPEECH.PARA: We must seriously question whether the ALP Government's obsession with compulsion is the most effective strategy in the training area. Successful countries such as Germany and Japan, which do not have compulsory schemes, have long surpassed Australia in the provision of training skills for their young people.

PARA.TAB: In a culture, such as in Germany, which rewards and admires achievement and the attainment of excellence, there are clear, well resourced, well funded and industry recognised training schemes and a great diversity of training opportunities. In Germany, almost 80 per cent of teenagers—virtually all of those not attending universities and colleges—are undertaking some form of training course. Australia, which has a national average of only 21 per cent of young Australians receiving vocational education, compares very unfavourably with this. The OECD average is 50 per cent.

The Professor of Adult Education and Executive Director of Training and Development Services at the University of Technology, Sydney, Professor Rod McDonald, has identified obstacles to achieving a better trained Australia. He said that we spend more on education than many OECD countries. So the problem is not how much money we spend on education, but how we spend the money. Professor McDonald provides solutions, but they are quite different ones from the professional trainer approach which is essential to the Government's training guarantee scheme.

Professor McDonald says that training is the responsibility of everybody in an organisation. The major trainers are people like line managers, supervisors and shop floor workers rather than the full time professional trainers. He says that what we need is a work force that is both well trained and can train well. All it requires is a little imagination to deliver training when and where it is needed. The single most important skill for all workers is to learn how to learn. Nothing they learn will serve them forever. Workers need to learn to take some responsibility for their own training. The more the workers learn how to train themselves the more they can contribute to the company.

In major banks, for instance, a terminal branch can deliver a mini-tutorial to a new teller if training assistance is needed. This is something that the bank provides but which the worker can use to train himself or herself. ICI Australia Ltd has turned routine plant shutdowns into training opportunities. Other manufacturers could follow this example when processing plants have to stop processing for maintenance.

Lend Lease encourages staff to become competent in dealing clearly and effectively with people in the workplace—that is, with their colleagues, their supervisors and their managers—as training for functioning more effectively with clients. The University of Technology, Sydney, and Lend Lease training have developed a program that develops simple skills such as writing and working in an organisation through to preparing training courses, motivating others and using reflection as an aid to diagnosing their own training needs.

Many businesses are engaged in training and it should be their responsibility to make the decision on what sort of training they give employees, when they give it to them and for how long. It should be an individual enterprise decision. The aim of the training guarantee levy program is to increase the overall level of training. But legislation that compels employers with a payroll above a certain level to spend progressively larger proportions of that payroll on training is inefficient and inequitable, in the same way that payroll taxes and compulsory occupational superannuation are.

The Government has sought to expand training provision in industry by the use of compulsion through this training guarantee levy. Compulsion inevitably leads to waste and poor allocation of resources, and obscures the absence of proper incentives for industry to undertake training expenditure. It is also illogical to apply the same rate across the entire spectrum of business activity. Take, for example, a carpet laying business which has very little opportunity for training compared to a computer firm which has much greater need to ensure that staff are constantly trained. A carpet layer would need to use much less than the one per cent or 1 1/2 per cent, whereas the computing firm would need to use a much higher percentage. Under the training guarantee levy both firms are treated exactly the same.

The levy is also imposed regardless of the profitability of the enterprise. It must be complied with even though the employer is not making a profit. This has become a major problem in difficult times such as in the current great recession. There needs to be some recognition of capacity to pay.

Large employers with training programs already in place are relatively unaffected, but smaller employers have been forced to divert funds from priority areas which they have determined can best develop their firms. Some employers have simply avoided expanding their operations so that they will not incur direct and indirect costs imposed by the Government training levy. The Business Council of Australia concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: Skills formation should be market driven. Australia needs a more flexible labour market and the last thing we need is a costly bureaucratic apparatus which will create new kinds of inefficiencies for firms.

The coalition is committed to upgrading vocational training to make it more responsive to the requirements of industry and the work force. Achieving that objective will require closer cooperation between the traditional sources of vocational education, TAFE colleges and industry. It will also require that TAFE colleges be more closely integrated with secondary schools and universities within their own States as well as in other States. These processes have already begun, but they need to be accelerated.

PARA.TAB: By the same token, training can no longer be left to the unstructured, hit and miss, learn as you go methods of the past. We must set national goals which will embrace the needs of industry, business and commerce for specific skills and for specific training. These goals must be met by providers who are flexible and highly qualified.

Industry has a vital and expanding role to play in entry level training. There are already excellent examples of cooperation between industry, schools and training institutions to provide integrated training. There are many possible models, and diversity in approach is to be encouraged within a framework of national standards. Industry and community must have an important role in driving these developments.

An excellent example of such an integrated approach is to be found in Taree on the mid-north coast of New South Wales. At one of the local high schools, a program has been implemented to allow attendance at school for five days a week, or school for four days and TAFE for one day, or school for three days, TAFE for one day and work experience for one day. This is a sensible program that goes a long way towards meeting the broad range of needs of the current student population, particularly with higher retention rates in high schools.

Fightback will help to accelerate reform programs such as the one being carried out at Taree. We will reduce and eliminate the unnecessary tax that is the training guarantee levy, and we will provide an additional $450m for TAFE over the rest of the decade. TAFE has a central role in lifting the levels of skills of Australians. It is the largest provider of post-secondary education and training and has a particular role in relation to upgrading adult skills and providing courses for disadvantaged groups. TAFE must be flexible and supportive of the needs of local industry and must be able to provide the training courses that industry requires.

Recognising the key role of TAFE in the national training arrangements, the coalition has undertaken to ensure that the growth of TAFE is adequately supported, and to this end undertakes to increase funding by over $450m over the rest of the decade, as I have already mentioned. The approach of the coalition to training is, therefore, very different to that of the Government. We vehemently opposed this legislation when it was first introduced. However, there are some benefits in the proposed amendments which include work experience for students and teachers in the eligible training program for the training guarantee levy. For this reason we do not oppose this

However, the training guarantee levy itself is simply the wrong way to go about bringing training to the forefront of the Australian workplace and it completely ignores the fact that training and education must be interlinked. That is why the coalition will abolish the training guarantee levy, which actually acts as a deterrent to training in many cases. We will replace it with an holistic approach to training and education that will see an additional $3 billion injected into education and training over the rest of this decade.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate, and for their support for the legislation.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 28 May on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will be supporting the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992 but with an amendment which I will speak about later and which I will move in the Committee of the Whole. This Bill confirms funding arrangements for local government with identified local roads money for the next three years—that is, for the 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 years.

PARA.TAB: These funds are one part of the Commonwealth's allocation to local government. The other part of the total funding to local government comprises financial assistance grants for general purposes which are untied. Currently, these untied grants stand at $719.7m. This part of the funding for local government is distributed by the Commonwealth Grants Commission between the States on a per capita basis.

However, the local roads grants—the ones totalling just over $300m which are dealt with by this Bill—are distributed not on a per capita basis but rather on a local roads needs basis. The percentage of moneys going to each State on the local roads needs basis is as follows: New South Wales, 30.9 per cent; Victoria, 21.9 per cent; Queensland, 20 per cent; Western Australia, 16.3 per cent; South Australia, 5.8 per cent; Tasmania, 3.9 per cent; and the Northern Territory, 1.2 per cent.

As this Bill provides for allocation on this basis, the percentages are the same as applied in the interim legislation which was dealt with by this Parliament last year and which in turn repeated the formula originally given in the land transport Act which used to distribute these local roads funds to local authorities. This formula gives a greater share of the total Commonwealth financial grant to Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory than those States would have received had these moneys been distributed in the same way as untied general purpose grants—that is, on a per capita basis. As I mentioned, it relates to local roads needs. It is probably appropriate that those States with the greater burden of local roads do receive a slightly bigger share of the cake.

It was decided at the Special Premiers Conference of October 1990 that local roads grants, although specifically identified for local roads, would be untied. This, of course, means that local authorities can use them for whatever purpose they like, even though they are identified as being for local roads use. The coalition supports this principle as it is in line with the coalition's policy which supports a federal system to distribute power in a way which encourages participation and acts as a barrier against centralist, remote and authoritarian control.

Tied grants can blur spending responsibilities and accountability, and governments also tend to blame decision making errors on other levels of government. We also had the ridiculous situation in the past where a great deal of time and money was spent filling in forms between local, State and Federal governments to ensure that money was spent in the way that the central government in Canberra directed. With the untying of funds, this waste of time and effort and the considerable bureaucracy that went with it will be avoided.

We believe the best decisions for local communities are made at the level closest to the local electorate. The local electorate will indicate its displeasure if local authorities spend money in anything other than a responsible and accountable way. To maximise competitive pressure and accountability for the benefit of the community, the Liberal and National parties favour each level of government being responsible, as nearly as possible, for its own revenue raising and expenditure decisions. There is general support amongst State governments and local authority peak bodies in each State regarding the allocation of these funds as provided in this

In my consultations in relation to this matter, some local authority people did raise with me the concern that untying roads funds might lead to a diminution in the importance of local roads to the Australian infrastructure. There has been a suggestion—and I know this concern is shared by my colleague Senator Panizza who will be speaking later—that the moneys might be issued with a condition that they at least be spent on roads but without any other conditions or accounting responsibilities. However, at this time it is the coalition's position not to support any conditions at all on the allocation of these funds. On that aspect, we support the Bill as it is.

In any case, my understanding is that most local authorities spend much more on their local roads than the Commonwealth grant. Therefore, the possibility that any councils will not use this money for their local roads is very remote, to say the least, although it is a matter which should be kept under consideration by the Federal Government. If it does not work out that way then it might have to be looked at again in the years ahead.

As I mentioned, the coalition believes that the best people to keep local governments on line and accountable are their own electors. I am confident, from my involvement with local government for more than a decade, that moneys allocated by the Commonwealth are spent responsibly at local levels and quite often more responsibly than when directions are given from the central government in Canberra. The States, having received the local road moneys that I mentioned earlier, will then distribute them within the States according to principles reflecting local roads needs. This will be done at the direction of the States Grants Commission on a needs basis.

Because of the lateness of this legislation, it is anticipated that the distribution of grants by the States Grants Commission for 1992-93 will be the same as applied in the last year. The principles reflecting needs for the following two years will be worked out between the Commonwealth and the Local Government Association in each State in the early part of the implementation of this I believe it is essential that the allocation for the following two years continues to be worked out on the basis of local roads needs.

I will move an amendment to this Bill which I do not think will be accepted by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). Although I advised the Minister of it over a month ago, there seems to be some confusion as to whether it will be supported.

PARA.TAB: The amendment is relatively minor.
