It makes me wonder just where Mr Jenkins might have got his advice from.

He seemed to think that the only reason we were moving the amendment in relation to Tasmania and the Northern Territory was simply to ensure that the Federal Labor Government had discussions with non-Labor governments in the two States. That his argument is so patently wrong is, of course, initially shown by the fact that if the amendment were for the purpose that the Labor Party suggested, we certainly would have included reference to the New South Wales Government, which is a non-Labor Government and is likely to be one, I might say, for many years to come. If that was the reason for the amendment, we would have also included Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and even Queensland, as those States will very soon have non-Labor governments. That will happen as soon as any of those current governments is prepared to go to the polls.

The amendment really relates to the fact that legislation indicates that for the Northern Territory and Tasmania there will be a change in the percentage of Commonwealth funding going to States for local roads needs and local authorities for local roads needs. Currently, State governments have some responsibility for local roads needs where there are no local authorities in charge. The same amount of money will be allocated, but there is this proposal in the legislation to shift some of the money from the States for local roads needs to the local authorities.

The second reading speech indicated that the Minister will discuss with the State and Territory the variation of percentages that will go to the Tasmanian Government as opposed to Tasmanian local authorities. However, in my consultations with the relevant parties, they suggested to me that it might be better if that undertaking to consult with the State Government and the Municipal Association of Tasmania, and the State Government and the municipal association in the Territory, were enshrined in the legislation to ensure that the Government did, in fact, have to consult and could not just rely on the Minister's word. So the amendment is very simply put. We will deal with it in the Committee of the Whole and I urge both the Democrats and the Government to support it.

I also say at this stage—again, I have been caught a bit unawares—and I raised it with the Minister just recently, that from talking with the Tasmanian authorities this morning there is a suggestion that the amount up to which that change of moneys might take place, which in the legislation is $4.41m, should be increased to $5.193m. That, again, is by arrangement between the Tasmanian Government and the Municipal Association of Tasmania. Apparently the MAT had written to or faxed the Minister about that amendment. The representative Minister in this chamber did not seem to be aware of it half an hour ago, so I am having that second amendment prepared in case it assists the Senate. Whether I move it will depend on whether the Government is going to move it. Again, it needed to fix up this legislation for the benefit of the parties involved.

The amendment to consult which I will move still leaves the final decision with the Federal Minister. He is required to consult. Having consulted, he then makes up his own mind, but the legislation requires him at least to enter into talks with the State and Federal authorities, which I am sure they would do in any case. For that reason I cannot see that the Government would have any objection to that.

The change in Tasmania, as I have mentioned, is occasioned simply because of the greater responsibilities given to some councils in some areas of that State. In the Northern Territory the change is occasioned by the fact that 52 additional local government bodies will be included in the local roads funding grants receiving a share of the money that was previously paid to the Northern Territory Government. A great majority of the new local governing bodies are Aboriginal communities which, prior to this, were excluded from this scheme.

The Northern Territory Government is happy with the proposals, although some finetunings are required to determine areas of responsibility. I understand that the Northern Territory Government is currently initiating talks with the Commonwealth in this regard. The amendment will ensure that the Commonwealth does consult before making decisions on the percentage to go from State government coffers to the local authorities.

The second reading speech to this Bill seems to be saying that funds relating to local roads needs are maintained in real terms. This is done by tying the quantum of local roads funding to local authorities to the general funding to States. In April 1991 this Government undertook to provide real term funding guarantees for the States. Through this Bill, they also pass on to the local authorities, but with a rider stating that it was on the understanding that Australia did not experience a major deterioration in its economic circumstances.

The Government has obviously very cleverly built in this escape clause to that statement. The current Budget blow-out from an anticipated deficit of $4.7 billion to the now—that is, a week or so ago—projected deficit of $9.2 billion, would seem to me to be a major deterioration in the economic circumstances of Australia or, more particularly, of this Government's management of it. It very seriously raises the concern that maybe the Government will cut back on funding to the States and local authorities as it has done, in the case of local authorities, in the last several years.

That is of some concern to me. Local authorities should be aware that this Government's promises to maintain local road funding in real terms are subject to that rider. The conditions in that rider would seem to have been met by the massive blow-out in the Government deficit. So I have some concern for local authorities around Australia that that funding will, in fact, be maintained in real terms over the next three years.This Bill does not guarantee it. All it guarantees is that it will keep pace with the States and the States will only get the funding providing there is no major blow-out in the economic circumstance of the country. It leaves me with some concern as to whether what local government authorities think they are now likely to get will, in fact, eventuate.

The Government is looking at a deficit of something like $23 billion if all of its promises recently announced are to be paid for. Curiously, that $23 billion is very close to the $27 billion we intend to recover from the GST proposals as part of our Fightback package. It seems to me that the Government is manoeuvring itself to introduce a consumption tax after the election. It would not do it beforehand because it does not have the guts to do that. Its deficit is almost what we are going to collect from the GST, and it seems to me that the Government is setting itself up to introduce a consumption tax.

It seems to me that the consumption tax is starting this week with the amendments to the sales tax legislation. Local governments are to lose their wholesales sales tax exempt status in certain areas because of this Government's sales tax legislation. It seems to be the first foot in the door for a consumption tax by this Government after the election, if it is extremely lucky enough to be re-elected. It is, I suppose, only academic because it will not be here, but the Government is not going to be game to do that. Mr Keating will have his way and introduce his 1985 preferred option of having a consumption tax to fund the $23 billion worth of promises that have been made. He cannot fund them and the only way he will be able to do it is by introducing a consumption tax.

The coalition is certainly introducing a GST, but the funds that we get from the GST will lead to massive personal tax reductions which we have identified for 95 per cent of Australians. It will mean that they will be paying no more than a marginal tax rate of 30c in the dollar, and as well other major savings will be funded. They will be paying a third less tax than they now do. In addition, there will be substantial reductions in personal income tax, as I mentioned, increased pensions for government pensioners of 8 per cent and other government benefits will go up by 6 per cent.

We will be completely abolishing wholesale sales tax and the fuel tax, which means that there will be a saving of 26c per litre for businesses and local authorities and a saving of 19c per litre for private motorists. We will also be abolishing the payroll tax and the training guarantee levy, both of which currently impost very heavily on local authorities around Australia. As I mentioned, it seems fairly clear to me that the Government will be introducing the same sort of consumption tax if it is lucky enough to be here in any strength at all after the next election.

Local governments will benefit substantially from the abolition of the fuel tax, the training guarantee levy and the payroll tax in those States which currently pay payroll tax on their water, sewerage and training activities. The savings that we will make to local authorities will be of great significance. I reiterate that the coalition will be cutting back Federal Government expenditure by a gross 10 per cent of existing current government expenditure. We will be paying some of that back in other benefits, but I might add that State and local governments will not be immune from the belt tightening which is needed to get Australia on the right path.

Our current foreign debt of $145 billion, which has increased from $23 billion when this Government took over, needs to be addressed. This can only be done by reducing wasteful duplication, and triplication in cases, of government expenditure. Because we recognise that local authorities have been more poorly treated in recent years by this Government and that their real terms funding has fallen, we will not be slashing our funding to them to the same extent, but we will be making a 5 per cent cut across the board to State and local governments. That will be the contribution of State and local governments to the belt tightening which is needed. I repeat the point so clearly made by the Municipal Association of Victoria that the savings to local authorities in fuel excise alone—the fuel excise we are going to abolish—will more than compensate for the reduced grants to local authorities under our proposals.

In my own community in the Burdekin Shire, on the last available full year's figures I have, the reduction of 5 per cent in the Federal assistance grant would be compensated more than twice over by the savings that council will make on the abolition of the fuel tax. I understand the situation is very similar right around Australia. Generally, the coalition has agreed to maintain funding at at least the current level on roads, but we will be doing this notwithstanding that we have completely abolished the fuel tax from general revenue. The private motorist will pay a GST of about—

PARA.TAB: The main purpose of the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992 has been spelt out already, but I will do so again. The Bill puts in place the decisions made at the 1990 Premiers Conference that funds for local roads be untied and paid at the same level to local government or State government via general purpose grants. Interim funding arrangements were provided for 1991-92 giving stability in the lead-up to the legislation being prepared. We all know how quick this Government is at getting legislation ready, so it has to have some interim position in place. Further funding arrangements are now set in concrete for the next three years, although in some cases there will be a loss of funding.

I suppose there is one good thing about all this, and that is, the Government is locked into this three-year program. But, as Senator Macdonald has already pointed out, it has included an escape clause so that if Australia's general economic well-being goes down in the next three years, local government funding will suffer. Fortunately, we will be in government in far less than three years and Australia's economy will turn around before then. So I can say that local government can look to a better future. Local government funding will continue to be identified separately rather than absorbed with general fund assistance.

Let us address the matter of untied grants. As Senator Macdonald said earlier, I have expressed fears concerning untied road grants. I must admit that I was rolled earlier. I thought I had the numbers but a certain chairman of our local government committee kept having meetings and my support eroded slightly as we went on. But I still have fears for these grants being totally untied. I believe in untied grants when there is specific funding for specific jobs. In Western Australia—and I presume throughout Australia—specific grants used to be tied to specific spots on the roads.

If a local government applies for funding for specific spots on a road, it will get funding for those spots. The site is inspected by a Department of Main Roads engineer and the local government applies for funding for that site, which may then be granted. The application has to be very specific. An example would be an application for a grant for work on a particular five kilometres of a road. I am very happy to move away from that situation. There is nothing worse than doing a specific job on a road and the funds running out when there is, say, only half a kilometre to go. Local ratepayers could not understand why that was the case. The equipment had to then be moved away. A lot of money has been wasted shifting road plants in remote areas, as it may be that there are hundreds of kilometres between jobs—although moving equipment so as to finish a job is a good idea.

I still have fears about untying grants completely. However, the legislation says that road funding will still be specified as road funding rather than as general grants, so I believe it is contradictory. I am happy to see how it performs over time. My fears are that different local governments will act differently. We have been told by Senator Macdonald and others that it is up to specific local governments how they spend their money and if a council does not spend it wisely then its local ratepayers will vote it out of office. That may be so, but it all depends where the local government is situated.

I fear for local governments that are controlled by the radical green movement. I can name three local governments in Western Australia that are in that situation, though I will not name them now. One green organisation does not want any more development in the area that it is associated with. It is doing its best to keep that development to a minimum.

There could be the situation where a local government does not spend money on roads and instead spends it on anything it wishes. As a result of the inconsistencies there will be a patchwork system of road standards throughout the States. Fortunately, these local governments that I have the greatest fear about are on the coastline. This means that they do not fit into the general arrangements for transport and roads across Western Australia. Nonetheless, there is a problem. In the next three years I look forward to seeing how this situation works out.

Each State will get road funding according to its particular needs. I believe that is the way we should head in Australia. New South Wales is going to have many headaches trying to work out where the most money is needed. I have never seen roads in such a shocking state. That situation was caused by the Wran Government neglecting rural areas in order to concentrate on inner city areas. In turn, a further problem is created. If we have a local government that is not spending money on roads then eventually its need for road funding will increase. That is a simple deduction.

The figures for exports on a per capita basis out of Australia are: New South Wales, $2,080; Victoria, $1,998; Queensland, $3,582; South Australia, $2,063; Western Australia, $7,459; Tasmania, $2,924—I am surprised that it is that high; the Northern Territory—because of its lack of population and high mineral base—$11,576; and the ACT $24. Tim Fischer will be proud of me for mentioning these figures. There is an Australian average of $3,025. That is the answer to how money should be distributed. I believe it should be distributed where the wealth is created. The people in those areas deserve a certain standard of living, as does anyone else. I fully support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Macdonald. I look forward to speaking in the committee stage.

—I am forced to be brief because of the guillotine. I have only a short time available. To allow Senator Boswell to contribute something to the debate and to allow the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to reply, I will be brief. There has been some criticism in this place this morning of the coalition's record on local government. Like my colleagues Senator Panizza and Senator Macdonald, our new shadow Minister, I have had experience in local government. I congratulate Senator Macdonald on his promotion. I can tell honourable senators, from my own experience, that on the ground, out there at the coalface where local government is doing the work and using the funds, the greater the flexibility it can receive, the better it is for local government. I commend the Government on this occasion for providing that flexibility in the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment

PARA.TAB: I do not believe the Government's record, over the last nine years, has been anything to crow about as far as local government is concerned. I remind Senator Powell, because she was critical of our Fightback package and the proposals for local government, that the thing that concerns local government, in my experience anyway, is consistency of funding and communication with the government of the day. I think in both cases this Government is at fault. In the nine years it has been in power what has it given local government? I hark back to the Fraser days, which are often quoted. In those days local government had financial recognition. Local government had a guaranteed percentage of personal income tax. Ask any person in local government, and he or she will say that the certainty of funding under those arrangements was far better than it has been in the last nine years. The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations was disbanded by the Hawke Government. This forum was at least tackling some of the problems, which are still there, of local, State and Federal government relations.

Honourable senators would remember the report put down in 1991 by the Commonwealth Grants Commission and its fiscal equalisation proposals that my colleague Senator Panizza talked about. After nine years we really have not got very far. We have had one report. The Commission wanted to do some more work on it, but unfortunately the Government could not find any money or the incentive to go on with it. During those nine years we had Mr Hawke vaunting his much advocated new federalism policy, but that has gone up in smoke with the change of Prime Minister. That has been replaced with an ad hoc State, Federal and local government arrangement a la Keating. I noticed only in the last few weeks that we are going back over the old story again. I noticed that Mr Keating is now talking about forming a council of local government—CAG for short. I expect that to be nothing other than another talkfest, as we have had in the past. It will be ignored under the new system of executive government which Mr Keating has thrust upon his Cabinet colleagues. We have had plenty of evidence of that in the last few days.

As this Bill deals with road funding I would like to remind the Senate of this Government's deplorable record in relation to road funding. In 1982-83—when the Labor Party came to power—the total fuel excise per litre was around 6.5c. It is now around 26c per litre. In 1982-83, 4.5c of the 6.5c was returned to road users. In this day and age, 6.5c of the total 26c is going back to roads. As a direct consequence, Australian motorists are paying heavily to subsidise the vote buying of this Government, and our road network will continue to deteriorate.

There has been much said by motoring organisations, local government and State governments about our roads. My colleagues Senator Panizza and, in particular, Senator Macdonald have talked about the effects of Fightback and how the removal of the 26c per litre fuel excise will help local government, as will the removal of the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, training levies and superannuation levies. I would remind those critics of the Fightback package of the assumptions made by the senior economist at the Municipal Association of Victoria; he has already been quoted by Senator Macdonald. We have the situation where, rather than there being criticism of the Opposition's proposals for local government, our record over many years of government has been one of support and reliability as far as local government is concerned.

All that local government has had in the last nine years is a very unreliable system of funding and a government that really makes a lot of noise about communicating with local government. But if we look at what has happened in the nine years there has been very little to show. It is somewhat of a change to be able to support the Government on this Bill because it does at least provide to local government some certainty of funding and some flexibility to local government in the use of funds.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill we are debating today is the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992. It formalises the arrangements for local government funding for the three years from 1992 to 1995. It is interesting to note that 82 per cent of the national road length of this country is the responsibility of local government. The provision of these funds, $300m, was previously administered under the Commonwealth assistance to local authority roads scheme, known as CALAR.

PARA.TAB: In 1990 the Special Premiers Conference decided that funds for local roads would be untied and paid to local governments or to State governments where they were responsible for local roads. That was done via a general purpose grant. It was decided then to distribute funds in 1991-92 under a set of interim arrangements reflected in the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1991. The present legislation is the culmination of exhaustive consultation between the Commonwealth, the States and local government. The Queensland Local Government Association and many councils in Queensland fought very hard to maintain the funding in the ratio that was decided upon. I refer to the proposals to depart from the historical practice of separately identifying the road element of local government funding within the general purpose grants. I am glad that the Government has backed away from this arrangement, and I hope that it is not only for this year. The passage of this legislation is a relief to many shire councils throughout Australia.

Since October 1990 the future funding for local roads has been under review while the interim arrangements were in place. This has led to uncertainty, and the local councils are faced with drought and low commodity prices in rural Australia at the moment. They have struggled to balance their budgets, and even a modest increase in rates is a tremendous burden to their ratepayers. In many of the smaller shire councils 20 or 30 people may pay 90 or 95 per cent of the rates. To put rates up at this time puts a tremendous burden on those people.

The legislation has some problems. The current formula for the distribution of road funding remains in place only for 1992-93; it is then to be reviewed for 1993-94 and 1994-95. Currently, the formula is based on a road length and population ratio: road length, 62.85 per cent; and population, 37.15 per cent. The current road length formula does not discriminate against unsealed roads—the majority of the roads in remote rural areas.

The Government is under pressure from both the cities and the large urban councils to vary this formula in favour of the more urban councils. Such a transfer of funding from rural councils would be devastating in the current rural recession. The cities have more significant rate bases and an $800m better cities program. I believe the way that the road funding will be distributed in the next 12 months is very fair and everyone should accept it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that in the short time available I should simply indicate that the Government appreciates the support of all of those who have spoken in this debate on the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992. Quite clearly, it is an important piece of legislation which has been arrived at after long and sometimes difficult but, in the end, constructive consultations with local government and State governments in order to ensure that the funding is provided back to local governments; back to that sphere of government which is so crucial to the well-being of Australians in their local communities.

PARA.TAB: Several amendments have been foreshadowed. Basically, in respect of those amendments, the Government can accept the amendment that looks for consultation with the Northern Territory and Tasmanian municipal associations, although it does not strictly think that this is necessary. Nevertheless, in the spirit of ensuring that local government understands that we are committed to the consultative process, that amendment can be accepted.

As to an amendment foreshadowed by Senator Macdonald in relation to moneys available to Tasmanian councils being increased from $4,410,000 to $5,193,000, once again, I am advised that that has been the subject of agreement as late as late yesterday between the Tasmanian Government and the Municipal Association of Tasmania. On that basis, understanding that what is involved is a transfer of funding virtually from the State Government to the local government bodies, that can be accepted. In fact, I think it would be best if that were put formally as an amendment moved by the Government, rather than by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Powell has not had circulated yet a second reading amendment to this legislation, so I forewarn people that it may be on the way.

PARA.TAB: Reading the debates on this legislation, both in the House of Representatives and the Senate, made me draw a very rare conclusion, one that I have always shied away from, and that is that the debate in the House of Representatives was second rate, tacky, not on the subject and generally did not add much to debate on the sorts of principles that are involved in this It is for once to the credit of the Senate that many of the principal issues have been addressed from a wide diversity of viewpoints. Senator Knowles and Senator MacGibbon probably represent the extreme view at one end, through to Senator Spindler and Senator Chamarette at the other. But all address the broad principles of the Bill, as did my colleague Senator Teague, who I apprehend has just come into the chamber. I congratulate them for addressing the principles of this

I want to turn to two or three areas. There is a general view around, especially expressed in the House of Representatives but partly reflected in Senator MacGibbon's speech, that this Bill was a result of the Gulf war. Let me say once and for all that that is not the case. A Senate committee, including the distinguished Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill), came up with the report on these matters referring to conscientious objection which was published in 1985. It is true that the Government took about a year to respond to that report. It took another couple of years for it to finally trickle through in the Defence Department that legislation should cover this area.

When I became Minister I made inquiries—and this was before the Gulf conflict—as to where the legislation should stand. I must say that my inquiries in all this were pushed along by Senator Tate, who has an office opposite me and who, every month or two, asked for a progressive report on how the drafting was coming along. I would have to say to him that this is not the most central legislation in terms of timing that Defence had at the time. Priority had to be given to other areas. However, to the credit of the legal people in the Department, they were able to draw up this Bill, which covers other matters which I do not think are contentious. I think we could say that the remaining contentious area of the Bill centres on conscientious objection and the provisions relating thereto.

So the timing of the Bill had nothing to do with the Gulf war. It had nothing to do with anyone's misperceptions about multiculturalism—nothing whatsoever. I know I am simplifying it, but there are two central points of disagreement in this chamber. The Opposition argues that there is no need for a provision within the Act where one can apply on conscientious grounds to a specific rather than a general conflict. It is the Government's view that we need to put this provision in the Act to cover that very small percentage of people who take their objections to a specific conflict.

We would prefer that this Parliament lay down the conditions—the criteria—for that sort of objection than let the courts go into some new merit making review process that binds us all. Both sides to the argument agree on one thing: we do not think it will be used very often because conscription almost inevitably will occur and only occur if the mainland of Australia is threatened. I cannot say any more than that. But certainly this side of politics has given that assurance, it is in our Party platform and that is where we stand on it.

Whilst I have had no assurance from those opposite, I suspect their general attitude in this modern day is that conscription would be necessary if the mainland of Australia were attacked. Under those circumstances and given the criteria we have put in the Act, it will not be easy to object in respect of that specific conflict. One would have to have a longstanding belief and there are three major conditions. So we hold our ground. Nevertheless, I respect the position put by the Opposition that its view is not based on any opportunism or any flawed philosophy as such. But we disagree on that issue.

There is disagreement on the 90-day rule. Reading the House of Representatives debate, it became absolutely clear to me that what was being proposed was not understood. Again, this is not of any massive moment either way.

We then come to the proposed Democrat amendments—certainly the arguments put by the Democrats—to give volunteer service persons the right to opt out of a specific conflict. I have to say that I draw the line there. There is no way that this Government can support that proposal.

When people sign up to go into the Australian defence forces, they do so in the knowledge that they could be involved in any number or any type of conflict. If at the point they are ready to sign up they believe that they cannot subscribe to or entertain becoming involved in some conflict, they should not join the armed services. But having gone to the enormous cost of training personnel and giving them general support—supplying everything from superannuation through to dentistry; the whole range of areas—we cannot be put in the position of being told, `Although we have accepted all those benefits, we will not do our expected duty'. That is the fundamental decision that is made at the time someone signs up and it is not to be made afterwards.

When we are involved in what we might call lower level conflict where conscription is not involved, service men and women can be exempted for a variety of reasons. They can be exempted on practical grounds—not on the grounds of a conscientious objection—from going to such a conflict. It may well be that a spouse is extremely ill. We do not force people to go overseas if they wish to be exempted on those sorts of grounds. But service personnel cannot opt out at the point we commit people to Cambodia, the Gulf or whatever other United Nations sanctioned operation we are involved in. The Government will rigorously oppose such a proposal.

In one sense this is a unique day for the defence debate in this country. Today the Opposition has announced that it no longer supports a bipartisan defence policy. I have no quibble with the Opposition about that. I find it strange that the Opposition made this announcement by way of press release in an address to a Sydney electorate rather than through a party room discussion. I wonder whether there has been a party room discussion on this point. Nevertheless, the Opposition has decided to end bipartisan defence policy.

This decision will mean that Bills such as the one we are now considering may well be debated in a different atmosphere in the future. One paragraph really stood out in the press release which announced the end of the bipartisan approach. Mr Downer said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . defence was not just about stopping small groups of foreign commandoes in Zodiac rubber boats throwing hand grenades at remote homesteads in northern Australia. It had to be more fundamental than that.

Well, by gee, it has to be a lot more fundamental than that. It has to be more fundamental than putting out inflated costs on service bands and calling for their abolition. We have to have a decent debate in which real figures can be discussed. It is not good enough to put out figures quoting the lowest possible Army presence in the Northern Territory, ignoring reservists, Air Force and Navy and totally ignoring the move north of 2 Cavalry Regiment and a brigade by the end of the decade.

PARA.TAB: I regret to say that we will now have some abrasive debates on defence. I hope they will be on the right issues. I hope that those debates will concentrate on the real substance of defence and not on the trivia, but I suspect this will be beyond the Arthur Daly of the shadow Cabinet and that, in fact, we will get the sorts of press releases we have had ever since he took over the shadow ministry. That is not to say that that will reflect on any job he will do as a future Defence Minister if, indeed, he ever becomes one.

There is a great difference between being an Opposition spokesman on defence matters and a Minister. I understand the difference. I understand the polemics required to retain one's position, to impress one's peers that one is being active and to be the greatest nuisance that one can be—in fact, to some oppositions, that shows that some progress is being made. I think that is true of all portfolios, but it is less true of the Defence portfolio because many of these issues go on into the future no matter which government is in power.

In those circumstances I will be quite fearless in analysing some of the past opposition-government defence policies, but I will not be callow about it. I will never fail to acknowledge some of the great defence policies produced by conservative governments. I still believe the decision to purchase the F18 was one of the most fundamentally sound decisions ever taken in this country. I note that during the massive defence cutbacks in the United States—where government expenditure on defence will go from 27 per cent to 16 per cent by 1995—there will be no fresh orders for planes except for 300 F18s.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new models.

—Nevertheless, 300 F18s will be purchased during the next three to five years. This again indicates that that decision was a very sensible one. I hope that, when we get to taws about defence, some of the sensible defence decisions made by this Government will not be dragged into the mud. When one gets into government one sometimes realises there is a degree of sense about such issues. As I say, it is interesting that for the first time in many years the Opposition defence spokesman said in a press release:

SPEECH.PARA: Coalition abandons bi-partisanship on defence.
So these sorts of debates may be a little more abrasive in future.

PARA.TAB: I will sum up the issues at hand in this The legislation, of course, goes to several very practical points. It puts ACPERS on a particular committee and it sets out defence superannuation issues, most of which I think are agreed in the chamber, and I certainly do not think these will be the last amendments of this sort in an omnibus

The central issues, however, are conscientious objection and conscription. Now is a very sensible time to discuss these issues, when there is no prospect of having to do either. Now is a sensible time to lay down these principles, not in the heat of a potential conflict or an involvement overseas, and not at a time when there might be a very heated and emotional debate. I do not think any of us at the moment consider conscription to be likely in the next few years, so this is the time to lay down those principles to guide people into the future.

I pay tribute to the committee work done in the Senate in 1985 which forms the basis for most of these recommendations. I suspect that at the end of the day the Opposition and Democrat amendments will fail, and that there will be a bit of a Mexican stand-off with the Government being in the middle. Nevertheless, all sides in this chamber can probably live with these provisions because they are far more precise. No-one in this chamber disagrees with doing away with the classes of call-up which existed from, I think, 1913, if not 1901, which, to say the least, were chauvinistic, racist and sexist—totally out of the way of modern thinking. All those particular classes are gone.

At the end of the day, when this particular Bill seeks passage through the chamber we will be in a position where most of us, at least, will be able to say that it is a reasonable We have minor disagreements on these two clauses: that is, the Opposition disagrees with being able to object to a specific conflict, which I think is the major objection, and there is a minor disagreement over the 90-day rule. In the end, given the Democrats' concern expressed during the Gulf conflict—a concern that I was critical of because I thought it whipped up unnecessary rumours and other things—they can now be a lot happier with the way the Bill is cast in terms of specifics, appeal rights for conscientious objectors, et cetera. It makes all those particular provisions and, as such, I think it will draw support.

I do not know whether Senator Chamarette is here; I have not seen her here this week and I do not think anyone else has. I do not draw anything from that other than to say that because she is not here I may not take it upon myself to respond to the various issues that she has raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement today regarding the youth summit to be held on 22 July. Why will the meeting be held in private in Parliament House? Why will the media have an opportunity only to gain overlay footage and record the Prime Minister's opening remarks? Is this not confirmation that the summit is a political stunt, with the Government terrified of the possibility of adverse publicity?
—Let me answer first the question as to why the meeting will be held in private. It is a meeting of, I think, some 40 people.
—That is not a good reason.

—No, that is not the reason. I will come to that. Why will it be held in private? My answer to that is: why not? It is a meeting to deal with issues acknowledged by the Government as being very serious.
—It is so we don't see the deals that are being done behind the doors.

—No, it is not a question of doing deals in private. Senator Alston is obsessed with the notion of transparency. I can understand that—I can see right through his head from where I stand. Given the composition of the groups which will be at the meeting, it is the Prime Minister's judgment—and certainly mine, as an observer—that it is much better that it be held in private. In any of these functions it is normal for some media exposure to be given to the introductory part of the proceedings. That will happen. I do not think there is anything abnormal about this at all. It is a very sensible solution.

—Is the Minister for Justice aware of the decision by the Tasmanian Government to pay a total of more than $330,000 to cover the legal costs of persons involved in the State's political bribery royal commission, including Mr Edmund Rouse and Mr Robin Gray? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the current financial circumstances of the Tasmanian Legal Aid Commission and the State's community legal centres network?

—I am aware of media reports to the effect of Senator Coates's question. In fact, Tasmania is in uproar this morning as it has been revealed that the State Cabinet is prepared to pay almost $340,000 to those who were involved in appearing before the bribery royal commission, including an amount of $53,000 to the millionaire businessman who was convicted and goaled—I think he served about 18 months in goal—for his attempt to pervert the course of democracy in Tasmania. Not only is the Tasmanian taxpayer being asked to meet the legal costs of those who appeared before the royal commission and the Supreme Court in a futile challenge to prevent the bribery royal commissioner's report being published because of an allegation of bias against Mr Carter, which the full Supreme Court threw out, but also the Cabinet has decided that the Crown will not press for the $150,000 it cost to defend the bribery royal commissioner against those unfounded charges of bias.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Questions must be asked in relation to the portfolio of the Minister. I do not believe the Minister has referred to his portfolio at all in his answer but is referring to issues in Tasmania.
—Order! Senator Tate was asked about two organisations that I believe he is responsible for. I would ask him to deal with that part of the question.

—I was just about to relate this matter to my direct responsibilities, shared with the Attorney-General of Tasmania, for the functioning of the Tasmanian Legal Aid Commission. That Commission, despite the $5m that the Commonwealth pays towards its costs, is operating in a way which leads it to refuse legal aid advice and representation in the courts to many people who do not qualify because of the increasingly stringent means test which has to be applied. This means that even those on social security, unemployment benefits and pensions of one sort or another who would normally be expected to qualify cannot obtain legal aid, this in a situation where the Tasmanian Cabinet is prepared to pay $340,000 in respect of the costs of those who have a flow of income and an expectation of income—
—Because you gave $10m in funds to the ACTU, you hypocrite!
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. There was a direct—
—Order! I heard it and I ruled on it the other day. You will withdraw that comment, Senator Kemp.
—I withdraw my comment.

—I understand the sensitivities, but I think it is a real question of social justice where those who cannot obtain legal aid through the Legal Aid Commission are faced with the obscenity of $340,000 being provided to these people who have an income flow, have income expectations, which will well enable them to meet their legal expenses, though it may cause some difficulty even to a millionaire businessman.

PARA.TAB: What one has to look to is the fact that I have provided over the last year an extra $200,000 to the Tasmanian Legal Aid Commission to help it meet its increasing commitments. I have also provided a quarter of a million dollars for community legal centres in Devonport, Bridgewater, North Hobart and Launceston, none of which is helped by the Tasmanian Government at all.

My challenge to the State Cabinet, if it adheres to this particular decision in a shameless sort of way, is that it ought to make an equivalent amount of $340,000 available to the State Legal Aid Commission so that it can show that it does understand the principles upon which legal aid should properly be based. That $340,000 would be very beneficial indeed in ensuring our social justice objectives for those who are without sufficient financial means to enable them to obtain legal advice and representation.

I refer the Minister to the latest gaffes by Mr Beazley regarding the Government's proposed youth job summit, in particular his remarks that youth unemployed people would not be represented at the summit and that the summit details would be announced by the Prime Minister in a few weeks, remarks which were contradicted by the Prime Minister yesterday. Can the Minister tell the Senate whether the Minister for unemployment will be making any decisions about his portfolio in the future or will it continue to be run by the Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —No question was directed to me as the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. If honourable senators opposite want to turn this place into a carnival and use questions in order to make trite and pathetic political points, they cannot expect the Government to cooperate by answering.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If Senator Cook is that precious-
—Direct your question to the proper Minister, otherwise you don't get an answer. Don't be a smart alec.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Ray used an unparliamentary word across the chamber, and I ask that you ask him to withdraw it. I will not repeat it because I would not repeat it in this place. He called one of my colleagues something that should be withdrawn. I ask you to ask him to withdraw it.
—Order! I did not hear any comment. Senator Ray, did you make any unparliamentary comments?
—Mr President, I did not say anything unparliamentary. I would be happy to withdraw, but Senator Patterson has misheard what I said.
—I did not.
—She absolutely did. All my colleagues affirm and I affirm I did not say the word which she has indicated to me across the chamber .
—Order! Senator Knowles can ask a supplementary question. It is up to the Minister whether he answers it.
—Thank you, Mr President. As I was starting to say, seeing that Senator Cook is so precious and cannot take a little bit of pressure—
—Get on with it. Stop wasting our time.
—Stop chucking a wobbly, Senator Ray. Behave yourself. You will have a heart attack. Just behave yourself.
—Order! Ask the question.

—I direct my question to Senator Cook or, if he wants what he believes to be his correct title, to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment—except there is none—Education and Training. I refer the Minister to the latest gaffes by Mr Beazley regarding the Government's proposed youth jobs summit, in particular his remarks that unemployed youth would not be represented at the summit and that the summit details would be announced by the Prime Minister in a few weeks, both of which were contradicted by the Prime Minister yesterday. Can the Minister tell the Senate whether the Minister for Employment, Education and Training will be making any decisions about his portfolio in the future or whether it will continue to be run by the Prime Minister? I hope Senator Cook can answer that question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be a pretty bad day if the fundamental courtesies of proper debate were not observed in this chamber. The question asked by Senator Knowles is really a question to the Government in the format, `When are you going to stop beating your wife?', which is a non-question.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—The fact, however, is that at least one of the premises of that question is fundamentally wrong. I am not so sure about the other: if Senator Knowles continues in her normal tradition, it probably is as well, but I do not have any perfect knowledge of whether it is or not.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the allegation about what Kim Beazley, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, said, he did not say at any point that young people should not attend the job summit. I have in front of me a transcript of an interview with Kim Beazley in Cairns on Monday, 22 June 1992. In that transcript there is this question:

ANSWER.PARA: Weren't you quoted yesterday as saying that it wasn't appropriate or wasn't necessary to have youth representatives at that summit?

I think the point I was making yesterday, was this. That what we need now is a statement from people who are capable of providing employment as to how they propose to do it. Whether or not young people are represented at the summit, the most important thing is we do know what young people want—they want training, they want jobs, and what we've got to do is to get from business as from Government training and jobs.

At no point did Kim Beazley say that young people should not be at the job summit. He said that the most important thing—and I think this will enlighten the debate a little—is that representatives of government and business should be there to talk about how jobs for young people should be created. That is the most important thing. We all know as a fact that young people in Australia want jobs and want access to training.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, we want to hear from responsible youth organisations what the experience of unemployment is. One in no sense belittles that because we as a government have consistently said how alarmed and concerned we are at the tragedy of the high level of unemployment in this country, particularly youth unemployment. We certainly want to hear the experiences and frustrations at, if you like, the consumer end of the market. But, quite clearly, the most important objective of this youth summit is to look at and gather from the community whatever ideas business, unions, the community aid sector and others can put forward to assist in the improvement of youth employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing for youth unemployment?

—I conclude in the face of some of the interjections that I am now hearing from those opposite. If they would like, I would be delighted to hear how they think a Liberal Party job summit, being conducted at a national Liberal Party convention as nothing more than a stunt thought of at the last minute, can do anything material to improve employment.

PARA.TAB: I would be delighted if at that so-called summit it could be explained how a 15 per cent consumption tax on all goods and services would help jobs. I would be delighted to know whether at that summit it can be explained how pushing people off the dole to fend for themselves after nine months will help employment. I would be delighted to know how the termination of the Commonwealth Employment Service and youth access centres will help employment and young people. I would be delighted to know how, under the so-called consumption tax package, the absolute reduction in funding to technical and further education will help job opportunities and training.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask that the Minister table the aNiMaLS transcript of Mr Beazley's fumblings that he quoted from.
—It is a matter for the Minister whether he will table it or not.
—I have my own notes on it and I am not prepared to make those available.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister said that he was quoting from the transcript during his answer.
—Order! There is no point of order. Whether or not the Minister wants to table a document that he is quoting from is his prerogative.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Justice to the current affairs show 60 Minutes last Sunday night, which claimed that 40 per cent of first marriages and 50 per cent of second marriages end in breakdown. Is the Government doing anything to assist Australians in the critical times in their marriages?
—Keep them out of politics.
—Several of my colleagues say that the stress caused by being in politics is something which can affect marriages. There is no doubt about that; many of us would attest to that.

PARA.TAB: The television program 60 Minutes did indicate, through what I thought at times was a very moving interview with a couple who were participating in marriage counselling, some of the ways that stresses and strains within a marriage relationship might be overcome or assisted by the intervention of a marriage counselling service, though this will not be appropriate in all situations. Nevertheless, the Commonwealth has provided, and been a major source of funds, for community based organisations which are undertaking such counselling.

I do not know why Senator Bishop is shaking her head in a negative way. I would have thought that this was a good piece of news. The Federal Government has been prepared to make available an amount of $15m in addition to the moneys available to the marriage counselling and family stability programs, which are a matter of great concern to the Commonwealth Government. We have a responsibility under the Family Law Act to provide such services.

Since 1990, the Government has allocated around $15m for preventative measures in support of stable marriage and family life through the family services program. This has been going extremely well. It has been my great pleasure to be involved around the country with those providing marriage counselling, marriage education, family mediation and family skills training services.

In particular, what was useful to see outlined in the 60 Minutes program was the comment by the couple concerned that they wished they had participated in pre-marriage education classes. I believe that these are being increasingly recognised in the community as being of use to provide those skills which might prevent disharmony from emerging or, if it does, to provide a means by which skills might be developed to deal with that disharmony.

Couples contemplating marriage are encouraged to participate in pre-marriage education programs. Whilst there has been a doubling of money in recent years for such programs, it is certainly my intention in the coming Budget to press for further funding for those programs.

I believe that 60 Minutes is to be commended for broadcasting this segment. It has brought to the attention of the community the capacity for obtaining assistance in these matters. Particularly in relation to marriage education, I believe there is a recognition that if this particular training in the skills required to enable a relationship to endure stresses and strains can be made available in the early stages of married life, it may be that the marriage can survive, whereas if it were not for the education provided it could disintegrate under great stress.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to last week's CAI and Westpac June survey of industrial activity in which respondents said that business conditions over the next six months are expected to be better than at any time since 1988. I ask the Minister: firstly, does the Government's research support this expectation, and, secondly, are these survey results relevant to the claims about the capacity of industry with payrolls over $1m to absorb the initial one per cent of the superannuation guarantee charge?

—In answer to a question last week I talked about the CAI-Westpac survey of industrial trends. The survey is more optimistic than since 1988. The press statement from the Confederation of Australian Industry and Westpac stated that `the worst appears to be over for the manufacturing sector' and that manufacturers `now expect new orders and output to stage a recovery'.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot asked me whether this is consistent with Government forecasts. I would be hesitant to say that, except to say that most Government forecasts and available information suggest that a slow recovery is in progress and confirm that it may be better for the manufacturing sector than some other sectors of the economy over the period in question. For example, the March quarter national accounts showed GDP growth for three consecutive quarters, housing and private consumption spending is showing clear signs of growth, and so are retail sales and housing approvals.

I do not think that the optimism of a short term business outlook means terribly much for the superannuation guarantee levy. After all, the superannuation guarantee charge is a structural reform which will improve retirement incomes and national savings over the longer term. That is to say, it is not a question of comparing the next six months with the longer term benefits which will accrue from the superannuation guarantee levy.

It is sometimes said it is never the best time to address underlying long term issues facing Australia. That is a failure of the `she'll be right, mate' culture at all levels—government, business and unions. Short term crises all too often crowd out action to address the structural problems facing the economy, such as, for example, the youth unemployment issue, which has been the subject of questions here today and during the week.

The Government does not resile from addressing this issue and from ensuring that the SGC addresses the important issues of adequate retirement incomes for an ageing population and improving the savings performance of the economy. There is no point in making false promises about that or coming up with fake solutions, as some political parties tend to do. The Government and the Democrats have agreed on a timetable for the implementation of the SGC. It is designed to ensure that firms will be able to absorb the costs with a negligible impact on employment. The Democrats are to be congratulated on the great amount of time and work they have put into their position on this issue.

It is expected that wage increases will take into account the increased superannuation guarantee contribution, and industrial relations legislation will be amended to require the Industrial Relations Commission to give consideration to the SGC in its determination of wage increases. It should also be noted that the increase in the SGC over the decade is a fraction of expected productivity improvement as we come out of the recession and that it can be absorbed.

I should add that another important consideration in all of this—and one which has been important for some time—is that the Government has a wage policy that has succeeded in restraining real wage costs. It will continue to do that. It is unfortunate that in addressing this issue the Opposition does not have such a policy. It has a recipe for industrial anarchy, and one which does nothing to improve the standards of living of ordinary Australians.

So, in terms of the short term outlook, I think the Westpac-CAI survey material is encouraging. I hope that material will be built on in future surveys and show a longer term trend improvement in the economy. In so far as the SGC is concerned, it is Government policy that it should go ahead anyway as a longer term structural reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand the Minister's caution, and it is refreshing to see somebody talking about the long term, but is it not really important—
—Why don't you go and hold hands?

—I would not hold hands with Senator Boswell. Is not the issue here, for once, the crucial factor of the short term difficulties for business; is it not true that businesses expect to wait nine to 12 months for the slow recovery to flow on to them; and does this affect their attitude to their capacity to pay?

—Certainly, I agree with that, in so far as in the heat of the current moment, with a fair degree of uncertainty amongst businesses, even though the CAI-Westpac survey is very positive, it is important that there be a positive survey like that in the context of some confusion. These sorts of structural changes, historically, as far back as one likes to go, are traditionally opposed by employers for a variety of reasons. As far as the timing of the implementation of the levy is concerned, particularly the January payment of the levy, I think the survey is very important and, I hope, encouraging to a lot of businesses in that climate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister advise the Senate on the status of the review on the conversion of the broad gauge lines in the south-east of South Australia to standard gauge? Is the Minister aware of the major benefits for rail freight and primary producers in regional areas of South Australia and Victoria if the Wolseley to Mount Gambier line, the Murray-Mallee ancillary lines and the Mildura to Portland lines can be converted and linked to standard gauge? Can the Minister also advise on the progress of the standardisation of the Adelaide to Melbourne rail link?

—I am aware of those benefits. A key element, of course, of the One Nation statement that the Prime Minister brought down was the conversion of the Melbourne-Adelaide line to standard gauge. The Minister for Land Transport has provided me with the following information. The South Australian Government has agreed that passenger rail services to Mount Gambier will not be re-established, as it is not economic to standardise the existing broad gauge spur line, given the traffic that it carries. The Commonwealth is awaiting advice from Australian National on the implications of standardisation on the remainder of the broad gauge network in eastern South Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Government understands that Australian National is undertaking a review of the viability of these lines. The Australian National review is looking at the benefits for rail freight users and primary producers in South Australia and Victoria of standardising relevant branch lines. Satisfactory progress is being made on carrying out the projects outlined in the One Nation statement.

The Commonwealth has established working groups chaired by the NRC, and including the States, other rail systems and the private sector, which are developing specific details of the One Nation projects and examining the best methods of completing them. In particular, the Melbourne-Perth working group is looking at details of standardisation between Melbourne and Adelaide and such options as resleepering and route selection to ensure that productivity on this route is maximised. The Government understands that the working group has made considerable progress in finalising these projects and will shortly be presenting detailed proposals to the Minister for Land Transport.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to the study by Melbourne University's Youth Research Centre into school retention, reported in yesterday's Age newspaper. I ask whether the Minister recognises that the current school retention rate conceals a significant shelter effect whereby:

QUESTION.PARA: Children are staying at school because there is nowhere else to go. That means a lot of them in a sense are wasting their time.

Can the Minister report on how many senior school students might fall into this category? Will the Minister concede that the existence of this dissatisfied group makes a farce of his Government's claim that only one in 10 young Australians is suffering from the effects of the recession his Government said we had to have?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Vanstone would know, I represent the Minister for Employment, Education and Training in this place. I saw the reference to the report in the Age yesterday, but I am not familiar with the findings of the report and I cannot profess now to be able to deal expertly with all of its findings. However, I can say with quite strong emphasis that young people who are undergoing training or formal education in the academic stream through universities are not—and categorically not—wasting their time.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition does not comprehend that we, as a government, have a vision for Australia which is an Australia which is world competitive, highly skilled and highly paid because it is putting out a world competitive export product. That requires a massive investment in training and education. Since coming to office in 1983, we have increased expenditure on higher education by 42 per cent in real terms. We have created the equivalent of 17 new universities. In terms of the One Nation statement, we have made a commitment to training for technical and further education of $720m. That compares with Dr Hewson's consumption tax package of $75m in technical training.

We have committed those funds because we believe a well educated and highly skilled Australia will be able to absorb new technology, will be up with the pace and will become world competitive in its manufactured exports and its service exports. That is a fundamental commitment to restructuring in the economy. It is not something directed at unemployment. That point is not well understood. It is directed at making Australia world competitive. The fact that it has a massive beneficial impact on unemployment is a favourable outcome, not an unfavourable one. I do not think anyone who is learning new skills and acquiring new knowledge is wasting his or her time. To categorise them in that form is to misunderstand the direction of fundamental policy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister understand that it is simply a matter of added interest, making it more topical, that a body with some qualification to speak raised this general point a day or so ago in the newspapers? The Minister has come in here ill-equipped to answer a question on a general point in relation to his responsibilities. That general point is whether the recession his Government said we had to have has created a shelter effect whereby:

QUESTION.PARA: Children are staying at school because there is nowhere else to go. That means a lot of them in a sense are wasting their time.
That is a general point. Would the Minister care to comment on that from his wide experience?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have now been invited to draw on my wide experience, which I am always delighted to do. I was invited before to comment specifically on the recommendations and findings of the report which I said I was not familiar with in close detail, but now I am enjoined to draw on my wide experience. I left school in 1957—sorry, I left school in 1960; I went to high school in 1957. My God, those opposite have got me; what a massive tragedy this is. I left school in 1960 and I could not get an apprenticeship because of the credit squeeze which had been induced into the Australian economy by the then Menzies Government. Thus I did not get access to training. As a young kid from a working class family, I wanted to have a job opportunity based on access to an apprenticeship.

PARA.TAB: Were I now in the same situation and facing the difficulties in this economy, I would be grateful for the fact that I had an opportunity to learn some other skills and acquire some other knowledge which would fit me for a job in an expanding economy which is requiring more sophisticated skills to be world competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to the welcome improvement in Australia's waterfront productivity being achieved under the Government's reform program. How does this productivity compare with the performance of ports in New Zealand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Waterfront reform in Australia is now demonstrating real gains, efficiencies and reliabilities, particularly since the move to full enterprise employment at our major ports. At this point I should pay tribute to my colleague Senator Collins, who presided over a very successful era of waterfront reform in Australia. What has that period of office achieved? More than 4,200 employees have exited the industry, which represents a 43 per cent reduction in the work force. By the end of the reform program later this year, the work force is expected to be effectively halved. This is well beyond the net reduction of 2,000 employees originally recommended by the Inter-State Commission's waterfront report.

PARA.TAB: It compares favourably with the New Zealand reforms, which have also seen an overall reduction of about 50 per cent in employees on the New Zealand waterfront. Our container terminals have improved container handling rates by between 60 and 80 per cent. Australia's productivity rates in handling containers are comparable with those in New Zealand. For instance, the average container crane rate in Auckland is 18 containers per hour, which is the same as the average across Australia's major ports.

Intense competition between our stevedores induced by the reform program has resulted in container handling charges for new business and contract renewals being about 30 per cent lower than they were last year. This means that the stevedoring charges on containers in New Zealand and Australia, as far as they can be reasonably compared, are now similar.

There is some need for further attention in the area of port authorities. Concerns have been raised recently regarding the higher level of port costs in Australia compared with New Zealand. This is primarily a matter for State governments. However, the current inquiry by the Industry Commission into port services and activities is expected to shed light on the validity of these comparisons.

That is an outstanding record of reform and improvement on the Australian waterfront. But, of course, it is not good enough for the Opposition, which is hell-bent on downgrading this country in the eyes of its trading partners. It is supposed to be Her Majesty's loyal Opposition, but it is not an Opposition loyal to the interests of Australia. New Zealand is the big icon for the Opposition.

I notice that the shadow Minister for shipping, Mr Sharp, recently claimed that the Australian reform program is a fundamental failure compared with New Zealand. I wish he would get it right. Mr Sharp has used the wrong data. He has used trans-Tasman shipping report data which is now outdated. The report's information was collected well before the radical restructuring of our stevedoring sector was fully implemented and before the achievement of the significant productivity changes to which I have referred.

The allegations of the Opposition are not only disloyal but also based on wrong data to create a false impression and to undermine the confidence of the many Australians who have worked very hard to achieve these significant reforms. I wish the Opposition would find out the facts before condemning this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Does the Minister agree that the union to union bans on third countries being involved in trans-Tasman shipping have no legal sanction? Is the cost of this closed shop to the two countries in the order of $110m annually? Will the Minister support moves by New Zealand in the current closer economic relationship talks to remove this disgraceful practice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we have Senator Parer—
—Come on; answer the question.

—I will answer the questions. I am just coming to the answer to those questions. Here we have Senator Parer yet again trying to make an impression about inefficiency and lack of reform and change in Australian shipping, which is not true. The reform that has been undergone of Australian shipping in the last several years of this Government is massive, overwhelming and recognised by the users as well as the shippers as being quite significant.
—It is the cabotage.

—It is the cabotage. I understand the question. The Australian position in the trans-Tasman shipping agreement will be consistent with that which has been advocated by my colleague Senator Collins. That will be a position of continuing to achieve the necessary reforms, breaking down any monopolies and ensuring competition, but on the basis of offering some security for employment to Australian seamen as well.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of that answer, what did the Minister mean by consistent with the position taken by Senator Collins? Does it mean that he will continue with the practice of union to union bans on third parties being used on the trans-Tasman? The first question I asked was whether the bans had legal sanction, to which the Minister did not reply. That is another question that I would like to throw at him again. Does he intend, as the Minister assisting the President of the ACTU, to stick with this rort because of the involvement of the Seamen's Union and the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ignore the attempt at slight humour by Senator Parer.
—It was very slight.
—It was so slight that anyone could miss it.
—When did you leave school?

—I left school at the end of 1960. Had there been a Labor government in Australia at that time, I would have done a lot better than I did under the Menzies Government. Now that we have cleared up that quite significant point, I make the point quite categorically that we do not support illegal bans or illegal operations. If we wish to contrast and compare our record of reform in shipping with that proposed by the Opposition, our record has been endorsed by the industry; in fact, even grudgingly recognised by, I think, Mr Sharp on the odd occasion. It is regarded universally as being a model for other countries as well.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is. That has to be compared with the type of confrontationist attitude that the Opposition would have, which would not succeed at consensual change but would plunge the industry into chaos and confrontation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Is the Minister aware of the allegations raised on this morning's Today program by journalist Fia Cumming that the meat substitution racket which jeopardised Australia's beef trade in the early 1980s is back in action; that National Parks and Wildlife officers and also Australians Customs Service officials have been and are involved in wildlife smuggling, in particular bird smuggling, and the rorting of the distribution and policing of kangaroo shooting licences; and that at least three murders have occurred in connection with these practices? Will the Minister guarantee to fully investigate these allegations and, if necessary, set up a full Federal inquiry to get to the bottom of these matters?

—I did not see the Today program this morning, though I have heard some reports of an interview that was conducted on it which raised certain of the allegations that have been repeated in the chamber here by Senator Lees. In relation to the meat substitution racket, if this relates to certain documents which I understand Senator Lees tabled in the chamber late last week, I do not think there is any general evidence of revival of the meat substitution racket in those documents. But the Government is well able to make proper policy in relation to those who might be involved in abattoirs or meat processing plants in Australia for export and well able to make proper decisions based on up-to-date law enforcement intelligence, and that has been undertaken. That is all I wish to say on that matter.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees raised the question of wildlife smuggling and the netting of birds and so on. I understand that some of the documents Senator Lees tabled in the chamber late last week related to incidents which were alleged to have occurred back in the 1970s and early 1980s. They were the subject of investigation by the AFP and, I think, the New South Wales and Queensland police at the time. I would have to check that that is the matter Senator Lees or Miss Cumming was referring to.

In relation to the questions raised by Senator Lees, I believe that some of them fall within State criminal laws rather than within the Federal jurisdiction. As to whether it would be a matter for a national inquiry, I think it would be far too premature to say. I will give an undertaking to Senator Lees to ensure that both my officers and those of the relevant Federal Minister for quarantine and other matters will examine all the papers that were placed before the Senate by Senator Lees. If Miss Cumming has any further information which could be useful, I would be most appreciative if she would forward such information to my office where she can be assured that it will be dealt with in the strictest of confidence and passed to the relevant authorities which might be able to help with further investigation if it was merited.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the industrial strike at Hamersley Iron in the Pilbara province of Western Australia, a strike involving 2,000 workers and caused by the unions because of one employee exercising his right not to join a union.
—Caused by him then.

—`Caused by him', says Senator McKiernan. I refer the Minister to Commissioner Fielding's direction for a return to work which has been defied by the unions. I particularly refer Senator Cook to the 14 workers at Tom Price who have obeyed Commissioner Fielding's direction to return to work and have defied the picket lines to so do. I ask: does Senator Cook support the rule of law and those workers who have complied with Commissioner Fielding's direction or does he support the illegal picket line and the picketers who have defied it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I answered a question from Senator Crichton-Browne on this subject on Friday. After the question he took note of my answer and we engaged in a small debate about it. Perhaps it is worthwhile making a number of very small and quick points about that. Hamersley Iron entered into an agreement with its unions in 1982. Part of that agreement was to recognise the obligation on people employed by Hamersley Iron to be a member of a union.
