The legislation was introduced into the Western Australian Parliament in December 1982 by the then O'Connor Government, which removed from the Industrial Relations Act that section of the Act which enabled such an agreement to be registered. As a consequence, the terms of that agreement were eliminated.

PARA.TAB: The point I make about that is this: what we are seeing played out in the Pilbara, unfortunately, is a damaging dispute which has national implications and implications for our balance of payments. It is a dispute being conducted under laws enacted by a Liberal government and not under laws preferred by a Labor government. It is therefore in microcosm a reflection of a conservative view of how industrial relations should be conducted, not how industrial relations should be conducted from this Government's point of view.

However, the question to me is: do I support the rule of law? That is almost an offensive question. It goes without saying that of course I do and, as a responsible Government Minister, I have an obligation to uphold it and I do. I support the rule of law. In this case I do not agree necessarily with what the law says because I think the law is wrong and I understand the circumstances which have caused the dispute to occur. Nonetheless, there is a fundamental obligation to obey the law and change it by constitutional means. I do support the law and I enjoin those who are on strike in the Pilbara to comply with the direction of Commissioner Fielding and return to work and enable the matter to be settled by other means.

What I understand as the current status in this dispute is that the Deputy Industrial Registrar at Karratha in the Pilbara is investigating ways in which the matter might be resolved. That is a function for the Industrial Relations Commission. Hamersley Iron has not taken the matter further, nor has the Western Australian Government, nor have the unions and nor has the individual concerned. What I counsel in this position is that people should not turn this dispute into a political football. They should allow the Commission to operate. The matter is before the Commission; it is in the Commission; and it is being—

TALK.START.PARA: —It has; it has decided.
—Yes, it is operating further, Senator. It is now doing some other things to try to resolve the matter. In the meanwhile, the direction of Commissioner Fielding should be complied with.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. To the extent that the Minister says that he agrees with the rule of law, does he accept the right of a worker to contract his labour with an employer without being compelled, coerced, threatened or intimidated into joining a union, which is what this strike is currently about?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —In this case, the law is quite explicit: no-one can take action against an individual if he does not wish to be a member of the union. If action is being taken against such an individual, the onus of proof is upon the person against whom the allegation is made; in this case, nominally that would be Hamersley Iron. So there has been a shift in the onus of proof to the defendant, and not to the person making the allegation. That is what the law is.

PARA.TAB: Of course, I support the rule of law and seek always to change it by constitutional means. Were the Legislative Council in Western Australia not gerrymandered and elected by one vote, one value, the law would have changed long ago by virtue of the incumbency of the Labor Government in Western Australia. The law remains simply because the legislation is unable to be changed by the Government which commands the treasury bench and which is the Government of the State. It is an example of the Government being in government but not in power.

However, Senator Crichton-Browne is asking another matter again. He is asking: what is just? In my view the law is not always just. If I had the option, I would change the law and make it just. In this particular case, there is the right of the individual, which I recognise and acknowledge. There is also the right of the 2,000 other individuals who have negotiated their agreement with Hamersley Iron and achieved for themselves, by virtue of that negotiation in what is a typical enterprise agreement, a set of rates and conditions upon which they have also managed to function. They say that their rights, as a collective group of individuals, are endangered by someone freeloading on the basis of picking up the conditions and achievements that they have reached, and they believe that there ought to be an obligation on freeloaders. I understand that point of view. But in these circumstances I return to my reply: I enjoin those unions in the Pilbara to abide by Commissioner Fielding's direction to return to work and enable this matter to be sorted out by the processes of the Deputy Industrial Registrar in Karratha.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer to the seizure by the Australian Federal Police and Customs in Melbourne of a record 13 kilograms of high grade heroin. I ask the Minister whether police believe the group arrested are part of the Japanese mafia, the Yakuza, and whether the profits from the drug haul were to be used to push the Yakuza into organised crime in Australia? Further, what steps are the Federal authorities taking to stop the spread of the Yakuza in Australia?

—I thank Senator Jones for his question. I certainly commend the Federal Police and the Customs officers for their successful drug interception—13 kilograms of high grade heroin being seized in Melbourne. I am advised by the AFP that, quite clearly, there is a very obvious international connection and that is being pursued, though, for operational reasons, it would be wrong to speculate on the outcome of such investigations. In particular, I think it would be unwise and unfair to the individuals who have been charged—
—You have to be careful about what you say.

—I do not need to be advised by the honourable senator. I am saying, on behalf of the individuals being charged, that it is very important that they not be tainted by any association with any organised criminal group. Therefore, it is very important that we do not prejudice them in any way.

PARA.TAB: In a general sense, I am pleased that there have been growing areas of cooperation between the Australian Federal Police and overseas law enforcement agencies, including the national police agency in Japan. This has led to an exchange of officers at the very highest level. Formal and informal agreements have been reached for the exchange of information and intelligence in accordance with the laws of both countries.

It is pleasing to see that earlier this year the Japanese Parliament caught up with this Parliament in dealing with money laundering and profits of crime legislation which will enable it, jointly with Australia and other nations, to deal with the phenomenon of those involved in organised crime ignoring national boundaries and engaging in the hiding and disguising of the profits of crime in a way which allows them to launder money in legitimate business activities and, thus, end up controlling segments of lawful business and commercial activity, quite apart from the black market, particularly drug trafficking.

I believe it is very important that we continue to expand these international links with Australian law enforcement agencies. That will be done by this Government. In this particular case no assumption should be made as to the individuals who have been charged.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to an article in the West Australian newspaper on Saturday which claims that Gregory Symons, a relative of Senator Richardson, had dealings with the Treasury in Canberra concerning the takeover of BHP in 1987. In a letter to Senator Richardson, Mr Symons is reported to have said:

QUESTION.PARA: You recall our conversation concerning the problem of BHP ownership and possible overseas control. I enclose a submission from our group which may be useful.
It is also reported that Mr Symons wrote to Mr Laurie Connell of Rothwells stating:
I am awaiting `in principle' response from Treasury in Canberra.

I ask the Minister to inform the Senate of Senator Richardson's involvement in this affair. Did his involvement have the sanction of the then Treasurer or Prime Minister? What in principle response from Treasury was Mr Symons awaiting?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never heard of any of that. I will try to obtain an answer and let Senator Hill have it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 15 June which states that many women are worried that workplace bargaining will undermine the gains that have been made in the workplace? Can the Minister explain how the Government's reforms to the Industrial Relations Act, recently passed through the Senate, address the concerns that women workers have about workplace or enterprise bargaining?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the Sydney Morning Herald article. It appeared on 15 June, as Senator Giles has said, and was written by Julie Lewis under the heading `Why women fear a hard bargain is being driven'. The problem here is one of brand differentiation. When the Government says workplace bargaining, we mean a different set of propositions from what the Opposition means when it says enterprise agreements. In the public mind there is a tendency to blur those differences. I would like to differentiate between our brands so that women workers and women entrants into the work force can understand why their rights are protected and their move to pay equity is supported by this Government.

PARA.TAB: Typically, women workers are streamed or locked into low paid jobs, or what is called women's work. Of course, this is changing under this Government. Nonetheless, there is a fear of what happened when the Fraser Government came to office, when the gains that had been made for women workers under the Whitlam Government slipped back again. We intend to continue to make some changes to provide better efficiencies in the workplace. We are concerned that things be not only best but also fairest.

Our changes to workplace bargaining ensure that women workers are protected because there is a fundamental condition that the value of pay and working conditions in workplace agreements cannot be contracted below the amount in an Industrial Relations Commission award. Thus, the minimum standards set by the Commission are an effective floor to the process of workplace agreements, and they ensure no exploitation of women workers.

We have also made a substantial commitment to skills training in Australia. For the first time many women workers have access to training and for advancement through higher levels of skill. Therefore, their pay inequities can be addressed. We will also continue with the national wage case. The national wage case makes economic adjustments for all workers in Australia annually. The position of the Opposition is to abolish the national wage case, to put general economic movements beyond the reach of ordinary Australians. We will continue with it because it is a way of protecting the interests of women workers.

In the same way, in our workplace agreements there will be a dispute settling provision which will require that those agreements are voted on by all workers in the workplace, meaning that on many occasions, for the first time, women workers will get a vote on their conditions of employment.

There are good examples of where this is already working. I gave details of the National Australia Bank's employment flexibility provisions the other day. The ANZ Bank has followed in its footsteps. The question of workplace bargaining is one in which we look to achieve economic efficiency—that is, best outcomes—but we want it to be fair as well. We do not want just best—we want the best and fairest industrial relations system. That is the one the Senate approved of just last week, as I am sure the House of Representatives will later this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

DEBATE.TITLE: YOUTH SUMMITSCHOOL RETENTION RATEWATERFRONT PRODUCTIVITYSHIPPINGINDUSTRIAL RELATIONS: HAMERSLEY IRON

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to questions without notice asked by Senators Colston, Crichton-Browne, Knowles, Parer and Vanstone this day, relating to education, employment and industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: I have sought leave to refer to those answers because they were in response to critical questions that were asked by honourable senators not only from this side but also from the other side in respect of both employment and productivity. In Australia today unemployment is running at some one million people. Of great concern to people on this side is the high level of unemployment among our youth. No matter what questions have been asked, the Government has deliberately evaded answering them.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook, in response to questions from Senator Knowles, took great umbrage at the fact that he was referred to as the `Minister for unemployment'. I cannot think of a more appropriate name to be given not only to this Minister but also to members of this Government, because they are the ones that created the unemployment. They have not come up with any answers. The Liberal and National parties have come up with a program that relates simply to looking at unemployment in Australia.

Senator Colston compared the position on the wharves and in shipping in Australia with that of New Zealand. That came about because of a question I asked Senator Cook last week, not about the number of containers handled on our wharves, because there certainly has been an improvement in Australia, but about the actual cost of moving those containers from the wharf to the ship.

The question I asked Senator Cook last week—and he had no idea of the answer, although he is supposed to be the Minister responsible—was about a reduction in cost of a mere $4 per container in Australia, from $282 to $278, whereas our New Zealand counterparts are benefiting from a reduction of $132, from $298 to $166. In response today, Senator Cook said that a report of the monitoring of trans-Tasman shipping prepared by the Australian Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics and the New Zealand Ministry of Transport was outdated and did not reflect the benefits that have flown from improvements on the waterfront, yet that report was released by Senator Collins on 21 May this year.

The other question I asked Senator Cook last week was how much idle labour is still being paid for on the Australian waterfront. To date we have not had a response, but I understand that it is in the order of $400 to $500. If that is the case, it is an absolute disgrace, because we have had this enormous amount of money paid out not just by the stevedoring companies but by the Australian taxpayers. The amount of money which has been set aside is in the order of $300m. In any other industry, that would not be paid.

The other thing that I think is worth drawing attention to is that time in and time out we have had the Minister for Industrial Relations come in here and say how great industrial relations are in Australia and what a marvellous improvement we have had. As honourable senators might recall, he went to Japan. My heart went out to the Minister for Industrial Relations when he went to Japan to explain to the Japanese how good things were, because I have been through that particular exercise myself. I say this quite sincerely because it gives me no joy to talk about the rotten reputation we have overseas in respect of industrial relations.

A recent official Government document talked about the good job that Senator Cook had done in Japan and how he had convinced the Japanese that things had changed in Australia—how good they were. What do we have now? We have one of the major suppliers of commodities to Japan—Hamersley Iron—on strike. Two thousand people are on the grass because one particular person was found not to be a member of a union. Do honourable senators know how it was found that he was not a member of a union? There was a show day when all employees had to show their ticket, and one guy did not have a ticket. This is a hang-up from the old Broken Hill days when people had to come along on a certain day and show their union ticket, and no ticket meant no work.

Can honourable senators imagine explaining to the tigers of the east—whether it be Japan, Korea, Taiwan or, more recently, Thailand—that one of Australia's major commodity suppliers is out of work because a person elects not to be a member of a union? Yet we get the Minister coming in here and we have had this Government coming in here time and again saying that there is no such thing as compulsory unionism in Australia, but that we do have closed shops—not compulsory, mind you! We had Senator McKiernan saying that the strike was not the union's fault at all.

Everyone knows that what the union has done is against the law in Western Australia. As the Minister said, he does not like the law. That is fine, but what damage is being done? I say this from the point of view of employment and productivity. If we are to get out of this incredible mess that we have got into, we must export more. In the process of exporting more, we must employ more people. We must also get into more import replacement. These are the real jobs. They can be created only by the private sector. There is no other way. The way to do it is to get our productivity up, to reduce the unit costs of production. It is not a matter of wages, as I have said in this place time and again. Our wages are about half those in places such as Japan, but our productivity is lousy; it is more than half the Japanese productivity. Unless that is addressed, we will not get the investment we need in the export producing commodity areas or any other export area or in import replacement.

The acid test is what people with some money would like to invest in in this country. We do not have to go to the ABS statistics to find out what is happening; we have only to get out of the ACT and talk to people in other places such as Townsville—Senator Reynolds is from there—Brisbane, Perth or Hobart and ask them what they are investing in. They are not investing in primary production, minerals, manufacturing or tourism. Those moneys are not being invested there. While they are not going there, we will not improve the wealth of this country; we will not increase exports or import replacements; and, more importantly—this is the thing that really matters—we will not improve the dreadful unemployment rate, particularly among the young people in Australia.

Recently the Minister came in here with a piece of legislation that was a direct result of the so-called Troubleshooters case. The Minister and the ACTU were coy. The ACTU and the committee investigating the matter had a wonderfully convenient loss of memory. When I asked them whether this was initiated by them as a result of the Troubleshooters case and whether it was after the Troubleshooters case that they spoke to the Minister and said, `We would like legislation', we had two gentlemen from the ACTU look at one another and say, `Look, we don't really remember this. We're not too sure'. `Do you remember talking to the Minister about this'? `No, I don't remember talking to the Minister about that'.

What a convenient loss of memory. Of course that is where it came from. The sad part about it is that we have very few industries in Australia that are productive. One of them is the home building industry. The Minister is shaking his head. He does not agree that the home building industry is productive.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I disagree that there are very few productive industries. There are lots of productive industries.

—There are very few industries that, on a world scale, we would consider to be efficient or productive. If there were, we would not have the balance of payments problems or the unemployment problems we have in Australia today. Everywhere I go I hear, `We have the most efficient X industry, Y industry, Z industry in the world'. We all hear it. I know that it is a good idea to lift people's morale and spirits; I really support that to the hilt. But I question whether it is really true that Australian industries are productive. Some industries appear to be productive because we happen to be blessed, say, with good resources or with a climate that is suitable and so on. But when you take it back to the productivity, the output, the unit cost of production, we are not really that productive. We have a long way to go.

PARA.TAB: We have two very efficient industries. One is the home building industry and the other is the transport industry, where owner-drivers operate their own vehicles. This legislation, brought in by the Minister at the behest of the ACTU, was geared to make it easy for the unions to take the money and incorporate these people within their particular union, whether it be the BWIU or the Transport Workers Union.I do not believe that the Minister is that naive. Maybe he is. One clause in the legislation says that the unions may—or words to this effect—change their rules so that they can take contractors as members.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do now.

—We know they do now, where they can. They use a browbeating method to do it. Everyone is aware that attempts are made by the Transport Workers Union to incarcerate owner-drivers within the Transport Workers Union system. Often, at any time in a production line—if you want to call it that—or a chain, there is a closed shop at one end or the other. A person who owns a vehicle turns up and the heavies say, `Unless you are a member of this union tomorrow do not come to pick up the newspapers', or whatever it might be. In the past those people have been able to argue strongly, `No matter how much we would like to'—they do not really want to, but it has been a wonderful way out—`we cannot because we are contractors; we cannot be owner-operators and members of a union at the same time'. This gives them the out to do so.

PARA.TAB: In my own home State we have temporary construction sites. One recent site was the Indi. In a couple of weeks—and this is typical of union approaches—there is a knock on the door by a bunch of heavies who say, `We have declared this a construction site'. The small subbies on site say, `What does that mean?' The answer that comes back is, `It means you have to join the BLF'. The BLF still exists in Queensland because it was considered by the government of the day, strangely enough, as being a good union. I suppose that might have been relative to the BWIU; I have no idea.

What they want, what they demand and what they get is that the subcontractor has to pay money to the union coffers. Once he pays that money, the union goes away quite happily. It has got the money. That is what this is all about. It is about making it easier for those sorts of people. I do not put them into some sort of ideological bloc somewhere.

I would not in any way like to cast aspersions on the Minister because, in the main, he probably does not engage in these practices or he probably did not. I do not know about that. All I know is that he would be aware that these practices go on and it is phoney to pretend they do not. The Minister has become the laughing stock of Australia. He is the laughing stock of every brickie, carpenter, electrician, plumber and plasterer in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And chefs.

—And the chefs; we will give them a run, too. They know what these practices attempt to do. If they were to have a good effect, we would support them, but they will have the effect of forcing those people to be unproductive. They will force those people to get less money than they now get, to work fewer hours and to join organisations against their will. That is the important thing.

PARA.TAB: Apart from the contractors finding themselves in a difficult position, the net effect on the consumer, whether that consumer be the person at the other end of the truck or the person paying the bill to build the house, will be increased costs. These costs vary from place to place and they have been estimated to be as high as 15 per cent to 25 per cent, which would add about $20,000 to the cost of a normal house.

I know that a lot of my colleagues wish to speak on this matter, but it is important to put it all into perspective. We have to direct our attention to a better, more efficient and productive country. For instance, I notice that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—and this was referred to in Question Time—has called a conference and that that conference will be held in private. A fascinating aspect of that conference is that, according to a press release by the Prime Minister, its purpose is to invite participants to a national meeting on youth training and employment. Guess who one of the participants is? It is Mr George Campbell of the AMWU. People may say, `What does it matter whether it is George Campbell?'. Is he not the same person who three years ago the Prime Minister of this country, Mr Paul Keating, referred to as the person who had the blood of 100,000 unemployed people on his hands? But George Campbell will be a participant in a conference called to discuss youth training and employment.

Of course, we will have the usual gaggle of ACTU participants amongst all the others—the Bill Keltys, the Bill Mansfields and so on. The rest of Australia does not understand this perpetual hang-up between the Labor Party and its industrial arm, the trade union movement. Looking back over the last 10 or 20 years, the group—one can have a whole lot of people in the group such as the Christopher Skases, the Allan Bonds or whatever; the failed entrepreneurs—which can take the greatest share of responsibility for destroying the productivity of this country, for bringing it economically to its knees and creating the unemployment we have, is the short-sighted trade union movement.

I am not talking about a number of trade unions which do not fit that category, but there are a lot who do. I am talking about those unions that go down the track of short-sightedness by doing things which on their face appear in the short term to be beneficial to the members of a particular union but which then force the more moderate unions to follow suit and show their own members that they can be as gung-ho and as militant as their comrades up the corridor. The effect is that jobs are lost. That is not just my opinion. It is also one held by most people who have thought this through. Whenever wage increases are at a greater level than productivity, it is inevitable that we have associated with it reduced productivity and increased unemployment.

Under the Fightback package we are offering a number of things. We are offering to get rid of all those input costs, and I will not go into that now because it is not related to the matter in hand. That is very important if we are to make this a more productive country, if we are to make our industries more competitive, if we are to increase our exports and get into more import replacement.

The other thing is that we must have a deregulated labour market. That is the sticking point between ourselves and the Government. It is the basic difference between us, as was pointed out by Senator Cook during Question Time. It is our belief—this is a belief which has been shown to be correct in just about every other successful country in the world—that if we are to get out of the mess we are in we have to get rid of those restrictive work practices that were imposed in better times by militant trade unions. Senator Cook will recall, and I am sure he will admit, that at any time that is discussed it is said that many of those restrictive work practices will have to go. Some have gone already, but not without cost.

When this is raised by various people with trade union leaders they inevitably come back with that old nineteenth century answer, `We are not about to give up hard won gains'. It is the standard response. Yet those hard won gains have cost hundreds of thousands of people, in fact almost a million people, their jobs. Commonsense needs to be used. At the time those gains were achieved, the unions may have thought they did a good job. When there was over-full employment, one could probably argue that they did but, when those gains were obtained at a rate where there was no equivalent productivity increase, it was inevitable that we would face the situation we are in today where a million people are out of work. With this Government in power, there is no light at the end of the tunnel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer has moved to take note of various answers I gave to questions from the Opposition and from my side of the chamber during Question Time. That is a device under the Standing Orders which enables him to speak to the answers that I gave. Apparently this afforded Senator Parer the opportunity to practise his oratory and debating skills and to perambulate a few prejudices around the chamber about industrial relations. If it served any practical purpose, it may have helped Senator Parer. If it has, I am grateful, and I do not resent taking up the time of the Senate on these frivolities because of that.

PARA.TAB: Much of what Senator Parer has said is dross, but amongst the dross are one or two gems. One of the gems he uttered, and with which I concur absolutely, is that as a government we are about making Australia a world competitive economy. Our vision for this economy is for us to be a world competitive, global economy producing high value added manufactures, moving away from being a supplier of agricultural commodities and mineral resources to the world, the rawest form of export, and importing sophisticated manufactured goods. We want to move this economy to an economy that does not simply export coal and iron ore, wheat and wool, but that exports those sophisticated manufactured goods. In order to do that, structural change in this economy is necessary, and we have embarked on it.

Although there is a world recession and a collapse in prices for our agricultural goods, which have had severe effects on the Australian economy, nonetheless an economic recovery is gathering in the Australian economy. Anyone who is prepared to be fair and reasonable and who can look with a dispassionate eye at the statistics produced by the ABS will see that the signs of that recovery are manifest. They are shown in an increase in housing starts and approvals for loans for housing construction; they are shown in an increase in the number of motor vehicle registrations, indicating that consumers are buying cars and other whitegoods for housing; they are shown in an increase in the number of advertised vacancies according to various indices.

It is a recovery that is beginning; it is a recovery that most Australians welcome; it is a recovery that is the answer to the problems of unemployment in this country. But it is a recovery that has this adverse political effect for the Opposition: the stronger it becomes and the more effective it is, the less chance the Opposition will have to win an election. The Opposition knows that. As a consequence, we find this effort to damage the confidence so necessary to fuel that recovery, to downplay the significance of the statistics and to talk about doom and gloom instead of concentrating on the positive measures that are occurring. That macro strategy has been the strategy of the Opposition over recent weeks. Today's foray is a subplot of that macro strategy; that is, to single out the area of industrial relations for particular criticism and to concentrate on that.

Let me deal with some of the criticisms that have been made and reply positively on behalf of the Government, giving the truth about industrial relations. If one compares our performance to the performance of the Fraser Government, one can see that the period of the Fraser Government was epitomised by a high level of industrial disputation, by a wages explosion in the economy that disoriented the axis of the economy and by high unemployment. The Fraser Government achieved the trifecta: double digit unemployment, double digit inflation and negative economic growth all at the same time. There was also a high level of disputation.

The features of the economy at the present time include very low industrial disputation, 60 per cent below that of the average of the Fraser years and, in the most recent returns of the Statistician, off the bottom of the graph—in fact lower than what the Statistician has collected since he or she commenced collecting those statistics. On the inflation front we are looking at a year average of 1.7 per cent. We had double digit inflation under the Fraser Government in its recession; we have very low levels of inflation in ours. We are coming out of the recession into economic growth. We have a very high level of unemployment which is the last factor which will come right. Through the initiative of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), we are now moving into a job summit for the young unemployed to deal with an area of concern in unemployment.

Dare I say—it will probably be unpopular if I say it and I may be criticised for saying it—that, in terms of a fair analysis of what the unemployment problem is, the highest area of priority is not youth unemployment. I know that is contrary to what is often said. But the highest area of need among the unemployed is among those who are middle aged, face redundancy and do not have marketable skills which fit them to take a place in the economy when it lifts. That is the group in highest need; that is the group that is most neglected in popular political debate. I say that because I think it is essential, if we are to debate these matters, to talk about the situation and not simply exploit the statistics for political reasons.

When one compares programs, the Government has a series of opportunities for training, for training in place of the dole, for work experience and for job placement. As I said during Question Time, we have invested $720m this year into technical and further education and we have increased expenditure on higher education by 42 per cent in real terms over the term of our period in government, creating the equivalent of 17 new universities. So we are trying to address those problems of training and skill necessary to achieve our vision of a world competitive economy.

The Opposition—which presided over a high level of industrial disputation, divisions in Australia according to whether one was a worker or an employer, the politics of hate and resentment and the politics of envy—now lectures us that all the problems of the economy are due to unions or the work force that they represent and that ordinary Australians have been too greedy because wages have been too high. That is a fallacy of the first order; wages have been restrained over the nine years of our Government. It is a pretty pathetic effort to try to blame ordinary wage earners by saying that their wages are the cause of the present recession.

It has to be said—and let me say it now as strongly as I can—that the ordinary wage earners, the ordinary, average Australians, have conducted themselves in a way of restraint that has been a model for any other economy in the world. That is a compliment which they ought to be paid and for which they ought to be recognised. They do not deserve to be criticised as though they are greedy. It is not they who were greedy: Christopher Skase was greedy; Alan Bond was greedy; all the heroes of unrestrained capitalism, to use the proper technical definition, were greedy. But it was not the ordinary people of Australia who were greedy, and criticisms of ordinary people in this context are totally unfair.

Coming to the particular points that have been raised in this address by Senator Parer—which no doubt will be parroted by the familiar litany of faces on the Opposition benches, who simply cannot look at the Australian work force and recognise that some Australians want to be in trade unions and have them represent their point of view—

TALK.START.PARA: —And some don't.

—That is right; some do not. But equally some do. Apparently, if some do, they commit some sort of felony; they become disgraceful human beings. They are the butt of allegations which cite them as being responsible for the problems of the economy.

PARA.TAB: I come right back to the only gem or nugget I could detect in the dross that was uttered by Senator Parer: that what we want is an internationally competitive country. That is what we want. As a fundamental question of good human management, I ask: do we get people to work together, to cooperate to achieve that goal, by confrontation, by demand and by insistence that they do things—which is the fundamental principle of the Opposition's industrial relations policy—or by cooperation, working together and the development of a team ethic?

The period of the Fraser Government was marked by division and confrontation. The so-called Fightback package, more accurately described as a consumption tax package, sets as its central goal `labour market reform', but no-one has explained and nor has John Howard said what those words mean. There is no detail to define the meaning. What we do know is where inspiration is drawn from by the Opposition for so-called labour market reform. It is drawn from across the Tasman in New Zealand. It is drawn from the APPM dispute. It is drawn from examples of confrontation and conflict. Those opposite must understand that they will get a better Australia when they work with Australians, not against them. Our industrial relations policy is one that concentrates on working with the progressive forces in the Australian community to achieve change.

I now turn to the waterfront, which is part of what Senator Parer addressed us on. Senator Parer, in a question to me last week, took statistics that had been compiled up until May of this year and tabled by the Minister on 21 May, which painted a picture of past circumstances and what they showed. He then used the picture of the past to condemn the present and to argue that reform on the Australian waterfront was not at the same level as that in New Zealand.

I know the Opposition is fascinated by New Zealand and wants to go down the New Zealand road. A weird side light of all of this is that, as Australians, we find we have a cultural cringe to New Zealand. Nonetheless, the fact is that Senator Parer's figures are wrong. What he did not do in the little exercise he engaged in was take account of the changes that occur through the implementation phase and which the statistics, which reflected the past, do not reflect. He did not do that.

On the most recent figures available, on a comparison of like with like, we find that there is significant improvement on the Australian waterfront; that, unlike what the Inter-State Commission thought, the redundancy figure is much higher, the work force has been halved in real terms, and we are as efficient in turning around containers right across all of our major ports as the New Zealanders are in Auckland; and that what we have here is significant reform.

If we want to be fair, we do not go on and then say, `Where are the blockages in the system?'. The blockage in the system at present, which is being investigated by the Industry Commission, is with the port authorities which are under State control and which are not passing on to the users the savings achieved by the rationalisation of labour on the wharf and the higher efficiency output of the container terminals. We have an Interstate Commission evaluation of that. When those findings are released, that will put me in a position of being able to deal with that problem and ensure that the users of the waterfront are able to achieve the full measure of the changes that the workers on the waterfront have brought about by agreeing to halve their work force and increase the efficiency with which they operate.

I think it is a pity that credit is not paid where it is due and that recognition is not given where efforts are made. Here is a case where real efforts have been made, and what happens to the people who have strenuously tried to achieve them? They are criticised as being defective.

I turn to the next matter which Senator Parer raised, the Hamersley Iron issue. I made it quite clear in Question Time that I do not support the Hamersley Iron strike and that I enjoin those people on strike to return to work in conformity with the direction of Commissioner Fielding of the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission. I also said that that is the law and the law should be obeyed. And so it should. But I do not happen to believe that in this case the law is just. That is not a reason for not obeying it; it should still be obeyed.

The law we have in this case is the law of the Western Australian Liberal Government in 1982, unable to be changed by the Western Australian Labor Government since 1983 because of a gerrymander in the Legislative Council in Western Australia, which means that the Government is in government but not in power in that State. Therefore, we have this survival of old Liberal legislation. The dispute in Western Australia is not a dispute under the law that we would like it to be; it is a dispute under the law that those opposite want it to be. Therefore, it reflects their notion of industrial relations. That does not diminish the obligation of people to obey it, but it does mean that those who want to change it through constitutional means should be encouraged to do that as quickly as possible, because it is a damaging dispute.

It is true that I went to Japan and talked to the Japanese about changes in Australian industrial relations. I was joined on that mission by the Chief Executive Officer of the Confederation of Australian Industry, Mr Brian Noakes, and the President of the ACTU, Mr Martin Ferguson. Here we had, speaking to the Japanese, me on behalf of the Australian Government, the chief spokesperson on behalf of Australian industry and the chief spokesperson on behalf of Australian unions.

The Japanese were pleased to see, in the first instance, that we all came together, we were united, we had a common view and we expressed it, backed up by fact and statistic. The Japanese were also pleased to identify, despite blips and disputes that do occur, that at the core there had been a considerable change in Australian industrial relations performance. It behoves every Australian to recognise that and tell it to our trading partners to help win markets for Australia. Pretending that it is the old Fraser era level of industrial disputation helps lose markets for Australian industry; showing what the changes are under us helps win them. As a matter of national patriotism, one ought to at least tell the truth to our major trading partners. That is what the Confederation of Australian Industry did, that is what the ACTU did and that is what I did on behalf of the Australian Government.

To their credit, many Japanese businessmen said, `Yes, that is true, there is a significant change'. I recall an occasion on which an old and venerated Japanese business person was referring to the disputes of the 1960s and 1970s—the disputes of the Fraser era. As he had not been back to Australia for some time, he thought that that situation still pertained. In a meeting of one of the business associations in Japan he was contradicted by younger executives working in industries with investments in Australia who said, `No, in fact, there has been a cultural shift'. If, because of these changes, we can win more markets for our products, that is a very good thing. Therefore, I say to Senator Parer: please do not decry the facts; please explain them properly.

I now turn to the issue Senator Parer raised of independent contractors. He has neglected to recognise that last week we enacted industrial relations law here which is quite revolutionary in that it introduces an era of workplace bargaining. It is a significant decentralisation of the system, but one with protections. We do not want to decentralise,

SPEECH.PARA: throw everyone into the law of the jungle and let the devil take the hindmost. People in employment are entitled to dignity and to get a fair day's pay for a fair day's work. The system we have introduced enables that to occur. Nonetheless, it is revolutionary and will bring forth a massive change in productivity in this country.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer talked about independent contractors. I will repeat some of the facts. For once in the lives of those opposite they might read the legislation and talk about what it contains, not about what they think it contains or what their prejudices or bigotries encourage them to believe it contains. This legislation reflects at a national level the industrial legislation that Premier Nick Greiner introduced into the New South Wales legislature last year. We are simply reflecting nationally New South Wales industrial law on the subject of independent contractors. The Opposition protests against us for doing this, but it is silent when it comes to the New South Wales Government, simply because it is playing politics. It is not looking at the issues; it is trying to exploit the arguments.

I repeat that we have enabled independent contractors who are victims of harsh and unreasonable contracts to have a speedy and accessible way of getting redress. Our crime is to put speedy and easy redress within the reach of independent contractors who in certain circumstances are victimised. This is taken to mean that independent contractors will be forced into trade unions. There is no such basis for that assertion, and that is well known. One merely has to read the legislation to know that that is the case. This is taken as meaning that awards can now be applied to independent contractors to set aside their contracts or that class actions can be taken. That is explicitly forbidden in the legislation, it is not true, yet the allegation keeps being made.

It is also argued that this legislation is some way of introducing rorts onto building sites. I have had a bit of experience in the building industry in my time, as has Senator Parer. It is fair to say that rorts have been on building sites ever since Adam was in short pants. No-one likes it—I deplore it—but it is a fact of life in that industry. However, this legislation will not change that circumstance other than to allow people with contracts that are being rorted in terms which are harsh and unfair to have speedy and easy redress. It will decrease the area of rort, provide a particular area of access to justice and provide for fair judgment in those circumstances.

The rest of the reform of the building industry is a much more massive task. We undertook it by announcing last year a building industry reform strategy, which is now beginning to work. The Opposition knocked the move because it perceived success for us as electoral failure for it, and it therefore had a vested interest in playing down the terms of the success.

In conclusion, the issues on which I am arraigned and accused are that somehow the union movement in this country is out of control, has induced the recession and is prolonging it. There is no evidence of that, and no independent economic commentator holds that view. It is a prejudice, a bigotry and one that is propounded by the Opposition because it prefers to play the man and not the ball.

The truth is that in 1983 the accord enabled rapid employment growth to occur, wage outcomes to be moderate, living standards to rise by virtue of improvements in taxation and the social wage, and an outcome in which there was a shift in factor terms from wages to profits in this country. That structurally remains in place and is an achievement of the accord. Living standards have to remain high so that Australians can afford to consume the products that they make and produce—buy back their own goods. That has meant that we have reduced taxation and bought out wage increases by cutting taxes so that employers do not have to pay the higher wages but that workers do not suffer through the ravages of inflation. That is what the accord does, and that is a responsible economic outcome.

I am enjoined in this debate to be censured in some form because of Senator Parer's perception of the lack of waterfront reform in Australia. I have answered that charge. If the statistics were right and the comparisons were fair, the reform achieved in this country on the waterfront is consistent with that in New Zealand. That is the benchmark as far as the Opposition is concerned. Moreover, and more importantly because I have no cultural cringe to New Zealand, it is consistent with productivity outputs in major ports in the world.

I am now thirdly attacked on the basis that the performance of the union movement in this country contributes to unemployment. The union movement in this country has committed itself to achieving a wages outcome based on the inflation levels of this country, which is a moderate outcome. The year average inflation level is 1.7 per cent. That is a moderate outcome. That is possible because of an accord. In Senator Parer's version of the law of the jungle—the devil take the hindmost—there would be a wages blow-out as there was in the last year of the Fraser Government.

Finally, I am lambasted in this place over the contractors legislation and I conclude again by shaking my head more in sorrow than in anger. If Senator Parer would only talk about what the legislation contains and not misrepresent it, he would understand that this is a social justice measure which protects independent contractors. It does not realise the dangers or fears that he talks about. Let me make this clear: the rhetoric he used and the rhetoric used by the HIA is not supported by the other major building organisation, the Master Builders Association. Yesterday I read a letter here from the Master Builders Association saying that the things the HIA were saying were not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —They also said that they were opposed to it.

—It said it was opposed to it; but here is an organisation with integrity. This organisation tells me it does not agree with what I am doing, but it says it certainly is not the end of the world and it does not go as far as the hysterical carry-on of the HIA. It will not, the Association says, increase the price of housing. It says that quite clearly. It will not, it says—and it says this quite clearly—lead to unionisation of the independent contractors area and it will not—and it says this quite clearly—interfere with the commercial relationship between contractors. It says all of those things. This is not me or the Keating Government speaking; this is the Master Builders Association of Australia saying these things.

PARA.TAB: On that basis, Madam Acting Deputy President, I rest my case and hope finally that those opposite will realise that they cannot make change in Australia by confronting people and institutions. They ought to learn to work with them cooperatively to succeed in making those changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook really put his finger on this issue when he answered my question by saying that he believed the law ought to be changed. The present law provides for it to be an offence to dismiss a worker who is not a member of a union. That is exactly the situation in Western Australia. Under section 96 of the Western Australian arbitration Act it is an offence for an employer to dismiss a worker who refuses to join a union.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook's answer really goes to the heart of the problem. Senator Cook wants to change the law so that anybody who is not a member of a union does not get a job; anybody who resigns from a union must resign from his job. In other words, a person needs a licence to work in this country and that licence means paying $160 a year to a union. Without that licence a person is unable to work; that is the law Senator Cook wants in this country. This debate is all about the intrinsic, basic right of individuals to work without having to join a union.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or if they want to join one.

—Yes—or to join one if they want to; the freedom to make a choice either in a positive or a negative sense. It is about the right of workers to individually or collectively negotiate a contract with employers for their labour; to enter into an agreement, a relationship or a financial circumstance with an employer of their own making, not in a corporate sense. This is not about workers' wages and conditions. It is not about bludging or freeloading and getting the benefit of hard-earned rights achieved by unions. This is all about denying the right of individuals to contract their labour.

PARA.TAB: This is all about unions maintaining their control. The unions, of course, no longer represent the workers; they no longer represent individuals. They now, of course, only represent officials. They have lost their raison d'etre. Unions no longer have a purpose other than to represent the corporate view. Unions are not terrified about individuals being able to negotiate, they are not terrified about a collective arrangement between a group of employees and employers—the unions' fear is that such agreements can be entered into and can work effectively and successfully for the benefit of all without the need for unions. The reason we have the Troubleshooters legislation is that the unions were terrified that they were losing more and more power.

That is what this industrial unrest in the Pilbara is all about. That is why there are 11 ships swinging on their picks. Two ships have been redirected, two shipping contracts have been cancelled and one ship is still tied up at the wharf. Hamersley Iron has lost a total of $4m thus far; $5m worth of sales have been lost; and 2,000 men are out on the grass losing $100,000 a day in wages because one man dared say, `I don't want to join a union'. I have outlined the price he has to pay, the price the company has to pay and the price society has to pay. That poor man, his wife and two children have now been driven out of Tom Price and have gone on holidays to Perth. They fear to live in the town because the man made a choice as to whether or not he would join a union.

The real distinction between the Labor Party and the Liberal Party is that we believe in people's rights to make choices; we trust people's capacity and their confidence; and we have faith in people's ability to enter into relationships with their employers. The Labor Party fears that they will do that and that they will do that successfully, and their trade union masters will be the losers.

As Senator Cook concluded his remarks he said that the reason there is the present industrial legislation in Western Australia, the industrial relations arbitration legislation of 1982, is that there was a gerrymandered upper House. I remind Senator Cook of the reasons that one Arthur Tonkin resigned from the Ministry, resigned from the Parliament and resigned from the seat of Morley. It followed a Cabinet meeting in Geraldton where he produced his blueprint for one vote one value. He put it on the table and Brian Burke said, `Make sure the legislation is so tough that the Liberals will have to reject it'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense. It was supported by the Cabinet.

—It was not. Unless the ex-member for Morley and an ex-Minister of the Burke Government tells pork pies, that is just not true. He himself wrote to Brian Burke, the then Premier, and said, `I am resigning because I cannot stand the dishonesty of this Government in terms of electoral reform, and now we have got a chance for electoral reform you are going to ensure that it does not succeed because the present boundaries satisfy a Labor socialist government'. That nonsense about a gerrymander in Western Australia is just not true.

—In opening this debate, Senator Parer was right about one thing: there is a fundamental difference between the Opposition and the Government on the question of industrial relations. While those opposite talk in bland terms about enterprise bargaining—a concept, I might add, with which we fundamentally agree; we do not have any basic arguments about the concept—they mean something quite different. To them it means a system in which managers manage; a system where workers take orders; a system in which management prerogative, as they know it, is returned, where managers have the right to hire and fire and set conditions of work in an unfettered way; and a system in which workers are seen simply as industrial fodder, without any ability or skill, without any need to be consulted; a system in which they are thought of as not having any intrinsic value.

PARA.TAB: This is why those opposite were such strong supporters of the APPM management in Tasmania, with its divide and rule philosophy. This is why they have supported Cliffs Robe River as strongly as they have, with its divide and rule philosophy—the dog-eat-dog approach to industrial relations, where the devil takes the hindmost. Sure, strong individuals, strong groups of people, strong unions and strong enterprises will do well in those areas where productivity is high, but those in weaker areas will not do well—the devil take the hindmost.

Our position is quite different. We believe in a system which upholds the dignity of the individual worker, which believes that he or she has something worthwhile to offer and which believes that the worker is worth consulting. We believe in a system which, while it has a measure of equality, does recognise differences in skills and capacities, and differences between enterprises. This is what award restructuring has been all about. It is a system in which productivity is maximised by consultation and teamwork, not by confrontation, aggression and division. It is a system which works well in continental Europe and Japan. It is a system which is in stark contrast with the conflict models, which the Opposition seems to want to follow, in the USA—particularly in the southern states of the USA—and the United Kingdom.

Blind criticism of the union movement, which the Opposition is so fond of, is out of step with world opinion. Senator Cook has already drawn attention to the fact that wage restraint in this country has been noticed worldwide. It got special mention in the recent OECD report. It regarded as remarkable the level of wage restraint which had been achieved by the consensus model.

The union movement has shown more leadership than many employers—certainly more than the Opposition. If one casts one's mind back to 1983, to the first economic summit, the unions left the employers for dead and certainly left the Opposition for dead with their awareness of the sorts of problems that faced this country and the sorts of things that needed to be done about them. In a recent visit to this country, the Secretary-General of the OECD, Mr Jean-Claude Paye, noted—these were his words and he spoke them quite publicly in a number of forums—that the union movement in Australia was a visionary union movement, the like of which he had not seen anywhere in the world. He was talking in particular about its capacity to face problems, outline those problems and try to manage change in order to overcome some of them.

To be fair, he also praised employers for the changes that he had seen between the last time he was here in 1985 and this year when he visited us again. He said that employers had a much more outward-looking posture than they had had before. They were less cringing and inward-looking and showed a much greater capacity for export orientation and an aggressive stance in the world economy.

Many things are still to be done. I am not pretending that the problems which face us are not difficult or that they have all been overcome, but we will get much further if we put behind us the blind prejudices about unions which are so often paraded before us by the Opposition. If we work together to try to improve things in the national interest—as many other countries and, notably, successful countries do—we will get a lot further. In the European countries and Japan, oppositions get together with governments to work in the national interest—they do not point score based on blind prejudices about unions. We would get a lot further if we worked together and attempted to be more objective in our analysis.

For example, all the talk about productivity seems to be predicated on the idea that productivity is always about labour; that productivity is output per unit of labour input. Productivity is also about output per unit of capital input or unit of land input. There are lots of measurements of productivity but there is only one that seems to mean anything to the Opposition. I think we would get much more by consensus than we would by the confrontation which is being offered by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to make a few comments about the contents of Senator Cook's answer to me today. The question that I clearly asked him was whether Mr Beazley, as Minister for Employment, Education and Training, had actually said that it was unimportant to have young people at this youth job summit. The Minister in his answer said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . he did not say at any point that young people should not attend the job summit.
Those are Senator Cook's words. Why did Senator Cook mislead this Senate? Quite clearly, Mr Beazley's words yesterday were, `I think we actually know what young people want'.
Asked, `What do they want?', he replied:
They want jobs and they want training. Having young people around telling us that isn't necessarily going to be a big help.
Why cannot Senator Cook be honest with this chamber? In addition to that, Senator Cook went on to say in his answer in Question Time today:
I have in front of me a transcript of an interview with Kim Beazley in Cairns on Monday, 22 June 1992. In that transcript there is this question:

Senator Cook has referred to a transcript not once but twice. At the end of Question Time my colleague Senator Tambling asked Senator Cook to table the transcript provided by aNiMaLS from which he was quoting. Senator Cook told the Senate that he was not quoting from a transcript; he was quoting from his notes.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he didn't say that.

—That is clearly what he said. The excuse that he used not to table the transcript was that it was now his notes. It is just incredible that not once but twice Senator Cook could mislead this Senate in one answer. Why did he say that Mr Beazley had not said that he wanted to give young people the flick for the youth job summit? Why did he say that he was quoting from a transcript when he was quoting from his own made up, convenient notes?

PARA.TAB: We now know why he said that Mr Beazley did not make these comments—because he was not reading from a transcript at all; he was reading from a figment of his imagination that he had decided to put on paper and quote as if it were Mr Beazley's comments. That is just scurrilous misbehaviour in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are making it up; that's the problem.

—I am not making it up, because I have the quotes. I have the quotes from Senator Cook today and the quotes from Mr Beazley. Who is making it up? Is Senator McMullan saying that Mr Beazley is making it up or is he saying that Senator Cook is making it up? Here are the transcripts. If honourable senators opposite do not want to refer to transcripts I cannot help that. If the truth hurts then it hurts, but that is just a bit tough. Senator Cook went on to say in his answer today:

SPEECH.PARA: At no point did Kim Beazley say that young people should not be at the job summit.

Once again, that simply is not true because not only did Kim Beazley say on the Sunday program that young people did not need to be there, but also in Townsville yesterday he said on the ABC national news program that there was no need for young people to be there. He did not say it once; he said it twice—and here is Senator Cook saying yet again that at no point did Kim Beazley say that young people should not be there.

PARA.TAB: I just wish Senator Cook could get his act together. Misleading the Senate in Question Time is not something of which he should be necessarily proud. Unfortunately there have been censure motions moved against Senator Cook in the past during this Parliament and previous parliaments but Senator Cook has chosen not to comply with the traditional Westminster system and resign once a censure motion has been passed against him.

Senator McMullan may well think that is a bit of a giggle. Prior to this Government, misleading the Parliament used to be quite a serious offence. Now it just happens to be something that can be taken as an everyday occurrence, because we have it today from Senator Cook yet again. Does he mind? No, he does not mind. Do any of his colleagues mind? No, they do not mind. Do any of them pull him into line and say, `How about telling the truth for a change?'. No, because this is the standard of this Government.

Members of the Government are not worried about getting jobs for young people; they are simply worried about their own political survival. As my colleague Senator Reid said at Question Time today, the mere fact that this is not going to be an open forum, that the only thing that is going to be televised is the opening speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), makes this whole show a blatant political stunt.

Does the Government really want to do anything about jobs? Does it want to get the tax burden off businesses so that they can employ more people? Does it want to remove seven taxes that are burdening the business community by $20 billion a year? No. Does it want to reduce payroll tax? No. Does it want to abolish payroll tax? No. It will not even look at it. Instead, it will put other taxes on employment; it will put training guarantee levies on employment. It will put extra demands for employer funded superannuation on employment, just to make sure that businesses cannot employ more people. If this Government were really dinkum about creating jobs, it would not have passed the legislation that it has passed this very week increasing the superannuation levies.

TALK.START.PARA: —We haven't actually done that yet.
—Yes, that is very true, but it is imminent, let us face it. Because the Government has this cosy little arrangement with these creatures down here called the Democrats, it will happen.

PARA.TAB: The Government and the Democrats do not care about the impact on employment and all of that. It matters not. If the Government were worried about employment impact, it would not be increasing these levies on the employers. It would be taking the burdens away from them so that they could create jobs. But no, at every turn we have additional demands being placed on employers.

Why then, with legislation in the Parliament this very week that seeks to increase the burden on employers, does the Prime Minister then turn around, scratch his head and say, `Wow, this is a good idea for a youth job summit?'. What was that crazy thing Senator Harradine referred to the other day that was all designed to create publicity for Prime Minister Hawke?

TALK.START.PARA: —Priority One.

—Priority One. I thank Senator Patterson. Young people were meant to be the priority of this Labor Government. Young people have been priority No. 1 for this Government to make sure they do not have a job. Yet here we go, we are going to reinvent the wheel and we are going to now have a youth job summit at the same time as increasing the burdens of taxation and compliance costs right across the board to business.

PARA.TAB: I believe that it is a very serious thing that Senator Cook has done today in misleading the Senate not once but twice. It would be a pleasant change for this Senate if Senator Cook had the decency to come in here and apologise. But to know Senator Cook is to know that he would never dream of doing that. No matter how many times he misleads the Senate, and no matter how many times there are censure motions passed against him, he will still stand on his dig and make sure that he can come in here and manipulate any story he likes for his own welfare and that of the Government.

It is absolute nonsense to have this job summit at a time when this Government is not serious about looking after young people. The only course of action that can be taken is to adopt the policy of a Liberal-National Party Government that takes taxes and compliance costs away from business and can create jobs.

I was talking to some business people—it is interesting Senator McKiernan, a fellow Western Australia, is here in the chamber at the moment—in Osborne Park the other day. They said to me that, just with the abolition of payroll tax and fuel excise, one of these smallish companies would be able to employ three more people and the other would employ two more people. With the abolition of just two taxes, five jobs could be created. But will this Government abolish those taxes? No, it will not. Will it take all the wholesale sales tax off business inputs? No, it will not. The Government should not turn around to me in this debate and say that we are going to add on 15 per cent to business costs because we are not. It is one of the Labor lies that keeps on being told time and time again in the hope that people will believe it is true. I just hope that, in the few remaining days of this session that are left, we can start seeing some fact coming out of Senator Cook's mouth instead of fiction.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate this afternoon on a motion by Senator Parer that we take note of about five answers to questions to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, is a very confused debate. The answers related to a range of issues—be it youth unemployment, the industrial relations legislation which was passed through this place last week, or the current industrial relations dispute at Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd in the Pilbara region.

PARA.TAB: I do not think the tactics being engaged in here are particularly good tactics. I think the matters that have been mentioned, or the motion that has been moved to the responses by Senator Cook, are very important. Whilst there might be an interrelationship between them Senator Parer, in moving the motion in the way that he did, I think has added confusion rather than make the matters in any way clearer or bring the matters closer to resolution, as in the case of the Hamersley Iron dispute.

I confine my remarks to that particular dispute and say quite openly at the commencement of my contribution to the debate that I do not know enough about what is currently happening within Hamersley Iron, Dampier, Tom Price and Paraburdoo in the Pilbara region of Western Australia. Nonetheless, I will proceed, albeit in ignorance, as I suggest previous speakers have done. It is a very dangerous thing to get up and speak in ignorance about something that has happened, but we in this chamber do it all the time. It has been witnessed here yet again this afternoon in previous contributions to the debate.

The Pilbara region in Western Australia is an area that I know exceptionally well. It is an area I would rather be in on these cold mornings than stuck here in Canberra. It has been noted for its high volatility in the area of industrial unrest and in the area of disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is responsible for that?

—Many people are responsible for that including, on the admission of themselves, the employers who participate in that area. They have admitted that in many cases in years gone by. Many mistakes have been made in that area by the unions, by the employers and by governments. One remarkable thing that has happened in the last nine years—and I pay tribute to Senator Cook for his contribution to this—is the establishment of the Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council, a tripartite body consisting of the employers, the trade unions and two governments—the Federal Government and the State Government.

PARA.TAB: Since that Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council has been in operation, industrial disputes within the Pilbara region have dropped markedly. That drop is not singularly attributed to the establishment and operation of the consultative council, but the council has played a major role in bringing it about. Not only is there the peak body which meets perhaps three times a year, but there are also local bodies which operate on a week to week, day to day basis. When problems arise, they are talked through and resolutions can be accommodated to satisfy all. It not just a question of winner takes all; it is that each side can get something out of it when there is a difference of opinion or whatever. It has worked. The statistics prove it—not only the industrial relations statistics of the strike figures, but also the productivity figures. They are there for people to examine for themselves.

So now we have a strike. Who precipitated this current dispute that was the subject matter of questions during Question Time? Was it Hamersley Iron in the form of Tony Finucane or any of the individual industrial relations managers? No, it was not. Was it any of the trade union people, be they shop stewards or convenors? No, it was not. Was it any member of the State or Federal governments, both of which played intimate roles in the operations of the iron ore industry in the area and the export of its product? No, it was not. It was one individual who stood himself out from the crowd; it was one individual out of in excess of 2,000 workers in the area who decided that he did not want to be part of the system. One individual has determined for himself that he is going to bring down all of the good work that has been done in the Pilbara region of Western Australia in the industrial relations field.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—Because of his own firm beliefs. He can do it in opposition to a set peace agreement that is in operation between the trade union movement and the employers in the area. The strike is not the fault of Hamersley Iron; the strike is not the fault of the trade union people who work there or, indeed, the workers.

PARA.TAB: The dispute will not be resolved in this chamber, in the other place or in any parliamentary forum. I suggest the best way of doing it for the moment would be for us to note what is happening and refer the matter back to where it can be resolved. It will not be resolved here in this chamber when it comes down to a point scoring exercise between political parties that are out there scraping for a vote.

Senator Crichton-Browne, in his contribution to the debate, made mention of the cost of this dispute that is happening right now in Western Australia. That is a cost to the community of Australia because we are losing valuable export income from it. It is a cost to the people who purchase the ore from Australia. It is a cost to the whole of the economy and the community of Australia. It is a cost to the employer, Hamersley Iron, which pays the wages of the individuals. The company has massive capital tied up there which is idle at the moment. It is a cost also to the workers and their families. They have not idly jumped up and said, `We are going to go on strike because we need a holiday'. They have gone on strike because of a principle. Two thousand workers have decided that they cannot and will not allow one individual to stick out. In taking the action that they have—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not allowed freedom.

—Senator Walters would not understand because she has no conception of what it is like for working people. The only thing these people have is their weekly income or their fortnightly income, which they earn with the sweat of their brow in that very hostile environment. They have decided that they will forfeit that income to preserve the basis of trade unionism as they see it in the Pilbara. Their employer, might I add, has no objection to trade unions because they have all lived with the formalised collective bargainings that have been in place for many years.

PARA.TAB: In his contribution Senator Crichton-Browne mentioned fear. He said that the particular individual who has precipitated this million-dollar—or whatever it has cost—dispute in Western Australia has had to leave town because of fear. I do not know whether that is the case. I do not even know the individual's name, nor do I want to. If the individual and his family have left town, it is probably for the good because tempers will get frayed as, indeed, they do in circumstances like this.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is no excuse for thuggery.
—Senator Walters should not keep interjecting. She has nothing to add to the debate because she does not understand what the hell is happening in society.
—We understand that Australia is losing millions of dollars worth of exports.
—I have already mentioned that, and have accepted it. Had it not been for Senator Walters harping in Senator Knowles's ear, perhaps Senator Knowles would have heard what I said. I did not excuse it.

PARA.TAB: If the individual has left town, I would suggest it was not only because of fear. If one really wanted to see fear in action, one should have gone to Pannawonica, Cape Lambert or Wickham when the other previous large industrial dispute was in operation, when very physical violence was exhorted not only on the workers who wanted to remain part of the union movement but also on their families. Not only was there physical violence but also the families, who in many cases were defenceless against very scurrilous, very secret and very damaging attacks by the white-collar work force, experienced mental torture.

Now is the time to back off. I do not think a debate by us here will resolve a dispute that is occurring in the remote regions of Western Australia. I think that will properly be done within the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission where Commissioner Fielding has already made a determination. I am disappointed that the workers have not seen fit to accept that determination. As I said, I am speaking in ignorance; I do not know all the details. Obviously the parties know a lot more about this matter than I do.
