I join Senator Cook in encouraging the workers who are in dispute to accept the recommendations of the umpire, Commissioner Fielding—or whoever else makes determinations on this matter—to go back to work to get the income that provides their livelihood, to provide the employer with the profits for which the business has been established and also to help get the nation back on its feet. Very valuable export income dollars are being lost. I think the dispute will be resolved in the Pilbara—however long it goes on; I certainly hope it does not go on for too long. It will not be resolved in the cosiness of the Senate chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the answers that Senator Cook gave in Question Time. It is necessary to do so because Senator Cook has misled the Senate. I will take up Senator McKiernan's comment that I would not understand the workers. I ask whether Senator McKiernan has ever worked a 72-hour week without overtime, whether he has ever worked a 60—
—Last week.

—I ask Senator McKiernan whether, prior to his coming to this place, he has ever worked a 72-hour week, without overtime, or whether he has ever worked a 62-hour week in the daytime, with no overtime. I have. During my nursing training for four years I worked 72-hour night duty weeks, with no overtime; I worked 62-hour day duty weeks, with no overtime, and I was paid a pittance of a salary. Do not let Senator McKiernan dare talk to me about not understanding the workers. Senator McKiernan has never worked the hours and in such difficult situations that I have. Let Senator McKiernan not try to tell me that I do not understand. I understand all right. It is a pity that Senator McKiernan has not done the sort of work that I have done. If he had, he might understand that things are not always rosy, that people do not go on strike just because they feel like it or because one person might not want to belong to a union.

PARA.TAB: Strike action would have been completely irresponsible because it would have left unattended the patients that I had been nursing. When one is looking after sick people, one cannot go on strike merely because it suits one or because one feels like it. One cannot go on strike up at Hamersley because, if one does, so much damage is done to the country. Because one person does not want to belong to a union is not a ground on which to damage the country.

It is really time that Senator McKiernan learned that, to be responsible and to carry out the important jobs in this country, one has to take the good with the bad. If one disapproves of one person not joining the union, that is tough cheddar. One puts up with it and does not go on strike to do the sort of damage that is occurring in Hamersley at the moment. As far as my work is concerned, I have certainly never been on strike, and I would never ever contemplate it.

Let us look at some of the other things that Senator Cook referred to in his answer. He told us how wonderful the waterfront reform was. Let me read from an article to illustrate the lack of reform on the waterfront and the lack of reform in the attitudes on the waterfront. This incident to which I am about to refer occurred only last month. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Picketing by Fremantle port workers aimed at stopping a shift from using non-union labour to load its export cargo exposes the superficial nature of many changes that have been made on the wharves in Western Australia in the name of waterfront reform.
The article goes on:

PARA.TAB: There is something drastically wrong with the system when a skipper says he can load a 700-tonne cargo of potatoes for $7.50 a tonne using contract workers while stevedoring companies charge a minimum of $30 per tonne.

SPEECH.PARA: Seven dollars and fifty cents versus $30! The article continues:

PARA.TAB: Such a discrepancy makes a farce of claims by politicians that new arrangements on the waterfront . . . have been successful.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet Senator Cook and Senator Collins have been telling us how wonderful the waterfront reforms have been since this Government started them a few months ago. Yesterday, an international report on Australia's competitiveness was released. The report said that, out of 22 OECD countries, Australia was sixteenth in competitiveness. In three years we fell from the tenth best to the sixteenth best. The report said that this was due to government corruption—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the poor management?

—I am coming to that. The report said this was due to government corruption, poor worker attitudes, the regulatory environment, poor product quality, a narrow export base, poor management and low priority for scientific research. We are now sixteenth out of 22, a fall in three years from tenth place. What a wonderful Government we have!

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook talked about New Zealand. Let us look at what the report said happened in New Zealand in just one year. Having been in eighteenth place out of 22—very low down—New Zealand went to fifteenth place, beating Australia, in just one year. Senator Cook says that New Zealand is doing so badly that we should not copy it. In one year New Zealand moved from eighteenth place, out of 22, to beating us in fifteenth place.
Honourable senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! If honourable senators are going to interject, I suggest they do it from their own positions.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good idea, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—I would like all remarks addressed through the Chair.

—Senator Cook is saying that we should not be taking any notice of what is happening in New Zealand with its industrial relations and its introduction of a goods and services tax. New Zealand does not have our full Fightback package. Our full Fightback package is far superior to that of New Zealand's. Senator Cook says that it is doing so badly.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook told us that the industrial relations legislation which the Senate has just passed says that independent contractors will not be forced to join unions. I said previously that I have past experience of this because independent contractors are just as vulnerable to intimidation as anyone else. If independent contractors are told by the union movement that it expects them to join the union tomorrow, or else they may be responsible for an accident occurring to their son—I am not quoting some hypothetical situation; this is what occurred to one independent contractor in Tasmania whom I know extremely well—

TALK.START.PARA: —Name them.

—If this happened, not many independent contractors would be prepared to risk putting their son on the line. Senator Sherry says that I should name them. If I believed for one moment that I could trust the Building Workers Industrial Union not to take vindictive action against these people, I would name them, but neither Senator Sherry nor I know or believe for one second that that vindictive action would not be taken. We know that it does and we know it would be.
—No, it wouldn't.

—Senator Sherry claims that it would not. If he is being honest, he is the only one who believes that. We have had so many reports of exactly what sort of intimidation does occur in that type of union. Let us be perfectly clear that the majority of unions in Australia are very responsible. But we do have a handful of rogue unions that misbehave, intimidate and threaten, and we all know them. As Senator Knowles said, the only way that we are able to set the unemployment situation right is to get rid of those five taxes that we have said we will abolish under our Fightback package.
—I thought it was seven.
—The Government has already taken up one of them. It already abolished one after we came out with the seven—
—What was the sixth?
—The customs duties one. The Government abolished that after we came out—
—It was the coal export levy.

—Oh, the coal export levy; I am sorry. That was the one that the Government abolished after we had named those taxes. We have said that the payroll tax must go and the Government tells us that it will not make any difference to jobs. We know that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) does not believe that because his interest in Danpork has been exempted from having to pay payroll tax. The Prime Minister's company has been able to negotiate with the Government of New South Wales to free the company of having to pay payroll tax until it gets started. That is not bad, is it? The Prime Minister will accept from the New South Wales Government an exemption from payroll tax on his family company's share in Danpork, but it is not good enough for the rest of Australian business. The Prime Minister accepts the exemption for his own company but he will not introduce it for other companies in Australia. He wants that tax taken off his back while his business gets going, but he does not want it taken off the backs of other businesses, so his company can expand and employ more people. Senator Sherry and Senator Tate, both Tasmanians, realise that the Pasminco company, for instance, pays $3.8m payroll tax.
—Will they employ more workers?
—Yes. Indeed, I have already spoken to them about it. Paul Salmon has said that if the company had more money it would expand. Very good plans have been made for expansion.
—To employ more people?
—If Senator Sherry does not understand that if companies expand then they will employ more people—
—How many?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! I ask Senator Sherry to cease interjecting. There are too many interjections on my right. I would prefer remarks to be directed through the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry does not seem to understand that if a company can expand and payroll tax is taken off its back, like the tax being taken off the back of the Prime Minister with Danpork, it can employ more people. That is what Danpork wants to do. It wants to set up in New South Wales and expand. It has been encouraged to go into New South Wales rather than Queensland. The Government of New South Wales has said, `You set up in New South Wales and we promise to allow you to get going and expand by removing from you the burden of payroll tax'. Senator Sherry should not tell me that that does not mean that Mr Keating's company can employ more people. Of course it means that Mr Keating's company can employ more people. If it is good enough for him, it should be good enough for every other company in Australia. But unfortunately that is not the situation.

PARA.TAB: I shall not speak for any longer because we are under the guillotine in regard to the rest of the Bills that are coming up and I know that some of my colleagues want to speak. But we must get correct answers to our questions; otherwise we will respond in this fashion on every occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate arose out of matters relating to what is happening in the Pilbara, but it has become a debate about the philosophy of what should guide unionism or should guide people who are in the work force. I think the proposition put by the other side—that individuals have rights and that the individual should stand above the group—is accepted in many places. That argument, put by Senator Parer in his usual lucid way, can be respected. Our difficulty is that we believe individuals have rights, certainly, but we also believe that groups have rights. As we look around to see who might accept and support our philosophy, as distinct from the individualist philosophy from the other side, we see, for example, a statement from the New Zealand Catholic Bishops Conference. I know that those opposite would not accept that, and I respect their position, because their philosophy is based on matters other than those on which we base our philosophy.

PARA.TAB: It is worth reading this statement because it refers to the legislation in New Zealand of which those opposite are much enamoured. I can understand, given the basis of their philosophy, that they would be enamoured of that legislation. When Senator Sherry, I and others were in New Zealand last year, we were given a statement from the Bishops Conference. It is worth reading a passage from it:

SPEECH.PARA: This legislative change—
that is, the change contemplated by those opposite—
is not simply a technical issue. It involves ethics and morality.

That is, unfortunately, the handicap we have on this side: we act from a basis of ethics and morality. It is often a bit difficult to counter those on the other side who are less inclined to do that in this area. The statement continues:

The question must be asked what the new legislation does to people and society, to human dignity and the common good. As Bishops of New Zealand we must speak against this proposed legislation as its underlying ideology is contrary to the social doctrines of the Church.

That is the Catholic church. We do not adhere to this or that church, but we do think the sorts of things the bishops say have particular relevance in this area. The bishops quote Pope Paul VI in this way:
Pope Paul VI teaches that, `All social action involves a doctrine. The Christian cannot admit that which is based upon a materialistic and atheistic philosophy'.

What is this materialistic and atheistic philosophy they talk about? As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator Parer is a most outstanding and decent man, but on this subject he unfortunately seems to have abandoned the sorts of things that are spoken about in this statement. What is this underlying philosophy that they talk about? The bishops go on to say:
The underlying ideology of the new industrial legislation—
that is the legislation the other side would like to adopt, it seems—
is unacceptable for two reasons: firstly, because it emphasises free choice without balancing this concept with concern for the common good—
that is, the public good—
and secondly because it emphasises the rights of the individual without their accompanying duty to act in solidarity and without giving any corresponding rights to the group.

That is exactly what Senator Parer is concerned about. He says, `The individual should be able to stand above the group. The individual should have no duty to act in solidarity with the others'. That is a philosophy I can understand, but I say to Senator Parer and those opposite that that philosophy is the one that is by implication described in this statement as materialistic and atheistic.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no.
—Senator Parer says `No', but he cannot contradict what is set out in the bishops' statement. The statement continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation assumes that the free pursuit of his or her interest by the private individual automatically leads to the public or common good of society. As Bishops, guiding our people in faith and morals, it is our duty to reject this assumption for two reasons.
I will not read them out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sound advice.

—As Senator Sherry said, it is sound advice. What concerns me and worries me about Senator Parer raising this debate is that he is so overwhelmed in his mind—a very decent mind on most things, may I say—by this concept of the individual's right to run roughshod, as Senator McKiernan said, over 2,000 people and over the employer and above the union that he believes that an individual's right supersedes and soars above all these things.
—It does.

—That is a philosophy Senator Parer is entitled to have. His philosophy is apparently accepted on the other side. That philosophy is described as materialistic and atheistic. It is all right for him to accept that, but we on this side of the chamber take a different view. We say that, although that individual in the Pilbara has a right, that right is not one that can override the rights of the group and the rights of the common good.

PARA.TAB: The debate this afternoon revolves around that philosophical difference, and we on this side will adhere to a view that is more in conformity with the sorts of things that the bishops in New Zealand said. I want to raise one other matter. There has been allegation after allegation from the other side that unions are violent—

TALK.START.PARA: —Some unions.
—I thank Senator Walters for the correction—that some unions are violent and that all violence is perpetrated, as far as industrial disputes go, by the unions. That is the inference.
—No, that's the fact.

—Senator Parer says that is the fact, that all the violence which occurs in industrial disputes is perpetrated or caused by the unions. The problem is that that is the witch-hunt syndrome. To illustrate just how false that statement is—and I hope Senator Crane will speak after me and answer this—there is the evidence of what happened at Camperdown abattoirs. A series of people there were prosecuted for alleged violence on the picket line. All the charges have either been dismissed or withdrawn, and the police as a result have had to pay $18,000 worth of costs. The highest ranking policeman down there in the Western Districts, the superintendent, Mr Neil Patterson, according to the Warrnambool Standard of 30 May 1992, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that witnesses in court cases against Camperdown abattoirs picketers had `used' the police. Asked whether he had any regrets about the outcome of the earlier cases—
he was talking at this stage about later cases—
and the decision to withdraw unheard charges, Mr Patterson said: "I wish the whole thing had never happened.

PARA.TAB: "We felt as though we were used in some ways.
"We got bad publicity and we were not the instigators in most of the matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters understandably said that she would not name the person who had been wrongly accused. I will quote the name of the person who was wrongly accused in this case. It was Shane Francis Reilly, who was charged with hindering the police. He had to go through the most dramatic of circumstances to have that charge dismissed. It appears from the cross-examination, which I will not go into as I have already referred to it on other occasions here, that a Mr Leeson was down at Camperdown to uncover evidence that could be used against the union and against the workers. In cross-examination, Mr Monti asked Mr Leeson:
You were part of a scheme by Kroger and Kroger to provoke trouble at the meat works, to bring an action for damages against the Union aren't you?
Mr Leeson answered:
No, I'm not.
Mr Monti said:
This is because of a large damages action?
Mr Leeson answered:
I don't know about what Kroger and Kroger want to do. All I know is that the matters may have been kept to be used in future Court proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't there a Kroger who's President of the Liberal Party in Victoria?

—That is so, yes. Perhaps Senator Crane can answer these questions: if all the violence is on the part of the union, why did we have that reaction from the head of the police force in the western district, Mr Neil Patterson? Why is it that the courts found it necessary to dismiss all of those charges? Why is it that Mr Leeson was down there looking after things and preparing for future court proceedings? I have graphically illustrated how unions and members of the unions, and how workers on the picket line, can be most maligned, ill-used and savagely treated in the pursuit of wrongly based court actions against them.

PARA.TAB: There was a unionist down there, Mr Beaton, who was most savagely attacked. He was beaten with an iron bar. The alliteration between his name, Mr Beaton, and the word `beaten' was used by those on the other side to make fun of him. They used that as an indication to others that they should not be crossing those who were looking for evidence to use against them in court cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleagues in this debate to take note of Senator Cook's answers. I wish to comment on Senator Cooney's final remarks. I read with interest what Senator Cooney had to say last Wednesday night with regard to Camperdown. At a suitable time, I will respond to what he had to say. I repeat what I have said in this place before, particularly with regard to the meat industry. There has been some disgraceful behaviour by the AMIEU with respect to the meat industry and what the AMIEU has done to it. Senator Cooney well knows that I have criticised a number of the employers involved in the meat industry for the part that they have played in it. At this time I do not wish to say anything more about that; I have been told that I have to wind up by 5 o'clock, so I do not have much time.

PARA.TAB: In the time I have available, I wish to refer to the Hamersley Iron situation and pick up on the comments made by Senator Beahan, Senator McKiernan and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). This debate highlights the fundamental difference between the Opposition and the Government—ours is a position of freedom of choice; the position of the Government is one of compulsion. That has been spelt out quite clearly by what the Minister said in answer to a question today and during this debate. He said that he disagreed with the law as it exists in Western Australia. All I can say is, `Thank God for what was done in Western Australia in 1982 by the then coalition Government. Thank goodness the upper House in Western Australia has had the sense to keep that law in place since that time'. This is a debate about compulsion as against freedom.

I think it is ironic that we are having this debate today when we look at what happened in the United States last week. Mr Yeltsin, from Russia, addressed both Houses of Congress in the United States. He got a standing ovation when he said, `This is the end of the era of communism and compulsion in Russia; it is the beginning of the era of freedom and that compulsion will never return'. That is a very significant comment. Those on the other side of the chamber could well take note of it.

In relation to the Hamersley dispute, this debate is about one of the worst abuses of union power which can possibly exist against the rule of law. It is a matter of high principle. This debate is about the abuse of union power by a select few unions in this country, thereby destroying the good reputations of those unions who behave quite rationally and quite sensibly. If I had more time, I would go on to name some of those unions.

However, the Minister commented today on the position of the legislation which was passed last week. We can compare those comments with the sorts of remarks he made last week about the Housing Industry Association—and, if we had time, it would be worth drawing a comparison also with the remarks he made about APPM in Tasmania. The Minister last week commented on the Housing Industry Association to the effect that it was extremist, disgraceful, dishonourable and disreputable, despicable, dishonest and untrue, a discredited housing organisation.

All that the Housing Industry Association was doing was exercising its right to disagree. It did not pull out the contractors in its industry and say, `Stop building houses'. It did not say, `We are going to take the law into our own hands'. It exercised the fundamental right to disagree with the Government and to state its disagreement publicly. Yet what has this Government done in terms of broadcasting? When we go into the next election, the Government will prevent organisations like the Housing Industry Association being able to advertise those particular matters on television and elsewhere. That is the position of this Government. It wants to kill free speech; it wants to take away the right of free speech from the Housing Industry Association or any other organisation, for that matter. The union movement has a right to put its point of view to the Australian public. But the union involved at Hamersley does not have a right to hold Hamersley to ransom. It does not have the right to victimise an individual and his family—because that is what this is about.

I congratulate Tony Finigan from Hamersley on his appearance on the 7.30 Report the other night. I hope Senator McKiernan, who is in the chamber, heard what Tony Finigan had to say on that program. Tony Finigan was asked—and this is as best as I remember it—`Wouldn't it be easy for you to sack that particular person and send him on his way and they'd all go back to work?', and he said, `Yes, it would be easy, but my company is not about breaking the law; I will not do it. That individual has a right to operate and to work on that particular site as an individual. It is his freedom of choice as to whether or not he joins the union'. It was a very brave Tony Finigan who said that, in spite of the pressure that is on the company. Employees do have that right, it has cost them dearly, and I will defend that individual's right of freedom of choice.

I agree with Senator McKiernan when he said we should not be debating this matter in this place. The only reason we are debating this issue in this place is that the union up there defied the decision of the Western Australian Arbitration Commission. If it had gone back to work, we would not be debating Hamersley here in this place today. It is for that reason we are debating it. It is about time that both sides of the equation, the employers and the unions, accepted the decisions made by the Arbitration Commission.

The same position applies to that which existed in Tasmania with APPM. If the parties had accepted the first recommendations to return to work, we would not have seen the continuation of that dispute in the way we did. What we are talking about with Hamersley is whether small groups in the community have the right to abuse the law, to take the law into their own hands and to run this country by anarchy.

The only way to improve productivity in Australia—Senator Walters has just touched on this matter—is by putting incentive into the system; by getting rid of up-front business taxes in industry; and by giving individuals the opportunity and incentive to maximise their own efforts. That will never occur until such time as those individuals are allowed to negotiate as employee and employers together.

Those opposite will not improve productivity under the certified agreement position that was put in the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill last week, particularly now that there has to be union involvement. There have to be unions on the shop floor. That was part of the legislation that was passed last week. That was a backward step in industrial relations reform by the Government.

I conclude my remarks on this matter by re-emphasising what Senator Knowles said about the Minister misleading the Senate. The Minister has a very loose tongue when it comes to playing with the truth; he likes to stretch it out a little bit. I bring to the attention of honourable senators in this place that it was about this time in the last sitting of Parliament that we were moving to censure Senator Cook over the Robe River matter. He was forced to put documents on the table. Those documents confirmed precisely what I had been saying. He also said at that time that he was going to make an adjournment speech to resolve the matter, to clear the air. He still has not done that. He said he would do so this session, and that is recorded in Hansard. He has only two days to go.

This Minister is consistent: he often plays with the truth and misleads us during Question Time as to the true position and the facts. I reject the sorts of accusations he makes and the language he uses when he comes in here and talks about these matters; for example, when he talked about the Housing Industry Association and others. He has also included the NFF in his attacks in recent times. He attacks them on a false premise, on matters that are not true. That highlights very succinctly the difference between us and the Government. Our position is one of freedom and freedom of choice, the rights of the individual; the position of the Government is one of compulsion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time I asked that Senator Ray withdraw a comment he made about one of my colleagues. Some of my colleagues on this side of the House agreed with me and some of them disagreed with me. My staff have listened to the tape and I have discussed the matter with Senator Ray. He said that the jury really is out because he may have made a freudian slip; he should not have called anybody a smart alec anyway—but I probably would not have objected to that. I think we have agreed that the jury is out on his comment. Therefore I may have been a little hasty, as there is some disagreement about what he said. I put that on the public record.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901 I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No.44 of 1991-92—Project Audit—Department of Social Security—Entitlement checks in localities with Community Development Employment Projects.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak on the Auditor-General's Audit Report No. 44—Project Audit—Department of Social Security—Entitlement checks in localities with Community Development Employment Projects, tabled in the Senate today. The community development employment projects or CDEPs which are administered by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission allow Aboriginal communities in which there are no alternative employment prospects to employ local community members to undertake community development activities. These community members are paid the equivalent of Job Search or Newstart allowance but still remain eligible for the additional family benefit.

PARA.TAB: In December 1990, the Australian National Audit Office reported on its audit of ATSIC pertaining to CDEPs. In this audit No. 12 of 1990-91, the Auditor-General found that there was a need for ATSIC and community members to clarify their entitlements to CDEP vis-a-vis the unemployment benefit. In particular, the Auditor found a need to ensure that, in cases where the CDEP payment is less than the unemployment benefit, the person receives the difference in the unemployment benefit. In this 1990 report, the Auditor also identified a number of factors which contribute to inaccurate payments, as well as a number of areas in which there was scope for ATSIC to improve its administrative procedures.

In the August 1991 Budget, the Government foreshadowed changes to the Social Security Act to prevent recipients of Commonwealth funded employment programs, such as the CDEP, from double dipping by claiming the Job Search or Newstart allowance as well. Although it was claimed by the Department of Social Security that such instances of double dipping were rare, the necessary changes to the Social Security Act were included in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), which passed through Parliament late last year.

In June 1991, an interdepartmental review of the CDEP found that checking of the simplified CDEP participant schedules was an inadequate arrangement for DSS's crosschecking purposes. As a result, amended checking procedures were put in place during the second half of 1991 whereby there would be a greater cooperation between DSS and ATSIC in establishing new CDEP schemes, but that DSS would rely on its own liaison processes to prevent incorrect payments under social security legislation.

In addition, in response to proposals for enhancing the CDEP scheme placed before the Government in July 1991, it was also decided that the relevant Ministers—the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, and the Minister for Social Security—prepare for the Government's consideration a submission for coordinating client databases and facilitating the exchange of client data. This is the background against which this project audit was conducted in mid-1991. It is a background which indicates that there has been a general recognition of the need for greater accountability, better monitoring and improved liaison between ATSIC and DSS.

Because of the significant policy and procedural changes which were being implemented at the time of this audit, it is difficult to assess whether the Auditor's concerns continue to be valid today. The Government's task must be to assess the extent to which the changes in policy and procedures that he has put in place address the concerns which have been expressed by the Auditor in this report. However, it needs to be said that the ANAO has concluded in this audit report that the procedures in place at the time of review were unable to provide assurances that persons in receipt of income under CDEP schedules were not also, as individuals, incorrectly in receipt of social security benefits.

Obviously, it is a very serious matter if people who are in receipt of CDEP payments are also receiving Job Search or Newstart allowances to which they are not entitled. Such a situation was totally contrary to the intentions of the Parliament when it amended the Social Security Act last year. It is totally contrary to the overriding rationale for the CDEP scheme whereby participants receive a CDEP wage in lieu of unemployment benefits. It also runs counter to the Auditor's earlier report in 1990.

In light of the fact that it was found that it was not possible to be assured that persons in receipt of the CDEP were not receiving incorrect social security benefits, the Auditor made a number of recommendations which need to be taken very seriously by the Government. Most notably, the Auditor casts doubt on the validity of the policy and procedural changes announced last year whereby DSS decided to confine its responsibilities to its own programs and not to have an involvement in the delivery of the CDEP program.

The Auditor contends that it is premature to endorse such a move when there remains the potential for people drawing CDEP wages to also claim DSS benefits for which they are not eligible. Instead, the Auditor believes that there is a need to pursue more coordinated and cooperative arrangements in relation to the setting up of new CDEPs, the conduct of periodic joint reviews, the coordination of databases and the conducting of a foreshadowed census of all existing CDEP communities.

The Auditor believes that DSS, rather than withdrawing its involvement in the CDEP scheme, is well placed to contribute to the development of the effective delivery of CDEP in remote areas because of its size, computer resources and experience. The Auditor notes that the Government, in its response to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, has recommended that there continue to be a general emphasis on `maintaining parity between CDEP wages and forgone DSS entitlements'. However, he concludes that, unless there is some form of regular check to minimise double dipping, it will be very difficult to maintain such a parity. I understand that both the Department of Social Security and ATSIC have agreed to the vast majority of the recommendations contained in this report.

The report is also important in the light of various concepts that have been put around. In fact, Prime Minister Keating, or at least one of the Ministers on the other side, recently suggested programs for young people working on farms. A similar situation may exist in that very careful auditing needs to be done to ensure that a program such as that does not have problems associated with it and that people do not receive two benefits.

We want every facility to be made to ensure that Aborigines in remote communities are able to carry out the programs with dignity, but we are also concerned about the Auditor's report in that the lack of coordination between some of the departments may mean that there are some problems still associated with CDEP and the possibility of double dipping from Social Security.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Audit report No. 45 of 1991-92, Efficiency Audit—Department of Veterans' Affairs—Outsourcing—The Management of Redundancy Arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This document, the forty-fifth report of 1991-92 by the Auditor-General, is a very important one, since its recommendations have implications for the future actions of many Commonwealth agencies. The report primarily addresses staffing issues and efficiencies achieved arising from the Department of Veterans' Affairs contracting out its information technology services to the private sector.

PARA.TAB: The Department of Veterans' Affairs has been somewhat of a ground breaker in the contracting out of information technology services. I understand it is the first Commonwealth agency to do so. The coalition strongly endorses the contracting out of public sector services as a general principle and, after obtaining assurances on the security of veterans' data, we supported the Government's actions with respect to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. We did that because every available taxpayers' dollar in that Department should be concentrated on the compensation and care of veterans and war widows. Any reasonable effort to contain bureaucratic overhead costs should be undertaken.

Of course, not everybody in the Government was happy with the decision. Senator Richardson tried, and failed, to dissuade Cabinet from approving the DVA proposal. The reasons for his objection were revealed in an extraordinary four-page letter to the Prime Minister which was leaked to the press. Not surprisingly, the objections were not based on principles of financial management or any genuine concern at the implications for veterans, but rather were purely political. Senator Richardson recognised that, by supporting the outsourcing, the Government would not be in a position to exploit any community concerns over the coalition's policies. On this occasion we can be thankful that the Cabinet reached a decision based, not on the dishonest politics of the kind Senator Richardson practises, but on sound policy principles.

In this report, the Auditor-General has criticised a number of aspects of the outsourcing process. Inadequacies in the process were highlighted when industrial disputation occurred. The disputation was initially provoked in September last year by a lack of coordination between the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Finance, resulting in Public Sector Union action. After a hearing before the IRC, disputation ceased. However, unfortunately, this was only for a short time. After a second IRC hearing, the PSU refused to comply with an order to end its disruptive activities.

The report notes that no pensions were affected as a result of these activities. Strictly speaking, that is true, but it fails to mention that a number of health providers were very seriously affected. For instance, I received a number of representations from domiciliary nursing agencies which were faced with going out of business because they were not being paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs for their services to veterans. This was threatening their capacity to properly care for veterans and war widows. The payment of veterans pension allowances was also disrupted, and I am surprised that that has not been noted in the Auditor-General's report.

It was only after long overdue ministerial intervention, and prompting from me, I might say, that the Public Sector Union accepted a staffing agreement and ended industrial action on 19 November. As a result of the inadequacies revealed in staffing negotiations, the report recommends that the Department of Finance and the Department of Industrial Relations develop a more comprehensive policy framework for dealing with the staffing aspects of outsourcing to the public sector. This is crucial, given that outsourcing activities are now being considered across a number of other agencies.

The investigation of the staffing issues also identified shortcomings with redundancies and superannuation. I intend to draw the Auditor-General's attention to issues related to redundancies in government business enterprises which I have had some involvement with recently and which I believe the Department of Industrial Relations is not dealing with adequately. I have had assurances from the Minister, Senator Cook, that he will review the existing policy, but it is also probably something for the Auditor-General to look at.

This report recommends action to make sure that, for those persons where continuing employment is gained with a new supplier, access should be denied to involuntary retirement lump sum superannuation benefits. In this case alone, because of unclear legislation, the cost to the Commonwealth was $700,000. With many agencies likely to follow the same path as the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the importance of getting this provision right is obvious.

The report also looks at the cost savings achieved as a result of the outsourcing. Net savings of $10m will be achieved over five years from February this year. The Department had claimed savings of $12.5m, but did not allow for the direct costs associated with the outsourcing, including more than half a million dollars as a result of the PSU actions.

While aspects of the handling of outsourcing of information technology by the Department of Veterans' Affairs have been criticised, it should be remembered, in fairness to the DVA, that it is the first department to undertake this activity. I find it extraordinary, however, that the Department of Veterans' Affairs continued to fill vacant positions in the computer centre after the decision to outsource had been made and, most incredible of all, that the promotion of one officer was actually gazetted three days after his job and the computer centre had ceased to exist.
The report contains important recommendations for improving the handling of outsourcing in the future. I urge the Government to ensure that the suggested procedures are adopted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
