DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the resolution of 21 June 1991, as amended on 10 September 1991, appointing the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies be further amended to provide that—

(a) the term of appointment of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies be extended till the end of the current Parliament, so that when the results of research the Committee recommends the proposed Australian Broadcasting Authority undertake become available, the Committee may monitor that research, have some input to it and make final recommendations when the research has been completed; and
(b) the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources to enable it to conduct such work.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee intends to table its report after this motion has been disposed of today. The Committee has agreed to seek an extension of its term for the reasons summarised in the motion I have moved.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have my tabling statement incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
This is the third and final report of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies.
The previous two reports, in December 1991 and May 1992, fulfilled that part of the Committee's terms of reference relating to telephone recorded information services.
This report fulfils the terms of reference relating to the standards for content of videotex services and pay television.
The Select Committee was appointed as a result of concerns raised by several Senators during debate in June 1991 on the Telecommunications Bill 1991 and associated bills.

The concerns related specifically to absence in the legislation of any measures which would control the content of 0055 information and entertainment services provided through Telecom lines, or the content of certain videotex services formerly provided through Telecom's Discovery service, and between May 1991 and April 1992 provided as the Genesis service.
Developments in telecommunications technologies had apparently opened up an area of operation not covered by existing censorship arrangements.

During debate on the Telecommunications Bill and associated bills, a majority of Senators formed the view that the whole issue of content and standards for telecommunications services and pay television should be the subject of an inquiry by a select committee.
The Committee was tasked with finding answers to a number of questions:
the nature and content of material being transmitted over the telecommunications network;
whether the content of that material was acceptable having regard to community standards for equivalent material available through other media;
the best way to ensure that the public interest was protected in relation to access to this material; and
whether the content of pay television should include material which would be classified in the R or X categories.

The Committee was to consider in the course of its inquiry the existing regulatory arrangements, at both State and Commonwealth levels, used to regulate all film, video, literature and other publications, and to determine whether similar arrangements were applicable to regulating the provision of commercial recorded information or entertainment services via networks utilising telecommunications technologies.

The Committee was therefore being asked to resolve the fundamental question of applying community standards, in the context of the existing classifications, to the new services of pay television, videotex and telephone message services.

In its May 1992 report on telephone message services, the Committee re-affirmed the recommendations it made in its December 1991 interim report, which called on Telecom Australia to adopt a code of conduct which would completely eliminate the carriage of unacceptable sexual material on the 0055 service where it was accessible by minors.

The industry would then be allowed to cater for this market only through its 0051 closed user access service, restricted to adults who must opt in to the system using a PIN number, but only for material of an equivalence no higher than the M film/video rating.

The Committee recommended that Telecom ensure compliance with this code of conduct by utilising the expertise of the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC) as the independent arbiter of community standards.

In the report I am presenting today, the Committee has concluded that the evidence taken by it in relation to the availability of X-category material reflected the anomalous situation which currently exists. That is, although the sale and distribution of X-rated videos is banned in all the States, sale and distribution is legal in the Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory, and there is a mail order business for such material going to the States from the Australian Capital Territory.
Possession of X-rated material is not an offence save in Western Australia, so that in most States such material may be legally viewed at home.

However, the Committee has given heed to the fact that the elected State governments, representing the overwhelming majority of the Australian population, have registered an objection to X-rated material by banning its sale within their jurisdictions.

For this reason, and because of doubts over its suitability for pay television raised in evidence taken during the inquiry, the Committee has decided to recommend against X-rated material being permitted to be available on pay television.

The Committee has concluded in relation to R-category material that there is undoubtedly concern in the community about the level of violence and the role that depictions of violence, sexual or otherwise, may play in the formation of attitudes to violence.

We recognise that the current situation is that in the Australian States and Territories R-category films and videos are available for public exhibition in cinemas, and for sale for use in private residences.

Despite this, the Committee has decided that, in view of the inconclusive nature of the evidence received by it during its inquiry, the proposed Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) should conduct extensive, Australia-wide quantitative and qualitative research on community standards of taste and decency in relation to classifications for pay television.

The research should also ascertain what levels of violence and depiction of sex should be allowed on pay television, and what other matters should be included for viewing by adults and children in the various classifications.

Until the ABA has completed this research, standards for programs on pay television should be the same as those currently set for free-to-air television by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, which would preclude R-category material being permitted to be available.
I turn now to that part of the Committee's report which deals with videotex services, such as Genesis.

Consistent with its reports on telephone message services, which took account of the high level of public concern at the availability of `adult' information and entertainment on the telephone network, the Committee has decided to recommend that material equivalent to either the R or X film/video classification, or the Category 2 literature classification, not be available on any videotex service.

The Committee has noted that Genesis Telecommunications, which provided an adult videotex service between May 1991 and April 1992, was terminated because the number of subscribers was too small to make it profitable. The Committee considers that this is an indication of the low level of community demand for and acceptance of such services.

The Committee has also recommended that, as with telephone recorded message services, AOTC and other telecommunications services carriers enter into contracts with the Office of Film and Literature Classification for it to act as the monitoring and enforcement body for the code of conduct the Committee has recommended for videotex services.

In the course of its inquiry, the Committee received 2,365 submissions, many of them signed by or representing more than a single individual. In addition, 793 form letters and 61 petitions (signed by a total of 942 petitioners) were received. The Committee noted that sixty petitions relating to the subject of the Committee's inquiry had been tabled in the Senate (15,751 petitioners), and 123 in the House of Representatives (22,807) since 1989.

On behalf of the Committee, I wish to express appreciation to all those individuals and organisations who took an interest in the inquiry, and particularly to those who assisted it by providing submissions and who appeared before it at hearings.
I thank my colleagues on the Committee for helping to make this a productive and successful inquiry.
I also thank the staff of the Committee for their consistent support.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney, I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the Territories Law Reform Bill 1992, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions received by the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.
Debate resumed from 29 April, on motion by Senator Evans:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, a second reading amendment was circulated in my name. I would have to seek leave in order to move it, and I have been given to understand that leave would not be granted.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Have you spoken in this debate, Senator Powell?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—In that case you do not need to seek leave.
—I understood that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) had closed the second reading debate.

—If I may intervene for a moment: I closed the debate in the traditional sense but not in the formal sense because often when legislation first arrives in the Senate it is introduced by a different Minister. I did not introduce this Bill and so technically my speech was just a contribution. I will just explain why we would have refused leave: it is not possible to debate the amendment. This is an important issue and I do not think it deserves to go either up or down on the nod. That was the reason.

—The second reading debate not having concluded, I would like to make a very short contribution. There has been a committee amendment circulated on behalf of the Australian Democrats in addition to those amendments already circulated by Senator Spindler. I would simply wish to raise this issue briefly in the second reading debate on the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. It relates to the recent announcement by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) of policies with regard to acceptable sexual behaviour by members of the Australian Defence Force in the one instance, and in the other instance an instruction with regard to homosexual behaviour in the Australian Defence Force.

PARA.TAB: This announcement raises an issue of major concern. I believe it represents an instance where Australia is in fact failing to meet its obligations under international conventions. There is no provision under anti-discrimination legislation to cover the rights of homosexual members of our society. During the early days of the Hawke Government when anti-discrimination legislation was being passed, the Democrats said that this should have been the case. Nevertheless, it is not and it remains an area where our anti-discrimination laws are, in our view, deficient. Therefore, it is legitimate to ask why, when the Government has legislated equal opportunity for women, for migrants and will soon do so for disabled people, it has not done so for the homosexual members of our community.

The Australian Defence Force is an area where there is a particular problem and the community has strong views on it. The release and endorsement of those two documents, to which I referred last week, point to this problem. It is for that reason that I propose to amend the Defence Act 1903 in the committee stage of the amending I have commended, and I do so here on the public record, the defence instruction on unacceptable sexual behaviour which was tabled by the Minister for Defence in the Senate on 18 June. But I contend that, because of the broad scope of the instruction—including the welcome inclusion of sexual harassment—its clarity and appropriateness, that is all that is necessary to meet the problems which are put forward by the ADF chiefs of staff as the reasons for the separate, and I contend discriminatory, policy on homosexual behaviour in the Australian Defence Force.

Those reasons come under the headings `Command and morale', `National security', `Health' and `Minors'. The point that I make is that the general policy refers to inappropriate sexual behaviour quite differently from the specific policy with regard to homosexual behaviour, which simply talks about involvement in homosexual behaviour, such involvement being unspecified as to its appropriateness; that is, it may not necessarily be in breach of any of the general policy's prohibitions, which are quite specific. For example, point 6 of that general policy reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In all ADF and single service `on entry' training institutions, including the Australian Defence Force Academy, sexual relations and public displays of affection and private intimacy between students and staff, and between all students, regardless of their training status, are to be prohibited within the precincts of the institution and during absences from the institution on duty through the promulgation of a general order as defined by the DFDA.

That is an example of how specific the provisions are in the general instruction. It is the question of public display of affection and so on which I contend should apply equally to heterosexual or homosexual members of the ADF.

PARA.TAB: I note the deep concern of the Human Rights Commissioner, which has been publicly expressed. I note the acknowledgment by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), in reply to a question from me in this place yesterday, that those discriminated against will have no recourse through the courts of this land against the policy, that our Human Rights Commissioner can report only to his Minister, and that such a report will merely be tabled in the Parliament. Senator Tate said regarding international recourse that a successful complaint under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights to the United Nations Human Rights Committee will deliver only a view which cannot be enforced, and that under ILO Convention 111:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has obligations to declare and pursue a national policy designed to promote equality of opportunity and treatment with a view to eliminating any discrimination. Sexual preference is a declared ground of discrimination. In that situation, all the ILO can do is publish the representation and, where applicable, the fact of lack of a satisfactory reply by the state.

In this case the state is the nation of Australia. I note also concerns regarding privacy. We have had reports from individuals dismissed from the ADF who tell of fishing expeditions which make a mockery of the ADF homosexual policy directive that speaks of `the need for sympathy, understanding and discretion when dealing with the member'. But it does not provide, as the general policy on unacceptable sexual behaviour does, for dealing with false allegations. That is a major concern as well.

PARA.TAB: These are just some of the issues which are raised by the recent announcement of the Minister for Defence. I know those issues are of concern across the community. I know they are of concern to people in this place. I believe they are concerns which must be met. That concern is widespread. In the committee stage, as I say, I will be moving an amendment which specifically prohibits discrimination on the grounds of sexual preference in making appointments to the Defence Force, in the promotion or transfer of members of the Defence Force, in respect of the period of service of any member, or in the discharge of members from the Defence Force. I believe that this must be done since it is in the defence forces that we see the last vestiges of discrimination in our society on the grounds of sexual preference.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, you may recall that I had occasion to raise with you the difficulty we face in moving these amendments that have been circulated in our names. I believe the problem applies to the amendments to be moved by other parties as well to the extent that, while there is one issue, the clauses which are to be amended are distributed throughout the whole Bill. May I therefore respectfully suggest that we move amendments in a block, party by party, rather than in the sequence in which the clauses appear in the Bill, if that is acceptable?
—I think that is a good idea. Would you like to proceed, Senator Spindler?
—Before I move the amendments that have been circulated in my name, I suggest that Senator Powell should move the amendment she has circulated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 4, page 2, insert the following clause:

PARA.TAB: After section 32B of the Principal Act, the following section is inserted:

SPEECH.PARA: Discrimination on the grounds of sexual preference

PARA.TAB: There must be no discrimination on the grounds of sexual preference:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)in making appointments to the Defence Force under this Part;
(b)in the promotion or transfer of members of the Defence Force;
(c)in respect of any period of service of members of the Defence Force; or
(d)in the discharge of officers or soldiers from the Defence Force.".

The amendment, which seeks to add a new clause 4A, proposes to amend section 32B of the principal Act under the heading `Discrimination on the grounds of sexual preference' and, as I have outlined in my speech on the second reading, prohibits discrimination on the grounds of sexual preference in making appointments to the Defence Force, in promotion or transfer of members of the Defence Force, in respect of any period of service of members of the Defence Force or in the discharge of members from the Defence Force.

TALK.START.PARA: —To say the least, this is a fairly contentious issue which has now, of course, been introduced into this piece of legislation fortuitously because it was not considered a few days ago. Therefore, the vehicle is now available that otherwise would not have been.

PARA.TAB: Let me first of all say that the Government opposes this amendment absolutely because it is technically flawed. It would only affect the Army and not the other two Services because of the section of the Act that Senator Powell seeks to amend. That is not a criticism—I understand what happens when amendments are constructed on the run. This is a danger and I cannot criticise Senator Powell for that because on other occasions I have come back and amended a Bill that I have put through the previous session because of an inadvertent technical defect.

The section that Senator Powell seeks to introduce for the defence forces is one that has been considered by Ministers for some months. I think that at the first appropriate occasion I should take the opportunity to put on the record the true processes that occurred. In Senator Powell's press release, and in those of others, the impression has been given that the chiefs of staff have ganged up on Ministers and that the Ministers have caved in. The fact is that the Chiefs of Staff Committee considered for some months this whole paper, plus—as a subsidiary of that—the view on homosexuality. The options paper it put to Minister Bilney and me contained simply options. The Committee did not come down with a conclusive view, nor did it try to force its views on the Ministers.

If, as Senator Powell says, this policy is not a good one, I have to wear the responsibility—not the Chiefs of Staff Committee in any sense. It was a decision made by me, not at the Committee's insistence and not under pressure from it. That is the way it occurred. That is true ministerial responsibility. Sometimes ministerial responsibility is either apparent or vague. On this occasion it is absolutely apparent. This is a decision made by Gordon Bilney and me. I just take the opportunity to put that on the public record. I know that there was no deliberate intent to put that in some other way. I can understand how that interpretation may have come about, but it is not true. The decision was that of the Ministers.

In regard to that, the previous policy on the acceptability of homosexuals within the Defence Force did concentrate on the various areas read out by Senator Powell in her second reading speech. But in my statements here and elsewhere, I stressed that the key factor was in terms of the esprit de corps of the armed forces and their effectiveness. I did not go to those other issues that were there in the past in terms of security, health and other matters. They are not particularly relevant these days. I am not particularly concerned about the matter of health and the homosexual community in terms of service in the armed forces.

I am certainly not concerned about the security matter these days, because the world has moved a long way in the last 20 years. I had to say those two things. Whilst they were in the original policy, they were not permanent in our thinking. It was the cohesiveness and effectiveness of today's Defence Force that led Gordon Bilney, and especially me, to make that decision to leave the existing policy.

I am pleased that Senator Powell and others have recognised that the document produced by the Chiefs of Staff Committee on acceptable sexual behaviour, which covers areas such as harassment, et cetera, is good. I believe that it is. A lot of work and a lot of thought was put into it. The armed forces are not like every other section of the community. There are some differences. The first difference is a thing called rank. This is not a class rank, but rank exists within the armed forces. Rank implies obedience and respect. When we come to things like sexual relations, the two can get mixed up horribly and pressure can be put on, inadvertently or otherwise. The response to an overture or something else can be as much a response in respect of rank as it can be to an overture of a sexual nature.

There are far more intense training institutions that the armed forces use. That complicates this as an issue for the moment, but not forever. The housing policies of the Defence Force which force cohabitation can also compound this issue sometimes. But if one goes around to base after base, as I am certain even my friendly opponent, Senator Newman, would concede, one starts to see single occupancy of rooms rather than multiple occupancy. That is part of the new trend in the Defence Force. Where there were previously four students or four privates, almost inevitably they are heading towards having one student, apart from during the three-month recruiting period. Those sorts of housing arrangements will change some of the relationships in the Defence Force.

But some things will never change. Submarines will never change. There is a hot bunk arrangement: one person gets out and goes to work and another person dives straight into that bunk. There is not really much scope to complain about behaviour. If unacceptable behaviour occurs, the consequences on a submarine, for instance, can be absolutely horrendous.

I want to assure honourable senators, in case they are in any doubt, that Mr Bilney and I did not retain the existing attitude towards the role of homosexuals in the armed forces out of some redneck bigotry. I hope that is accepted, but if it is not I have to wear the consequence. It certainly is not an attitude resulting from our having any phobia towards homosexuals, et cetera. We also have to say that there are homosexuals in the Australian defence forces at the moment, but we do not encourage or authorise witch-hunts against those individuals. Probably all of them perform their tasks, adequately or otherwise.

The real problem is the reaction of the rest of those in the Force. That does not necessarily mean that it can be dismissed merely as redneckism or a machismo sort of behaviour. Everyone, at least until today, who signed up in the Defence Force did so under certain conditions. One of those conditions was that homosexuals were not eligible to serve; homosexual conduct, not so much preference or activity, was not allowable in the defence forces. To change the conditions absolutely, whilst those people are under return of service obligations, does not seem to me to be a useful process.

But it is an issue outside this chamber that will be argued to both extremes, and not rationally. It is one that will generate an emotive debate and, at times, a bigoted debate. I think that is a pity, but that has to be confronted. If people think the decision that Gordon Bilney and I made was the easy way out, I ask them to think it through fairly substantially. Of course we anticipated that the ABC would be giving us a pillorying every day; of course we anticipated that the Fairfax press would come out the way it has. So it was not the easy route or the easy way out for us to adopt the retention of this particular proposal.

I indicated in answer to a question that this issue may be challenged in the court or elsewhere. I have listened with interest to what Mr Burdekin and Senator Tate have said. I found it a little surprising that there would be so little room for appeal, because people do have appeal rights.

I do not intend to respond to Mr Burdekin; he has processes that he has to go through. He approaches his Minister with a report and, in turn, his Minister approaches me. I will not enter into a public slanging match with HREOC at this stage. What people have said, I will let them say; but I will not respond other than through the normal, formal processes.

As I have said, at this stage the Government will not accept Senator Powell's amendment. If I raised this matter with the 119 Labor Party Caucus members, I do not believe that everyone would agree with the decision of Gordon Bilney and me. I suppose this throws up other problems of process, which are never examined when the status quo is being endorsed. However, a new policy has to go through all those processes. A couple of my Party colleagues have indicated to me that they want to look at it as an issue—and that is their right. If they want to look at it as an issue and come back and put other arguments to me, I will not have a closed mind.

But at this stage I still have some fairly compelling reasons for not altering the existing policy. If we did alter the policy by acceptance of this amendment today, and if the House of Representatives were then minded to accept it, I believe we would severely affect the cohesiveness and the effectiveness of the way our defence forces are configured today. That belief comes from a lot of discussion. Honourable senators might assume that every time we go to a base we just go to the officers' mess and have a meal, and that is it. On at least half of the bases we visit we go to the other ranks' canteen. We always do a tour and stop to talk with the soldiers, the airmen and the seamen. Overwhelmingly, they would see a major problem if we were to alter the existing policy.

It came through very clearly to me in Kangaroo 92, as it did to every parliamentarian who visited the area during the exercise—from Pine Creek to Kununurra to Exmouth to bare base Curtin to Tindal to Darwin; no matter where we were, this was a universally raised question. Most people said, `We signed up under a certain set of conditions. How can you change those conditions?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The same thing happened at a Darwin seminar when an RSM put that view very clearly.

—As Senator Teague says, many of the RSMs have also put that point of view. It is not that RSMs particularly have one set of social values. They see it as their duty to represent those under them vocally. Because of the training and forcefulness that the RSMs seem to have, they know they can put their views positively on behalf of the rest of the soldiers or their equivalents in other services.

PARA.TAB: In summary, Senator Powell's amendment is flawed technically—that is not a criticism—in that it would apply only to the Army. The Government is not minded to accept it in what, unfortunately, will be a confined and narrow debate, although I am not backing off the guillotine one inch. Because the amendment has been introduced so late, people have not been able to contribute to it in this chamber even in the second reading arena. I know that a number would have come in to contribute to it had it been introduced earlier.

I assure the Committee that the decision by Minister Bilney and me is not based on any preconceived, moral judgments about individuals or preferences. If honourable senators want to go back to my record in immigration, they will find that many of my colleagues regarded me as being far too libertine in my treatment of homosexual reunion. At the time some senators on the other side made that point. We do base our sincere judgment on the premise that to move at this stage would affect the effectiveness and cohesiveness of the armed forces, and the esprit de corps that exists.

We do have a responsibility for pastoral care and to represent the defence forces as well as the rest of the community. We have done that, and we have done it to the best of our ability. We have come down on what has to be a fairly fine judgment to retain the existing bar. There will not be, as I have to say there has been in some stages, a grievous witch-hunt with military police spying through bedroom windows, et cetera. That is not the sort of culture that we will be involved in. If anyone in the armed forces thinks we are going to do that, that person should stand corrected immediately. On that point, the Government rejects this amendment today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am perfectly ready to attack the Government when the opportunity presents itself, but on this occasion I put on record my appreciation of the sensitive and thoughtful contribution of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) on the Australian Democrats amendment. I think it shows an understanding of the special and unique needs of the Defence Force, which are demonstrated to be lacking by the Democrats' even having to put up this amendment. As the Minister said, this issue is regarded very differently by different groups in the community. If ever there were a need for rational debate, it is on this subject. If ever there were a need to get rid of passion in debate, it certainly is in this area.

PARA.TAB: Some people call other people `homophobes'; some people are just as rude about people with another point of view. I do not have a passionate view on this issue. I have always taken the view that it is a matter which is very much central to the defence of our country and our capability to defend ourselves. Anything which will diminish our ability to effectively defend this country has to be scrutinised very carefully. As I said in my personal explanation earlier today, that is the position which I, on behalf of the Opposition, have taken since this matter first became public in February.

We have to look at this question totally, in the interest of the nation and our ability to defend our country. The first duty of the Government is to see that this country is properly defended. To that end, while the decision that has been taken is a ministerial one, as the Minister says, quite properly it clearly has been based on advice from the chiefs of staff. I say `properly' because this is a matter which goes to their ability to see that their troops can effectively defend the country. If we put people into such positions of authority and pre-eminence, we must be able to rely on their judgment in most things, and certainly in something as intrinsic as their ability to produce a force which can defend us. I would have been relying on the professional advice of the service chiefs, as the Minister has.

I also share the concern that we are talking about members of a community who work together, live in very close proximity to each other and fight in extremely close proximity to each other. There are often great difficulties with people who are frightened and need reassurance. Close friendships can and do develop in the Defence Force. There are a lot of very young people under the command of people older and more senior than them. Consideration of all these things is vital to the esprit de corps of the Force.

I am very disappointed—and I will be more outspoken than the Minister has been—about the Human Rights Commissioner. A few nights ago on the radio I heard him most passionately arguing the case for the so-called rights of the members of the Defence Force to practise as homosexuals in the Defence Force. Mr Burdekin, of all people, should know that Defence Force personnel sign away a lot of rights when they commit themselves to the service of this country.

There are ILO conventions that this Government regards as extremely important to the protection of workers. Those rights do not transfer to the members of the Defence Force, who can be compelled to work long hours—24 hours, if necessary, or longer if there is a demand. They are told where they can work and what they will work at. They are told whether they can live out of a Defence establishment or on base. They are directed to change jobs, often quite frequently and often in places where they would never choose to live if they had their way. They are totally unable to strike. They are unable to have unions. That is so for good and proper reasons. I am not arguing that any of these things should be changed. But service men and women know when they sign on in our defence forces that by doing so they are signing away, at least while they are in uniform, many of the rights which Australians regard as basic.

The sexual practice of men and women within the Defence Force, whether it is heterosexual or homosexual, is proscribed and subject to military discipline. That is so for good and proper reasons. Mr Burdekin should have known that. I am very offended that a man who might be in a position of having to judge these issues has come out as part of the political debate.

In the last week or so the British also completed a review of this whole question. While it has been widely reported that they have changed their policy, in fact, all they have done is decide that they will no longer charge people for homosexual offences under military law. They have reviewed their right to administratively discharge people for homosexual practices and they have retained it. I hope that the media, which have reported this inaccurately, will get it straight and put it on the public record.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is decriminalised, but they are still dismissed.

—Senator Teague is exactly right. It is most unsatisfactory that on such an important Bill, where conscription is really a major issue, the Democrats should take so much of the short time available to discuss another issue which is immaterial to this debate today. We have very little time to discuss something as important as conscription. At other times the Democrats would regard that as of prime importance. This is a diversion and an attempt to get sectional support wherever they can, as they so frequently do. The Opposition rejects the Democrats' amendment. It is nothing but an attention-getting exercise.

—I rise to express very briefly my sense of disappointment at the response of the Minister and the Opposition to this amendment. I am quite prepared to accept that in making his response the Minister put forward reasons of practicality rather than speaking out of any sense of false morality. On that basis, I believe that the Minister has done those men and women who work in our defence forces an injustice. I believe that we can have confidence that members of the Defence Force could deal with all aspects of the particular situations that the Minister has described. I feel a great sense of disappointment that we do not have the moral courage and the confidence in these people for them to act in a proper manner, to perform their duties in a proper manner and to cope with any difficulties that may arise.

—I am conscious of the time. For that reason, although it would have been my preference to do so, I will not call a division. I simply say that the views of the other parties in this chamber have been expressed. I express my disappointment at the Minister using as one of his reasons for no change at this time the same reason that my grandmother used against decimal coinage when it came in. She said that we must wait until all the old people die before we have any change. In terms of the way our society has evolved, especially in relation to anti-discrimination and equal opportunity legislation, to mount those arguments is antediluvian in the extreme and intellectually not really up to the usual standard of this Minister.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

8.Clause 9, pages 3 and 4, line 19 (page 3) to line 2 (page 4), clause to be opposed.
9.Clause 10, page 4, lines 3 to 11, clause to be opposed.

These amendments seek to do away with the term `conscription' wherever it occurs in the Bill. The intent is to simply delete the concept of conscription out of Australian defence legislation. While I am prepared to move these amendments on behalf of Senator Chamarette, because I believe that the principle is one that this chamber should take note of, I personally find myself unable to support them. Senator Chamarette put forward the reason that we must at all times attempt to move towards a position where this world lives in a peaceful state and where people should not be forced to do violence unto others. I believe that is a laudable objective. As a long-time member of the peace movement, I have worked towards that aim and will continue to do so.

PARA.TAB: However, where Australia, my home, can be attacked and is being attacked—and that is the only situation in which conscription can be used—the government of the day must have every opportunity to defend its citizens. If somebody tried to bash down my door in my home, I would take whatever action was necessary to defend my family.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government takes the view as espoused in its party platform. The Government has never been a consistent supporter of conscription, but if Australia were threatened we would certainly approve conscription, as we did in the Second World War. Like Senator Spindler, under direct attack, I am not a conscientious objector either.
—The Opposition will also be opposing Senator Chamarette's amendments for very similar reasons to those expressed by the Minister.

—As a person who was conscripted in 1966—the last time there was conscription in Australia—overall I welcome the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill to make the arrangements for conscientious objection much more appropriate for the modern day. It is an amendment to the Defence Act that many of us in the mid-1960s argued for. I congratulate the Government upon finally achieving something that many of us demonstrated for in 1966. Opposition members will be pleased to know that, although I was conscripted, I failed the medical.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 7, page 3, proposed subsection 60(4), line 10, omit ", but not more than 90 days before,".
2.Clause 7, page 3, proposed subsection 60(5), lines 12 and 13, omit ", within the period of 90 days before it is expressed to come into effect,".
3.Clause 9, page 3, paragraph (d), proposed paragraph 61A(1)(i), lines 30 to 32, omit the paragraph.
4.Clause 9, page 3, paragraph (e), proposed subsection 61A(1A), lines 38 and 39, omit "(either generally or during a particular war or particular warlike operations)".

I am particularly concerned about the proposal in the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill to allow selective conscientious objection. The view of the Opposition is that if one is a conscientious objector one is a conscientious objector on either religious or moral grounds which cannot be selectively applied to one conflict or another. We are talking about the defence of Australia; we are talking about apprehension of the invasion of our homeland. We do not believe that conscientious objection can be selective with somebody suffering from virtually a split personality.

PARA.TAB: If this country is to be invaded, surely Australian citizens have an obligation to contribute to the protection of the country. If they cannot defend their own country, they must be able to demonstrate—let us face it, conscientious objection means a long held view, a strongly held view—that it is not some fleeting whim of the moment.

Surely, it will be very difficult for anybody in Australia to demonstrate that they have a conscientious objection to defending their country. It makes it even harder, I should have thought, to demonstrate that they have a conscientious objection to defending their country in either this particular instance or in another. We find it utterly illogical and totally unsatisfactory, especially as there are provisions in the legislation for true conscientious objectors to provide an alternative to military service if this country is under attack.

We do not believe that there is a need to provide a separate category. People who are conscientious objectors to war, and are genuinely found to be so under the procedures laid down in this Act, can provide other service to their country. People who do not have a total objection to war surely should defend this country. We do not see any rationale for the provision. In fact, we fail to understand why the Government has seen a need to put it in. It is an extraordinary provision. Perhaps the Minister can explain why the Government has done so. To date, it has not been explained satisfactorily to the Opposition why a blanket conscientious objection is not enough. How can one have a selective opposition?

That the amendments (Senator Newman's) be agreed to.
