DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS AND TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1992SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1992SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE CHARGE BILL 1992SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 and 27 May, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of superannuation legislation introduces changes of fundamental significance for retirement incomes policy in Australia. It is worth recalling the genesis of the legislation. It is a direct response to the criticism by the Industrial Relations Commission of a number of aspects of award superannuation, particularly non-compliance, and the Government's refusal to accept the Commission's recommendations to convene a national conference on retirement incomes.

PARA.TAB: The Bills require employers to make progressive increases in the minimum level of employer support over the next 10 years so that by the year 2002, 9 per cent—and probably 12 per cent of wages—will be set aside for retirement income purposes. The coalition acknowledges the need for Australians to accept increasing responsibility for their own standards of living, both during their working years—by productivity-driven enterprise bargaining—and during their retirement years. For those who cannot or do not choose to save for their retirement, a safety net by way of the age pension must remain available.

There is now a significant body of demographic writing which has recently been endorsed by a House of Representatives committee suggesting that, at the very least, confident predictions about the cost to government of an ageing society 30 years down the track are fraught with danger. Nonetheless, the coalition accepts that the implications of the greying of the population cannot be dismissed or down-played simply because the probable impact is unlikely to be felt until well into the next century. It makes a great deal of sense, therefore, to address the issue now, but the approach we adopt is crucial.

Many of those who argue for compulsion do so from a narrow retirement incomes policy perspective rather than a national macro-economic approach. The key issues are affordability and capacity to pay. For countries like Singapore with growth rates of 8 per cent to 10 per cent over the past decade, it is possible to afford many elements of a comprehensive welfare state. For countries like Australia which have been going backwards in recent years, increasing levels of compulsion can only be paid for in two ways: either at the expense of jobs, if the full burden is borne by employers; or at the expense of wage increases, if workers are to bear the brunt as the Government claims they should. Either way, the outcome is very bad news for those struggling to make ends meet and for those policy-makers determined to get the country back on the track in order to provide people with rising standards of living and a greater capacity to earn and save for retirement. That is why we have undertaken to retain the floor which is in place at the time of the next election—probably 3 per cent to 4 per cent—and then to offer a range of generous tax incentives within certain contribution limits. With Australia still suffering from the greatest economic recession it has had in 60 years and with the level of unemployment over 10 per cent, the last thing which business needs is policies which undermine the capacity of employers to expand their enterprises and increase employment. Yet the Government's proposed superannuation guarantee charge regime will add at least an extra $2 billion a year to labour costs, irrespective of the state of the international or the domestic economy.

Even ardent advocates of compulsory superannuation, such as National Mutual, are concerned that the legislated contribution levels make no allowance for the capacity of various employers and industry to meet the requirements. The legislated approach assumes that everyone can pay higher rates at the same point in time. The impact on small business, where the great bulk of the burden will undoubtedly fall, is particularly severe. The Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce estimates that for an average award employee, total on-costs will rise from 31.5 per cent to 37 per cent of labour costs and even more for many staff not covered by awards.

Like the training guarantee levy, the SGL is a de facto payroll or employment tax imposed regardless of profitability, but, unlike the TGL, it offers no prospect of productivity improvements. Since the SGC is being imposed as a legislative obligation, there will not be any opportunity for employers to bargain any offsetting productivity increases with their work force. At a time of very weak demand, firms will have great difficulty in absorbing the costs or passing them on.

There can be little doubt that most Australians aspire to a higher level of retirement income than that enjoyed by the current generation. After eight years in office, the present Federal Government has finally managed to achieve an age pension equivalent to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. But the capacity to make significant future improvements will be critically affected by the health of the national economy.

Already more than three-quarters of persons of age pension age receive at least a part pension at a cost to revenue of approximately $12 billion a year. This amount will undoubtedly increase with the ageing of the population unless there are a number of significant structural changes, such as the gradual raising of the age pension age for women, the abolition of compulsory retirement ages and the easing of pensioner poverty traps.

The bottom line is that a country simply cannot achieve permanent increases in national savings and retirement incomes unless they are financed by faster economic growth, higher levels of productivity and rising levels of disposable income. These are not simply retirement incomes issues—they are national economic issues.

Two major arguments constantly advanced by the Government to justify a compulsory system are the need to boost national savings and the need to curb the rising cost of age pensions. There is undoubtedly an urgent need to boost national savings. Household savings have more than halved from a peak of about 15 per cent of disposable income in the mid 1970s to just over 6 per cent in 1990-91.

However, it by no means follows that forcing workers to go without wage increases will help the cause. As overseas experience has shown, unless there is rising output and productivity increases, compulsory savings in one form will simply lead to a run-down in savings elsewhere. Treasury is particularly conscious of this switching effect. The most that it claims in favour of the SGL is:

SPEECH.PARA: Higher superannuation savings would not be fully offset by reductions in other savings because many employees have equivalent levels of non-superannuation savings and superannuation savings are not a perfect substitute for other savings. . . . Some substitution . . . can be expected, however, . . . there is unlikely to be complete substitution. No estimate of the likely magnitude of this effect is available.

In other words, there is likely to be a very significant switching effect—not a perfect switch by any means, but a very high level of switching. Therefore, it cannot be said with any degree of confidence that there will be any particular level of increase in savings as a result of this regime. As Paddy McGuinness has cogently argued:

The weight of economic evidence is that imposing compulsory superannuation on individuals does not increase total savings. It simply causes people to save less of their residual income, their take home pay.
Or worse still, to go further into debt. Professor John Freebairn is right when he says:
The key to providing high income in retirement is the pursuit of policies promoting high economic growth.
Even prominent advocates of government intervention, such as Ray Block, who gave evidence to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation on behalf CEDA, admitted:
. . . we realise that the increase in national savings will only be marginal.

According to Peter Griffin, Managing Director of Rothschilds, a compulsory system is unlikely to increase national savings and will lead to lower returns to savers, as well as a big distortion in the allocation of investment capital and the workings of the capital market.

PARA.TAB: The key to national savings is to build a sound economy and provide incentives to save. A leading retirement incomes commentator, Daryl Dixon, told the Senate Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the key to increasing national savings is to give people incentive to save.
Professor Julian Disney, a member of EPAC, said:
. . . if one is concerned about national savings, it seems to me self-evident that the best way of encouraging savings is to provide a savings incentive for the widest range of purposes.

Therefore, the critical issue is national savings—that is, how much the country as a whole saves—not the savings of any particular group. The OECD's most resent comparison of savings patterns shows that Australia's national savings averaged 20 per cent of national income throughout the 1980s down from around 24 per cent in the 1960s and 1970s.

PARA.TAB: However, there is no evidence that the Government's superannuation initiatives have produced or will produce a large increase in national savings. Indeed, it is possible that the Government's initiatives are exacerbating a major shift in savings away from traditional retail financial institutions. This structural shift of savings will have profound and largely unforeseen consequences for the composition of investment flows. Compulsory superannuation would hasten the process by allowing major taxation concessions for compulsory superannuation. National savings may actually decline.

There are no short cuts to economic prosperity, nor is there any magic retirement incomes pudding, whereby increasing levels of retirement income can be forced on employees or encouraged by taxpayers, irrespective of capacity to pay. This is recognised by all the major institutions. National Mutual Life has urged the Government to deregulate the labour market, deregulate and privatise key areas of the economy, including transportation, communications and government business enterprises, and to direct the fiscal stimulus toward encouraging savings in long term private sector investment. The coalition supports, and indeed has made the running on, many of these vital national reforms.

With the nation experiencing a protracted economic crisis of Argentinean dimensions, more than ever it is vital to take a leaf out of the Japanese postwar rebuilding book and start to engender a national savings culture. This will not come about via a system of compulsory superannuation which pretends to put all the burden on employers. Inevitably, many employees will take the view that their superannuation needs are being taken care of by others and that there is no need for them to make any further provision for their retirement.

This lowest common denominator approach is quite the opposite of a savings culture. Indeed, once compulsory superannuation is firmly entrenched, it will not be long before politicians are being urged to take the view that tax concessions—currently around $3.5 billion and set to at least double by the turn of the century—could be better used elsewhere. Indeed, there are a number of senior Government figures who already take this view.

Perhaps the most damning indictment of the SGC proposals is their impact on employment. It is quite fatuous, and indeed disingenuous, to pretend—as the Government's principal spokesman on superannuation, Senator McMullan, did recently—that the levy will not be an additional cost. In the initial stages at least most employers would already pay out the required amount of superannuation.

This legislation does not tinker around the edges. It will involve substantial cost increases to provide superannuation cover for possibly 800,000 non-managerial, non-award private sector wage and salary earners, possibly 50,000 to 100,000 public sector employees currently lacking effective coverage, for example, due to poor vesting, and possibly 650,000 employees of non-complying employers, at least 600,000 of whom are in the private sector. These new recruits constitute 25 to 30 per cent of private sector employment and around 5 per cent in the public sector. Overwhelmingly, they are in small businesses. Some are young professionals who consciously prefer not to save via superannuation until much closer to retirement, but the great bulk are employees earning less than average weekly earnings. The fact is that many firms are not even paying the first 3 per cent of award superannuation.

Senator Cook, the Minister for Industrial Relations, has estimated that the outstanding amount is around $700m a year. The main reason, according to his own Department, is that most employers simply cannot afford to do so. As Treasury made clear in its evidence to the Committee, if the full unit cost impact is to be borne by employers, there will be up to 45,000 jobs lost over the next two years and up to 100,000 jobs lost over the next five years. The only way to avoid such an outcome is to discount wage increases for the effect of the SGC.

But this the Government steadfastly refuses to do. Instead, it piously promises that if Australia's inflation rate gets significantly out of line with those of our major trading partners, it will somehow depart from a specified legislated timetable for annual increases in contributions to the year 2002. In this regard, the following extract from the Committee's Hansard is most instructive:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston: Your submission states: `The effect on employers net savings will be influenced by the extent to which increases in employer superannuation contributions are taken into account in wage negotiations. If increases in contributions do not result in any change in employee's total remuneration—which you say elsewhere must include superannuation—employer's net savings positions should not change significantly.
In other words, the SGC will be at the expense of wage increases. That is what it is saying, is it not?
Dr Preston: It is saying that wage increases will be lower than they would otherwise have been.
Senator Alston: And if it does not involve any net increase in the cost burden to employers, it must be at the expense of wage increases, must it not?
Dr Preston: Yes.
Dr Preston is the Deputy Secretary to the Commonwealth Treasury.

PARA.TAB: The Government's refusal to give firm and specific commitments to discount wage increases contains the seed of an economic and social disaster waiting to happen. If Australia is to become truly competitive as quickly as possible, it must surely do everything at this stage to lower its export cost structure. Once the fruits of increased exports start to flow through, there will be a sound case for employees being entitled to share in the increased profits. But, to ignore actual costs and wait perhaps several years at least before making some subjective comparative judgments about international inflation rates will only ensure that our economic predicament will worsen.

In recent weeks the Government has claimed that the economy will be able to afford both the increased cost of the SGC and a wage claim well in excess of inflation, because of claimed unprecedented growth rates and productivity increases. These utterly unlikely and intuitively implausible predictions have been greeted with a great deal of scepticism on all sides and the recent downward revision of the expected 1992-93 growth rate from 4.75 per cent to 4 per cent by the Government's own economic adviser, the Joint Economic Forecasters Group, is simply official confirmation that these targets are absurdly optimistic.

Australian business is in no position to afford a multibillion dollar payroll tax, especially one which is scheduled in most cases to treble or even quadruple within eight years. Even if existing double dipping loopholes are closed, it would be of little consolation to taxpayers if a declining pension bill is more than offset by the rising costs of the national dole cheque. More importantly, however, the dangers to the social fabric of high and prolonged unemployment are already apparent worldwide.

TALK.START.PARA: —With unemployment levels on present policy certain to stay around 10 per cent for years to come, and even the Government claiming only a marginal improvement over the next few years, it would be little short of lunacy to introduce a massive new cost burden on employers—with unions saying only that the cost will be taken into account in further wage negotiations. History over the last decade offers no basis for any confidence that any reliance at all could be placed on such a vague and essentially meaningless formula.

PARA.TAB: Who pays? Unlike every other compulsory system in the world, the SGC legislation puts the burden entirely on employers, many of whom will be expected to find 12 per cent within 10 years. The Government's timetable ostensibly requires employers to pay 9 per cent by the year 2002, but it is clear that they will be expected to pay the last 3 per cent as well. The Government has said only that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it will give consideration to using employee contributions and tax cuts.

This `employer pays' approach will inevitably encourage many employees to take the view that superannuation is no longer their responsibility, thereby ensuring a lowest common denominator outcome for retirement incomes.

PARA.TAB: I turn to other wage and salary earners. If the Government persists in its pretence that the cost of the SGC will be funded by general reductions in wage increases, this clearly means that those already in receipt of the prescribed level of superannuation will be required to go without a wage rise to cross-subsidise those without superannuation coverage.

There are some real losers: part time and casual employees. Those who will do worst out of compulsory superannuation are part time and casual employees, more than two million of whom are women. Not only will they be effectively forced to forgo substantial wage rises, but also the amount set aside for them in the name of superannuation will be decimated by administration, insurance and taxation charges, leaving them with a small cash pittance and no retirement income. The retail industry, which is the largest employer of staff in the private sector, and is traditionally a major employer of part time and casual employees, has made it clear that the legislation will not only be administratively complex but also will lead to immediate job reductions, particularly in the depths of the current recession.

The Retailers Council of Australia is also concerned that to allow the levy to operate in conjunction with the existing award system will expose employers to a situation of double jeopardy, particularly because of the vast differences in award superannuation provisions compared with the standard levy requirement. This is particularly evident with the different qualifying periods, which vary between States but in most instances require a person to be employed for at least six months before payments are made, usually retrospectively. This contrasts with the SGC legislation, which will require payment for all part time and casual employees from day one, even though major retailers such as Woolworths have a staff turnover of 30 per cent a year. According to Coles-Myer, the country's largest private employer, with 135,000 employees, of whom 32 per cent are regular casuals under the age of 21:

SPEECH.PARA: Not only would there be a significant administration burden for both the company and funds if such employees are to receive employer funded occupational superannuation, but there would be no real gain for the individual in terms of retirement income.

As the SGC applies only to those in the paid work force, some two million non-working women are denied access to the alleged benefits, despite the fact that not only do they live longer than men but also they are particularly financially vulnerable in their retirement years in the event of early widowhood or divorce. The Fightback proposals explicitly address this and, unconstrained by industrial relations considerations and ACTU veto, we will certainly ensure that those who are in most need of superannuation access will have it.

PARA.TAB: From the time the Bills were introduced into Parliament on 2 April 1992, the Government has been insisting on a 1 July 1992 start-up date. This is despite the fact that there has been no clamour for such a date from any organisation except the ACTU. On the contrary, a wide range of community groups and organisations have repeatedly requested the Government to at least defer the legislation and convene a national conference to be attended by all interested parties in order to develop a long term, viable and effective retirement incomes policy for Australia. The coalition would welcome such an initiative and would be keen to play an active and constructive role in any such discussions.

Not one witness before the Committee seriously sought to justify the indecent haste of a 1 July start-up date. According to Brian Scullin, even ASFA, which generally supports the thrust of the legislation, told the Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there remains in our view a number of significant defects in the legislation and ten of these are in the paper that I have tabled today. . . As none of these have yet been addressed by the Government and businesses throughout the country are complaining about the impossibility of meeting such a tight deadline the Government has no option but to defer the legislation.

It is plain, therefore, that the only explanation for the Government's obsession is its anxiety to have its accord deal with the ACTU in place well before the next election. Such a justification is almost a perversion of the democratic process. When the country is crying out for a sensible long term approach to retirement incomes policy, the Government seems determined to honour a back room deal irrespective of the consequences and in defiance of overwhelming community opposition. The irony is that once the workers of Australia become aware that they are, at least in theory, expected to forgo wage rises and accept lower standards of living in order to disqualify themselves from the age pension, they will be most unlikely to show any gratitude to this Government at the ballot box.

PARA.TAB: One cannot help but agree with the Business Council, which urged the Government prior to the last Budget to postpone its plans to legislate for superannuation until agreement is reached by employers, unions and the Government as to the future direction of superannuation and retirement incomes policy. It has consistently stressed the need for a: . . . comprehensive approach to retirement incomes based on outcomes rather than contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: The small business sector will be particularly affected by the legislation as the bulk of non-compliance is in this area and most of this comes about through inability rather than unwillingness to pay, compounded by genuine uncertainties about the appropriate fund. One of the best summaries of all the objections to the current legislation was enunciated by Mr Willis on behalf of the MTIA. He stated:

First, that the timing of 1 July 1992 will impose an unsustainable cost burden on industry, unavoidably resulting in further business closures and job losses. Given the protracted and the severe recession being experienced and the urgent need to lift business investment to improve both competitiveness and employment opportunities, this new employment tax is totally unjustified; second, that the arbitrary timetable for future contribution increases may also be prejudicial to future economic growth later in the 1990s; third, that the form of the Bill is unnecessarily complex and costly to administer; fourth, that another tier of legal compliance for superannuation will compound the problem of excessive regulations rather than contributing to necessary simplification; fifth, that the many uncertainties of the proposal, including the extent to which consequential cost increases are to be offset against future wage claims, may cause significant industrial disputation; sixth, that there is no firm provision for direct employee contributions and seventh, that the exemption and thresholds are unrealistically low and will result in a substantial number of costly but ineffectual benefits.
As far as consultation is concerned, again the evidence to the Committee speaks for itself. Mr Emery, the Under Treasurer of the South Australian Treasury, said:
. . . our Premier wrote on behalf of all Premiers requesting Treasury and other consultation before the legislation was introduced and that request was simply declined.
Ms Jane Elix, Director of the Federation of Consumer Organisations, said:
The Government has undertaken no consultation with the community at large and absolutely minimal consultation with the organised community sector.
Ms Eva Cox of the Womens' Economic Think Tank said:

. . . this is a deal between the Government and the ACTU about something which has got very little to do with retirement income and much more to do with the politics of the union movement and the Government.

The Bills will pose substantial administrative difficulties for employers, many of whom are likely to find that they have unintentionally failed to comply with its strict requirements and have thereby incurred an SGL shortfall. In many instances, a significant increase in contributions will be involved simply by virtue of updating current award contributions.

PARA.TAB: For example, many awards currently specify a fixed contribution of 3 per cent of the appropriate wage when the award was granted—which may be as long ago as 1986. Thus even 3 per cent of the current wage would effectively require an additional 2 to 3 per cent payment. Many industrial awards require superannuation contributions to be paid into particular funds. As a result, many employers face considerable administrative difficulties and increased expenses by being required to pay into a multiplicity of industry funds nominated by separate awards which do not allow employers and employees to develop their own superannuation arrangements.

The levy regime perpetuates the continuing lack of freedom for employees to choose their preferred superannuation fund. This is graphically illustrated in Queensland where the retail award allows for employee choice and, as a result, an overwhelming number of staff choose to use the company fund instead of REST, the industry fund. The coalition's Fightback proposals address this obvious unfairness and will provide those employees with the flexibility that they ought to be entitled to but which this legislation denies them.

Whilst it purports to allow contributions to be made to `any complying fund', it will not excuse failure to comply with award obligations. Indeed, Treasurer Dawkins has made it clear that the Government will support ACTU attempts to vary award provisions so as to absorb the increases in compulsory employer contributions. As Treasury recently admitted to the Senate Committee, once a compulsory system is in place there is no economic or financial justification for the retention of an award-based system.

The SGL legislation does not require any levels of contribution for self-employed persons—yet another anomaly. If it is so important to insist that the employed work force should be required to accept a compulsory regime, there is no good reason why the self-employed should be exempt, particularly as some of the Government's most generous concessions are directed towards them.

The whole thrust of the legislation is to force private sector employers to fully fund ever increasing amounts of superannuation. It therefore makes no sense at all that public sector schemes with current accumulated liabilities of between $80 to $100 billion are to be excused from the discipline of funded arrangements.

The SGL goes to the heart of the debate about superannuation in this country. It is an accord solution to an industrial relations problem. It does nothing to address the fundamental complexities and inequities of the present system, but merely seeks to force an unaffordable timetable on top of the current unfair and inefficient award based system. Insistence on industrial relations solutions to retirement income problems has led to award superannuation which, after six years of massive non-compliance, has failed so badly that the Government now finds it necessary to resort to a compulsory system.

But superannuation arrangements remain fatally flawed in a number of respects. In almost every instance this is because the ACTU has vetoed sensible changes which have long been advocated by serious commentators and superannuation industry analysts—for example: closing off double dipping; raising the preservation age; restricting access to lump sum payments; gradually aligning the age pension age for men and women; encouraging employees to contribute to the cost of funding their own retirement; allowing part time and casual employees to have access to low cost superannuation arrangements outside the award system; abolishing compulsory retirement ages; providing deferred pensions; and allowing women outside the paid work force to contribute to superannuation schemes.

The coalition's Fightback package has bitten all of these bullets but, because of ACTU and government intransigence, instead of a rational retirement incomes policy Australia is now to be saddled with the worst of all worlds: an industrial relations based early retirement scheme totally unrelated to capacity to pay and funded entirely by employers via a multi-billion dollar payroll tax, which is likely to cost many thousands of jobs and run the very real risk of reigniting inflation over the next decade.

For those concerned to alleviate Australia's current savings problem and future age pension cost problems, these Bills are not the way to go. The answers to our economic problems do not lie in compulsion or conscription, but rather in a concerted, voluntary national effort whereby all Australians will reap the rewards of their own honest endeavours both during their working lives and in their retirement. As in many areas of human endeavour, it is no substitute to leave it all to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The four pieces of legislation the Senate is considering tonight—the Superannuation Legislation (Consequential Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill 1992, the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992, the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill 1992 and the Superannuation Guarantee (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992—represent one of the most fundamental and important reforms to social security in the nine years of this Labor Government. It ranks alongside the reforms and introduction of Medicare as the most important social security change of this Government and certainly ranks amongst the most important social security changes ever made by a Commonwealth Government in the last 90 years.

PARA.TAB: Up until the last 10 years, retirement incomes have primarily been based on a pension, which now currently stands at some 26 per cent of average weekly earnings, or on what is known as private sector superannuation. Up until 1983, private sector superannuation was largely the preserve of those who were highly paid—a minority of the work force who enjoyed very substantial and lucrative tax concessions which were varied by this Government in 1986.

I intend to deal with the following areas of policy relating to these pieces of legislation: first, why should we act now; second, the economic impact of the legislation; third, the likely retirement benefits; fourth, the impact on Budget figures; fifth, the employment and inflation implications of the legislation; sixth, the interaction of the legislation and social security benefits, that is, the existing pension; seventh, the attitude of State governments; eighth, some other arguments against this legislation; and, finally, the alternative vision that those opposite are offering.

These pieces of legislation are very long term in their effect. They will not come into full effect for 30 to 40 years. In that sense, they are unique because it is very rare for politicians in this country to look beyond the next election, let alone beyond the next 10 elections. It is to the credit of this Government and, indeed, particularly to the credit of the present Prime Minister, Paul Keating, who, while he was Treasurer, first enacted the major changes in pension superannuation retirement incomes in this country. For the last 80 years this issue has been debated time and time again, yet precious little reform had occurred until the present Prime Minister took the initiative with some long term policy and some long term vision about the future of retirement incomes in this country.

Why should we act now? We face an ageing population. While it is true that the dependency ratio will not change a great deal over the next 20 years, it is true that there is a marked shift in the dependency ratio from persons under the age of 14 to persons over the age of 65. It costs two and a half times the economic resources to support someone over the age of 65 as compared with someone under the age of 14. What is more, even though the number of young persons is declining, it is extremely difficult to shift resources away from young persons—the education sector—towards the elderly. If we are to prosper and to advance as a nation, we need to increase our resources on young persons in the area of education. It is not simply a matter of shifting resources away. We need to increase our resources on both our young and our elderly.

In terms of an ageing population, we currently have some 11 per cent of the population over the age of 65. By the year 2030 that will have doubled to just over 21 per cent. As for superannuation overseas, it was very clear from the evidence that was presented to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, of which I was Chair, that overwhelmingly the overseas experience has been to adopt levels of compulsion that are in fact generally much higher than is being proposed in this legislation. If we look down the list of 24 overseas countries that were surveyed by the Senate Committee on Superannuation, all but two of them provide for very significant levels of compulsory retirement contribution benefits. Indeed, the employer contributions average in all of those countries is some 13.7 per cent; employee contributions average 9.95 per cent.

New Zealand, like Australia, has not provided for its elderly and has not put aside significant levels of money—in fact, none at all. In New Zealand last year the new National Party Government, faced with severe budgetary restrictions, attempted to reduce the old age pension. There is a lesson in that for this country if we do not attempt to save adequate levels of retirement income.

Our report investigated and received hundreds of submissions on the issue of the levels of contributions required. Without almost any contradictory submissions, overwhelmingly it was put to our Committee that levels of contributions in the order of 12 per cent to 15 per cent are required. The Institute of Actuaries of Australia, the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia, AMP, Mercer, Campbell, Cook and Knight, the ACTU, even the business organisations, whilst they might disagree with the timing and with who pays, submitted overwhelmingly that we should be contributing levels of 12 to 15 per cent.

With regard to the issue of compulsion versus voluntarism, again from the evidence that was gathered before the Committee in the last year, not just at the hearings that were held on this legislation, the overwhelming evidence was for compulsion. Indeed, at the present time we have a tax system that pays for a pension system. That is based on compulsion. People will simply not—the overseas experience shows this—voluntarily save adequate levels of income for their pension retirement. That is the theory that is being advanced by those opposite. If that is the theory, why were more Australians not saving for their superannuation prior to 1983 when we had one of the lowest tax regimes and the most favourable tax treatment—less than 5 per cent? Why were they not saving then? The simple answer is that voluntarism does not work.

The other important theme behind this legislation is the compliance levels with the current superannuation provisions. The Department of Industrial Relations submitted evidence to the Committee—and it was the only reliable survey that was carried out—which showed that some 14 per cent of the work force in this country are currently missing out on their legal entitlements, their 3 per cent. There were a variety of reasons advanced for that. That is a very important principle. There are many employers—not all of them but many—who are simply ignoring their legal obligations. One of the important elements of this legislation is to ensure that the legal obligations are being met.

The next issue I wish to consider is the economic impact of this legislation. The Treasury estimated that there would be a 2 per cent increase in our national savings in the next 15 years, and that by the year 2020 there would be a 2.5 per cent increase. Similarly, independent economists Fitzgerald and Harper submitted that there would be a 3 per cent increase in national savings in the Australian economy over the next 10 years. They submitted that Treasury estimates were initially very conservative.

Senator Alston advanced an argument about Singapore, which has a compulsory contribution level of 40 per cent. He said that we cannot afford to do what Singapore has done or go anywhere near what Singapore has done. Yet Singapore started 30 years ago, back in the 1950s. Its level of investment, its employment levels and its economy were basically underdeveloped. I would submit that the 40 per cent contribution level is in fact one of the dynamic factors behind the growth of the Singapore economy.

In terms of the retirement benefits that will come out of the superannuation guarantee levy, the Treasury put forward the projection that, after 40 years and with real levels of return at 4 per cent, which is a fairly conservative estimate, a person on half average weekly earnings, about $16,000 a year, would receive a pension that is 31 per cent greater than the current old age pension; a person on three-quarters of average weekly earnings would receive a pension some 17 per cent greater than the current old age pension; and a person on average weekly earnings, currently just over $30,000 a year, would receive a pension 17 per cent greater than the current old age pension. A person on 1 1/2 times average weekly earnings would also receive an improvement on his or her old age pension. Those figures are not contested.

Initially, there will be a net cost to the Budget because of these reforms in terms of the tax deductions if the current tax regime remains in place. By the year 1999, there will be a net loss to the Budget of $1,100m. By the year 2009, some 20 years hence, there will be a net loss of $887m. By the year 2019 there will be a net gain to the Budget of $33m—in current dollar terms—and by the year 2029 there will be a net gain to the Budget of $1,100m. In 40 years time, when we are all dead and gone, or have certainly all left this place, the proposals that we are passing tonight will save very significant levels of expenditure in the Budgets. As I said earlier, it is extremely rare for any government to look that far forward.

In terms of the employment and inflation impact, much has been said about these issues, and much of it, frankly, has been nonsense.It is estimated that the total cost of these proposals to the economy will be 3 to 4 per cent over the next decade. Again that figure has not been refuted. It is 3 to 4 per cent—not 9 per cent, as some people seem to believe and claim. At the present time, we already have a floor of 3 per cent for the overwhelming majority of people. In many cases, those luckier persons in the work force enjoy levels much greater than 3, 4 or even 5 per cent. So, with the phase-in of this proposal to 9 per cent over the next decade, those persons who enjoy significantly better than 3 per cent will be absorbed within that 9 per cent until we get to the 9 per cent levels. That is why the cost is 3 to 4 per cent, spread across the total economy. That figure has not been refuted.

In the first year of this proposal—this was before the recent changes that the Government accepted—Treasury estimated that the likely cost would be between 1.5 and 2 per cent on inflation. That is going to be a high figure, given the recent changes that were announced. It will have an inflationary impact of no greater than about 1.5 to 1.7 per cent.

Much nonsense has been spoken about employment. These increases of 3 to 4 per cent over the next decade, which is a very responsible timetable, will be offset against future wage productivity increases. The Opposition claims that if they are not offset there will be a massive increase in unemployment. That is true. If they were not offset there would be an increase in unemployment. But the ACTU has committed itself—and the Government has gone one step further and said that it will legislate in the Industrial Relations Act—to ensure that the 3 to 4 per cent cost impact will be taken into account. So there will be no increase in unemployment as a result of this legislation; there will be none at all. This is a good time to be introducing this legislation. It is a time of low inflation; it is a time when the economic indicators show that we are coming out of a recession, when the productivity growth in the economy will be at its most significant.

In evidence presented to our Committee on this issue, it was submitted that real unit labour costs have increased in the last two years due to the recession, but they will fall with recovery and increased capacity utilisation. That is happening at the present time. Industry has been restructuring. It has spare capacity so that during this recovery there will be an increase in productivity, unit costs will fall and profits will rise. That is what is happening in the economy at the current time. Most of the overseas countries that we surveyed were taking a far-sighted view. They were introducing this type of measure in the 1930s and the 1940s when the economic conditions in those countries were far worse than they are in Australia today.

Of course, the truth of the matter for those that argue against this proposal is that no time is a good time. It does not matter how good the times are, business will never face up to a responsibility to have to pay. But it is not simply a matter of business paying or employees paying out of future wage increases; if we want a decent level of pensions, the community as a whole has to pay the cost of an adequate level of pensions and retirement income.

As part of this proposal, pensions can be maintained and strengthened. I referred earlier to the tragic situation that New Zealand faces; it is an area with public policy prescriptions that those opposite like to cite and want to adopt in all sorts of government policy areas. The truth of the matter is that, if we do not adopt this policy, if we do not start reducing the impact of pension costs on our budget over the next 20 to 30 years, it will be impossible to maintain the current old age pension.

The next issue I would like to turn to is the role of State governments in this debate. They, like business, have been strongly opposing the proposals before us tonight in a most reprehensible way. The cost of this increase will be taken into account in terms of public sector wage rises. So it will not have the financial impact that State governments claim. But State governments have gone two steps further, and most perversely, in their arguments. Current State government schemes are grossly inequitable.

We carried out a survey of State public sector funds. Only four States responded. I do not know what happened to the others. If this issue is so important, one would have thought they would have bothered to respond to surveys on the matter. In South Australia, only 30 per cent of public sector employees are in the very generous public sector fund, which in effect has contribution levels of 15 per cent, while 70 per cent of public sector employees are in the 3 per cent fund. There are two classes of public sector employees in South Australia. The 30 per cent are very well off with notional contribution levels—because these levels are not funded—of 15 per cent.

In Western Australia, the figure is worse. In that State, 30 per cent of public sector workers are in the public sector fund, 60 per cent in the 3 per cent fund, and the remaining 10 per cent of public sector employees in no fund at all. In Queensland—I pay some tribute to Queensland as it is the only fully funded public sector fund in the country—one half is in the public sector fund and the other half is in the 3 per cent fund. In New South Wales, 72 per cent of public sector employees are in the much more generous public sector fund while only 28 per cent are in the 3 per cent fund.

This is the sort of inequity that the superannuation guarantee charge is designed to cure. I find it appalling that we should have some Labor State governments arguing against this proposal. The State governments have been involved in one other appalling display of behaviour over the past few years. They have been quite busily converting from pensions to lump sums and indirectly have been encouraging the practice of double dipping. They have been encouraging public servants to take lump sum payments, to spend them in part, and then to convert them to a part pension, which is a cost to Commonwealth revenue. We have an appalling approach by State governments to this issue.

Some of the other arguments that have been advanced against this legislation include an allegation—which is false—that the Government has not been addressing some big picture items. There were a range of submissions put before the Committee in the past year from a number of organisations, including ACOSS, the Womens Electoral Lobby, and the Federation of Consumer Organisations, about other issues such as prudential and safety matters; reform of the iniquitous tax concessions on superannuation; the preservation age; and the allegedly high administration costs, which, frankly, I think is a side issue. Those sorts of issues also need to be taken care of. It is certainly right that they do need to be taken care of.

This Government has adopted in record time—12 days—many of the recommendations on prudential issues made by the Senate Select Committee. The Government will hand down its tax reform package on superannuation in the next month. It will deal with the preservation issue. As I have indicated, I do not accept that administration costs were a real issue, but if they were a real issue the reforms that have been indicated in the amendment will take care of any problems.

Let us deal with this administration costs issue. It is being used by the Opposition very frequently in the debate. If we look at the old cut-off point of $250 a month, a 3 per cent contribution would give a total of $90 a year, which does not take out administration costs. If that is increased to 12 per cent by the year 2002, as is proposed, that level of contribution rises to $360 a year. Given the Government's amendment, if it is $450 a month, a yearly contribution of $162 at 3 per cent would rise to $648 in the year 2002. We surveyed the administration charges made by most of the major funds. They averaged between 60c and $1 a week. The argument that the administration costs eat away at the contributions is not a real argument; it is a false argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here's one.

—Senator Panizza waves around an example. I bet that it is an example from one of the funds where there are high fees and charges which, perversely, given the coalition's argument about freedom of choice, it wants to impose upon people in the community. I will say a little more about that later.

PARA.TAB: This Government is moving towards reforming the big picture items. Superannuation is a complex issue. It has been ignored for 80 years by all other governments. No-one could seriously expect to bring in one piece of legislation to totally reform every aspect of superannuation overnight. What this Government has done in the past eight or nine years, and what it will be doing over the next year, is transform and put into place a total superannuation picture.

The arguments advanced by some of the consumer organisations and the women's organisations that persons should get a pay rise instead of superannuation do have some superficial attraction, but for persons to receive a pay rise in lieu of superannuation is not a real option and it never has been. The constitutional power to carry that out does not exist, nor do the political opportunities, except in indirect ways, with the Federal Government providing some direct targeting of persons on lesser incomes through the social security system or through some form of flat wage increase. All the big picture issues are being faced up to.

What is the alternative vision that the Opposition is proposing? Senator Alston, on behalf of the Opposition, refuses to believe there is a problem. There is a fundamental difference between us and those opposite. Senator Alston prefers to believe that there is not a great problem facing us. When we tabled our report on Thursday, 18 June, Senator Alston said:

SPEECH.PARA: The pace of technological change is ever-accelerating. Who knows? It could be anything from euthanasia to dramatic reforms in bio-technology.
That is Senator Alston's proposed vision. He went on to say:

I am saying that there will be so many technological changes in bio-technology that we may well find that the cost of maintaining the elderly is actually a great deal cheaper than it is today. We talked about how the abolition of compulsory retirement ages would also ease the burden quite dramatically.

That is some sort of vision that Senator Alston, on behalf of the Opposition, offers this country! He is basically saying, `Let's ignore the problem. Let's not do what every other major OECD country has done'—except New Zealand; and we know what has happened in New Zealand—`Let's simply ignore the problem. But if we do have a problem, we can rely on some theoretical biotechnological changes. If that doesn't work, we can rely on euthanasia'. It is a fascinating prospect that the Opposition offers for the elderly in this country.

PARA.TAB: The other part of the vision the Opposition offers is freedom of choice. We regularly hear this notion of freedom of choice from those opposite. They are proposing that employers and employees should be able to direct their moneys into whatever fund takes their fancy. What is the reality of the outcome if that occurs? The moneys will be directed away from the larger industry and employer funds that currently exist, which have enormous economies of scale, and, as I indicated earlier in this debate, administration charges of between 60c and $1 a week. Superannuation investment will be in the hands of agents, who in many cases have been charging iniquitous and enormous fees and commissions. That is what the Opposition wants to do. It perversely, under the argument of freedom of choice, wants to allow agents' fees and commissions to eat into the superannuation levels. We will not have a bar of that.

In terms of the Opposition's philosophical approach, it is presenting voluntarism to us: people will go away and voluntarily save 10 to 12 per cent of their income and, whoopee, they will have an old age pension. That is what the Opposition is arguing for. We know it will not work. I prophesy that if those opposite unfortunately win the next election, they will change their policy after the election and they will not reverse what we are putting in place. Every major country except New Zealand has relied on compulsion and levels of at least 12 to 15 per cent. Voluntarism does not work.

What is the reality of the Opposition's policy? The reality of the Opposition's policy is that in 30 to 40 years time, based on contribution levels of 5 per cent, it will effectively halve people's pensions. That is the Opposition's policy going into the next election—to halve pension payments. That will be the outcome.

While we are talking about truth and honesty, let us look at the seven taxes that the Opposition says it will abolish in its Fightback package. I refer to the so-called abolition of the superannuation tax. But the Opposition does not tell people that it will whack another superannuation tax on superannuation investment income, which brings in the same amount of revenue as the tax that it said it would abolish.

Let us be honest about the issue of retirement incomes. This legislation is visionary legislation. It is designed for 30 to 40 years down the track. I am proud of a government that can look that far ahead. When I leave this place—when most of those opposite will already have left and gone to some other place—and look back in 40 years time to this week in Parliament, I will recall that this was a time that we faced up to some long term problems that are confronting this nation. This is a week when we will be passing one of the most significant social reforms in this country's history. It ranks alongside Medicare as one of the most significant reforms. It is a reform based on vision, a long term plan and it is put forward by a visionary leader, Paul Keating, in our One Nation statement. It is a reform that will deliver improvements in investment income; it will deliver improvements in investment and employment; and it will deliver decent pensions for old age persons. That is why this legislation should be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with many things that Senator Sherry said. We are debating truly historic legislation this evening and we are going to do a rare thing; we are going to introduce a long term strategy to address a long term reality. That long term reality is that Australia is facing a demographic imperative, which will, if ignored, lead to a dramatic decline in the retirement living standards of Australians.

PARA.TAB: Today approximately 78 per cent of retired Australians receive an age or service pension. This costs about 3 per cent of GDP. The pension is currently set at 26 per cent of average weekly earnings. I think most of us would like to see that increased. Over the long term this legislation will provide much higher levels of retirement income for those on low and average earnings. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which was included in the report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation inquiring into this legislation.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. We are also in a period when the average age of the population is increasing for all sorts of obvious reasons. That means that by about the year 2020 we will experience dramatic increases in the proportion of the population which is receiving social security. The so-called dependency ratio—that is, the ratio of social security recipients to the working population—will also increase dramatically. If we just ignore the problem, if we continue to ignore the marked failure of Australians to save for what I believe is a combination of political and cultural reasons, if we continue to ignore the failure of 90 years of voluntarism, which is what the Opposition is proposing—it is saying, `Let's wait another 10 years and we'll see whether voluntarism really works because we've got some magic solution'—and wait another 10 years, we are facing a disastrous choice. Even if we take the optimistic projections of the recent report by Barry Jones's House of Representatives Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies, we will be facing an increase in costs of approximately 2 1/2 per cent of GDP to support our retired population. I say to Senator Panizza that the cost will be nearly doubled.

PARA.TAB: It does not sound like much money to some people until we put it into current values. In current values, this represents an extra $10 billion in taxation that we have to find. That is $10 billion, or perhaps an increase in personal income tax of 20 per cent for every single taxpayer. Or we could opt for the much less fair option of the abolition of the wholesale sales tax and the introduction of the GST, without any compensation or income tax reductions. This extra revenue would simply be needed to maintain—not to increase—what I consider to be an inadequate pension.

Given the electoral unpalatability for most governments, of whatever persuasion, of increasing taxation at all—even to create employment during a recession—it is ridiculous and naive to assert that future administrations and, indeed, the working population of Australia will agree to such a dramatic increase in taxation simply to maintain the present level of age pension. Put bluntly, the opportunism of the political system will ensure that such changes do not happen. We all understand why. It means that the living standards of retirees without superannuation or other savings will fall. We will go back to the days when we saw those graphic pictures of pensioners being forced to eat dog food.

That is the context within which this legislation must be considered. That is the way the Australian Democrats have approached this problem. I wish to put on record the fact that this package of legislation is not our preferred option; we have always preferred a truly national, portable superannuation model. This would involve the centralisation of administration and the formal integration of the pension system and the superannuation system. In effect, people would purchase an additional pension on top of the basic age pension.

We think that this would have a large number of benefits over the privatised model we are debating. We think it would totally and permanently simplify the superannuation system. Employers and employees would have to deal with only one administration agency. The proportion of members' funds spent on administration costs—something Senator Panizza has suddenly discovered is of concern—fees and commissions would be dramatically lower than the $500m which is currently expended. We think this would free up much needed capital for use in more productive areas and would increase the returns derived by members. We see this as a classic win-win situation, but the reality is that nobody agrees with us. The question of solvency of such a fund would not arise and the massive reserves necessary under the Life Insurance Act would not be necessary as a government guarantee would operate. This is the kind of system which most OECD countries have adopted, and which is highly supported in these countries. Instead, the Democrats have to choose between a government system based on compulsion and an Opposition system based on voluntarism.

It is very interesting to look at the history of attempts to impose national superannuation on this country. It is a sorry history and one that is not very well understood. I refer all honourable senators, especially Opposition senators, to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, entitled Income Support for the Retired and the Aged: An Agenda for Reform. During the 1890s—100 years ago—both the New South Wales and Victorian governments extensively investigated compulsory superannuation after Bismarck, of all people, introduced his revolutionary scheme in Germany in 1889.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly worked in Germany!

—As Senator Kemp can see, compulsion is not something dreamed up by this Government; governments of Senator Kemp's persuasion have flirted and attempted to impose it as well. In 1905 the Commonwealth established a royal commission into old age pensions which rejected the German model and, instead, recommended the current age pension. However, just a few years later, many again started thinking of a national superannuation system. At least one of the reasons was that the German system was widely believed to have contributed to improved industrial efficiency of the German economy, a point which Senator Kemp seems to have missed.

PARA.TAB: By the beginning of the First World War 14 nations, including the major European countries, had a national superannuation system. Between 1913 and 1939 three unsuccessful attempts were made to introduce a compulsory system of contributory national superannuation in Australia. These were all by non-Labor parties and they all failed.

Indeed, the failure of the 1938 legislation has some strange parallels with last year's leadership struggle. The pretender at the time, Mr Menzies, was a supporter of the 1938 legislation, which was passed by the Parliament but was never commenced because of the opposition of the financial establishments of the time. Eventually, Mr Menzies replaced Mr Lyons and then promptly forgot about his commitment to national superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a pity you weren't there to remind him.

—I am here to remind Mr Keating. Mr Keating used the superannuation proposal before us today as a key element in his ascension to the prime ministership but, unlike Mr Menzies, his Government is at least pressing ahead with the measure. In 1943 the national welfare fund was established by the Curtin Government. This was to be the basis of a comprehensive system of welfare, something along the lines of the present excellent system which operates in Singapore. As a separate tax, the social services contribution was introduced in 1945 to fund the benefits to be paid from the national welfare fund. This tax was absorbed into general income tax in 1950, and from 1952 the national welfare fund was funded purely from Consolidated Revenue until it was abolished in 1985. Then the Whitlam Administration commissioned the Hancock National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry, which delivered an excellent report which was shelved and then rejected by the Fraser Government.

PARA.TAB: So we have had this issue on the agenda for a hundred years and it has been put in the too-hard basket every time. We have come to the situation tonight where we are going to make a decision. We have heard the predictable assertions from the competing vested interests—business saying it cannot afford the rise in these current economic conditions, particularly the 3 per cent to 5 per cent rise; the ACTU saying that workers are owed this industrial gain as part of an adequate retirement incomes policy and as part of a wages trade-off.

The Democrats, by virtue of their balance of power, have had to assess the proposals and weigh up what we believe to be in the best interests of 90 per cent of the employees of this nation. It was the Democrats who moved to have the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation established. The Committee has examined the legislation in detail. It has sought the views of a very diverse cross-section of the community, including foremost experts in the fields of superannuation, industrial relations and retirement incomes. In coming to our position of support for this legislation, we have exhaustively covered every option and every possible variation.

Overwhelmingly—and this has always been our starting point—the evidence to the Committee has supported a compulsory levy. We have the overseas evidence where every major comparable country has a compulsory system of some sort. We have the evidence of the various accounting bodies; the evidence of actuaries; the expert evidence of Professor David Knox, who was advising the Opposition in the superannuation area; and the evidence of the study by Harper and Fitzgerald, which shows that a voluntary system will not deliver the claimed benefits, especially given the taxation proposals in the Fightback package.

In addition, we have a trade union movement which has accepted, and which will be legally bound to accept as a result of amendments, that this superannuation charge will be taken into account when negotiating future wage increases. We believe that is a major bonus to the affordability of this scheme. To those on this side who continue to claim that we should be fearful of these unions who are going to go around and push for an extra one per cent because `the Democrats did not give them five; they only gave them four', I say, `Let them push all they like; let the Industrial Relations Commission make the decision, as it should rightly do'.

To continue to assert, as some members of the Opposition do, that the Industrial Relations Commission will be blackmailed and will not do what in fact it has to do, is to accuse the Industrial Relations Commission of deliberately breaking the law. The second question mark on the introduction of a compulsory levy—

TALK.START.PARA: —It has put industrial relations considerations ahead of capacity to pay.

—Senator Alston is right; the second question mark on the introduction of a compulsory levy was the capacity of business to pay. We have seen what I regard as disgraceful but predictable misrepresentations from the Opposition and from other groups on this question. It all revolves around this 100,000 job loss worst case scenario. Dr Alan Preston of the Treasury was asked questions by Senator Alston on the possible effects of the legislation on employment. These questions were based on the totally ridiculous assumption—referred to by the Secretary to the Treasury as garbage—that the whole of the levy would be a net cost to business, that there would be no offset against wage rises. This is a completely invalid assumption and Senator Alston knows that. The Opposition has fraudulently claimed—and speakers tonight will continue to claim—that 100,000 jobs will be lost.

PARA.TAB: Of the rest of the Opposition speakers, only Senator Watson can claim to have heard the evidence in context, to have heard the comments about the assumptions in the modelling. The rest of the Opposition speakers are just baying at the moon and repeating in a totally unquestioning way the deliberate beat-up of Dr Hewson and Mr Peter Reith on this issue.

I commend the journalists and the other commentators covering this issue for realising the falsity and the hollowness of these arguments from the Opposition and for exposing the flawed methodology of the Confederation of Australian Industry survey on this issue. I received a letter today from Pierce Matthews Service Hotels, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator,
Thank you for your reply to the concerns expressed in my recent submissions—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this a Gareth Evans letter?
—No, it is not a Gareth Evans testimonial. The letter states further:

SPEECH.PARA: The effects of this levy would . . . have had a direct effect on employment levels in my companies' operations . . .

In this current climate, I feel that it is important to pass on my gratitude for your assistance and assure you that the outcome of the revised Superannuation Guarantee Levy has certainly given confidence to my companies to maintain the difficult battle and fight for the preservation of our business and the development of my employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read us all those hundreds from the other side.

—I have hundreds more. I could read Senator Kemp a lot of letters but I have more to say. I believe the Opposition is being isolated on this issue. Its credibility is being severely dented. Like so many other knee-jerk reactions in the area of tax and superannuation, I predict that after the election, if not sooner, the coalition's opposition to this legislation will disappear. We have seen that happen with the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax.

PARA.TAB: Let us take a moment to look at the big changes in superannuation policy which the Opposition has made in recent years. A couple of years ago, the Opposition rhetoric was to totally oppose what it called `union dominated superannuation'. In fact, what union dominated meant was equal—not sole—trustee representation for employee representatives and for employer representatives. That big lie was promoted for years until last year's Wollongong conference. During his speech at that conference, Senator Alston reiterated his Party's continued opposition to union dominated superannuation. His comments were so badly received by the industry that he has never repeated them.

A few months ago the first report of the Select Committee was released. Recommendation 5.1 of that excellent report was agreed to by us all, including Senator Alston and Senator Watson. Just to refresh our memories, I will quote it:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the requirement for equal employer/employee representation should apply to all funds with arms' length members; that is, funds with 5 or more members.

Just over one year ago, Senator Alston and the coalition went from a position of opposing any employee representation for funds with 200 or more members to creating support for the principle of democracy.

PARA.TAB: The second major back flip in superannuation policy by the Opposition has been in the taxation arrangements which currently apply to contributions. On 12 December 1990, Senator Alston opposed Government amendments to introduce the partial rebate system which currently applies where employees earn less than $31,000. The Democrat spokesperson at the time made the point that a system of rebates was much fairer in a progressive taxation system than the prevailing system based on tax deductions. At the time, Senator Alston stated:

SPEECH.PARA: What appalled me more than anything was that he seems to have swallowed the Government line on this whole change and simply picked up, at its most base level, the notion that somehow rebates are better than tax deductions and that that, therefore leads inexorably to equity in the field.

So 18 months ago the Opposition was appalled by the notion that rebates were proposed as a more equitable way to provide tax incentives. Guess what! The Fightback package adopted completely the concept of flat rate rebates for employee contributions and the taxation of contributions at the marginal rate.

PARA.TAB: I have to put this in context because Opposition senators are sitting here tonight trying to pretend to us that their policy today has always been fixed in concrete and that they know exactly the reasons why voluntarism is the preferred method. They are telling us that they have a lot of confidence when I am pointing to their history of back flips on major issues relating to superannuation. I am predicting that we will see more in the near future.

I congratulate the Opposition on its late but sensible change of direction. I remind the Senate of the recent plea of Mr Ian Salmon that the Government and the Opposition adopt some common proposals in this area. The Democrats have extracted from the Government an agreement to increase the threshold of the levy from $500,000 to $1m. We believe that this will protect the jobs of 250,000 employees. In addition, the initial rate of the levy will be 4 per cent, with a disallowable increase to 5 per cent from 1 January. This increase will be assessed at the time with reference to the strength and scope of the recovery. As such, we believe that we have absolutely minimised the immediate impact of the levy on employment. In addition, we have slowed down the implementation by two further years. Any such criticisms on the basis of the impact of the levy are completely bogus and are seen to be so by most people.

The critics also ignore the fact that we have convinced the Government to amend the Industrial Relations Act to enshrine the fact that the Commission must take into account the effect of the levy in national wage case decisions. This is a superior outcome to the original proposal. We are glad to have had the opportunity to change and improve the legislation.

I now turn to the benefits of the proposals for two specific groups in the community. The first of these is women. There has been much comment on how the superannuation guarantee charge will affect women. I guess that we have to ask which group of women. I say in passing that it is extraordinary that none of the big players has addressed the issue of superannuation for all women. Most witnesses, particularly from the superannuation funds, said, `Oh, yes, we are aware of the problem, but we do not have an answer'.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do.
—The Opposition's answer to the need of women to move in and out of the work force because of their commitment to parenting is to allow spouses to pay into a special account for the wife.
—What is wrong with that?

—That assumes in that quaint Liberal way that all women have spouses to provide for them throughout their lives. Only a Liberal would assume that. This comes from the champions of the low income earners. Let us examine the facts. Voluntarism for women has been a disaster. Before 1986, less than 25 per cent of women had any superannuation. Today, 72 per cent of women have coverage. A letter from the Australian Nursing Federation states:

SPEECH.PARA: Until 1987 the vast majority of our membership did not have access to employers contributions to superannuation. This lack of access arose for a variety of reasons including the mobility of nurses between employers and lack of portability. . . and the fact that 92% of nurses are women, many of whom work on a part-time basis for part of their career and have career breaks for family reasons.
The Superannuation Guarantee Levy will gradually develop the opportunity for our members to retire with some financial security.
The same applies to the Clothing and Allied Trades Union of Australia, which stated:
This will mean a great deal to our members who without such legislation would never be the recipients of employer contributed superannuation and would never have enough savings—
under the voluntarism of the Opposition—
to contribute to their own retirement savings plan.

PARA.TAB: Contrary to the view of critics like Eva Cox, who have no mandate from low paid workers like our members, women workers will benefit greatly from the Superannuation Guarantee Levy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What! You were impressed with her.

—I am reading from a letter. Finally, I wish to address the equity concerns which have been raised in respect of the legislation. I believe that most of the equity shortcomings can be addressed. Firstly, the welfare lobby correctly stated that for very low income earners—those earning below the income tax threshold—a rise in wages would be preferable to compulsory superannuation. I agree with that position. We are supporting the Government's amendment to raise the threshold from $250 per month to $400 per month, because it goes some way towards achieving that outcome. Even when the levy is operating at 9 per cent, the lowest amount payable would be $5.60 per week. Even if there were no charges on this rate of contribution, it would never grow into a significant amount of retirement income. Evidence provided by Coles-Myer also outlined the position facing part time students and casual workers, who make up a high proportion of its work force.

PARA.TAB: We think the benefits of raising the threshold outweigh the drawbacks. However, the point has to be made that State or Federal industrial tribunals can at any time grant award-based arrangements which start at a lower level. Indeed, there are some such arrangements currently operating. As I have stated in this chamber before, the Democrats support a pay rise for this category. We think the most effective way for this to occur is for the upcoming national wage case to consist of a flat rate award. This gives the greatest benefit to the very low paid.

We think that administration charges should be limited to 5 per cent of the contributions of members, and I recommended this outcome in my minority report. I am still unclear as to the exact objections of the Government to this, and I would ask Senator McMullan to explain to the Senate exactly what the Government's objection is to protecting fund members from being ripped off.

In addition, I will be moving an amendment which will allow flat rate superannuation arrangements to be paid by employers instead of the current strict employee-based system. I understand that the Opposition will be supporting this amendment. I thank it for that and commend it for its position on this aspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we will be moving it, actually.

—I do not think so. By this amendment, employers and employees will be able to negotiate arrangements which provide every worker with the same benefit if they so decide. There are already excellent examples of this system in operation in the New South Wales coal industry, the clothing trade and the transport and building industries.

PARA.TAB: The real question of equity is that of taxation concessions which apply to superannuation. This legislation does not deal with taxation at all. This issue will come up in the next session, and the Democrats and the Opposition have the numbers to fix those inequities. Certainly, the Opposition's policy on this aspect of superannuation is a good starting point, but I understand that there are some technical problems which have to be overcome with that proposal. There are a number of amendments which the Government will be moving. I have referred to those, and they have been moved in order to address Democrats concerns.
In closing, I note that the passage of this legislation is simply the beginning. It is not the end, but the beginning of a whole era of superannuation. We still have an awful lot of work to do.

It is dishonest of Senator Panizza to keep putting forward that misleading figure of 100,000 jobs. I challenge him to substantiate it. We still have a lot of work to do in terms of prudential matters, on taxation, on the preservation age and on getting more local investment in the traded goods sector. The opposition to this legislation will quickly disappear as the manifest benefits of it become well known and accepted by the community. This legislation will benefit 90 per cent of Australian employees, it puts in place not my preferred option but a satisfactory retirement incomes policy for the future, and it does not put at jeopardy 100,000 jobs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are discussing the Government's latest tax on business, the superannuation levy and its increase and extension. I do not think any of us should forget that, especially when the Senate this afternoon passed the Government's other tax on business—the increase in the training guarantee levy. I do not know why this Government thinks that business is a bottomless pit of money that it can tap every time it has a bright idea.
