It indicates to me that it is totally out of touch with the community and the number of people who are losing jobs. I know we need training for people to get jobs, and if, as I said this morning, we can identify the jobs and determine what training is relevant for those vacancies, we might think about it a bit differently. But there is no other conclusion that anyone can come to as a result of the legislation which was passed this morning and that which will be passed this evening—because the Democrats are agreeing to the Government's guillotine—that these are taxes on jobs and jobs will be lost. It is all very well for the Democrats to say that it will not be 100,000 jobs. I hope it is not 100,000 jobs, but there is very good reason to think that it will be.

PARA.TAB: In the short period remaining in which to debate the Superannuation Legislation (Consequential Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill 1992, the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992, the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill 1992 and the Superannuation Guarantee (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992, having been given only four hours in total and the Government and the Democrats having taken an hour of that time already, I wish to refer to that group of people in the community which is totally ignored by the Government and by the Democrats; that is, women. This is occupational based superannuation. It has no bearing at all on those in the community who have part time jobs or casual jobs, 75 per cent of whom are women. It makes no provision whatever for the two million women who are outside the paid work force.

Perhaps the Labor Party is still living in the antiquated times when the appropriate way for a woman to regard her superannuation was to think that she could rely upon her husband's superannuation. Once upon a time that may have been adequate; it no longer is, for several reasons, one of which is that one out of three marriages ends in divorce. No woman now can rely on her husband's superannuation to provide for her retirement income. Retirement income is of vital importance, particularly to women, as the population is ageing. Women outlive men and the facts do not need to be reiterated tonight.

We have the quaint situation with the Commonwealth superannuation scheme that a widow of a Commonwealth superannuant receives only a portion of his pension. What genius worked out that that was appropriate for her to maintain a standard of living of the same order as previously is quite beyond me. Her mortgage repayments do not drop because her husband is no longer there, her rates do not drop because her husband is no longer there, but she has to try to make do for all those expenses with the lower amount that she then receives.

It certainly was not me who first said that superannuation has been designed by men for men, but it is certainly a statement that we cannot help but think of tonight in discussing this legislation and the Labor Party's attitude of perpetuating superannuation as a male prerogative. It has not been designed to help women or take into account their needs or employment patterns.

One out of four women only are in employment with an employer-sponsored superannuation scheme. One out of two men are in such a scheme. In the industries and occupations where most women work there are no superannuation schemes. There are still few women in management, and I hope that will change dramatically in the next few years. Senator Sherry has spent some time tonight telling us about the imagination of this scheme and that we are looking at a 30- to 40-year project—and so we should—in relation to retirement income. But surely we can take the women of this country with us into such a scheme if it is going to be as imaginative as he says.

He says it is a great social security change—why he used that expression I do not know—and compared it with Medicare. That will send the fear of you know who into most people, especially those who have been sick and those who have been attempting to rely on Medicare. But most women are employed in part time and casual employment. They are excluded from most superannuation schemes which exist presently and will still be excluded after this legislation is passed tonight.

The legislation, the explanatory memorandum and the second reading speech take no account of the work patterns of either men or women. If one does not fit into the usual mould, one does not fit in and that is that. In most superannuation schemes it takes 10 to 15 years before people are entitled to their employer benefit. That does not fit the work pattern of many women in our community. It is totally inappropriate for women. I invite those opposite and the Democrats to read the report of the Lavarch Committee on equal opportunity and equal status for women, in which a great deal of work has been done in many areas, including this one. It recognises that women are not covered, but the Government has still not responded to the needs of women.

Senator Sherry's speech got 10 out of 10 for passion, but he missed out on dealing with a lot of the issues which are of vital importance. I was interested to hear him talk about the way in which the beneficiaries of Labor's superannuation scheme would receive amounts significantly above the value of average weekly earnings. This is the second half-hour speech we have heard from Senator Sherry in five days on the matter of superannuation. He is, of course, the Chairman of the Select Committee on Superannuation, and he spoke when the Committee presented its report last Thursday. I will quote from that speech because it is interesting and it substantiates the point I am making tonight that women just do not fit into the Labor Party's mould when it comes to superannuation. He referred to the fact that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is proposing by the year 2002 a 12 per cent level of contributions.

That represents 40 per cent of average weekly earnings. So all of these males whom the Labor Party and the Democrats are busily looking after will, if the scheme continues in this fashion, by the year 2002 be able to obtain superannuation to the value of 40 per cent of average weekly earnings. But what about all of the women to whom I referred who will not be able to be in that scheme, who are not in the work force or who are part time or casual? Senator Sherry did not forget them. Let me tell honourable senators what he had to say about women. He stated:
With regard to those persons who do not spend significant time in the work force—
and I stress the words `significant time'—
that includes, particularly, women who, for significant periods, are in many case bearing children—it is important to emphasise that the current old age pension will be maintained.

I suppose we are expected to bow three times and be ever grateful to the Labor Party and the Democrats that the current rate of old age pension will be maintained, giving those on it—particularly women, according to Senator Sherry—an income of 26 per cent of average weekly earnings. In the same breath, he tells us that those people whom the Government has put into a super scheme will get 40 per cent. That is the attitude of the Labor Party and the Democrats with regard to women and that is the point that I wanted to make tonight without going into the whole of the debate.

PARA.TAB: I also want to refer to our attitude to women in the Fightback policy. I shall not go into the whole details of it, but it is an aspect which is specifically referred to as follows:

As a major initiative to assist women in particular, the Coalition will allow spouses, either in a married or defacto relationship, to make tax rebatable contributions in respect of themselves and their partner. Such contributions will be immediately vested and preserved in the name of the beneficiary.

SPEECH.PARA: That is very different from what we are looking at tonight. It continues:

The maximum rebatable amount will be $1,500 a year in respect of a maximum contribution of $6,000 a year. This rebate, raised by the spouse in whose name the contributions are made will be in addition to $1,500 rebate available to all individuals in respect of their own superannuation arrangements. The maximum rebatable contribution that can be made by a married/defacto couple will be $12,000 per annum.

It then goes on to refer to part time and casual employees and to the opportunity for those who are not or who are intermittently in the work force to have a retirement savings account. We specifically recognise the need for a retirement income of a decent standard for women as they get older, as there are less people in the work force—which has been referred to tonight—and things of that nature. We are prepared to do something about women's retirement income and their future. The Labor Party and the Democrats are not.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry referred to this being a 30- to 40-year project. Why then is it necessary to bring this levy in on 1 July 1992 when we are still in the depths of recession and when even the Labor Party is only just beginning to tentatively refer to the fact that we may be turning the corner? Surely, if this proposal were the right way to go for superannuation, it would be better to wait a short time—which is what the Labor Party would have us believe is the case—until business is thriving a little better than it is at present.

One will not find much joy towards superannuation and retirement income from any person who loses his or her job as a result of the two taxes placed on business today. But jobs will be lost because businesses will not be able to absorb the training guarantee levy and the superannuation increase which descend upon them next week on 1 July 1992. However, tonight I am particularly concerned about the women of this country as they get older. I am also concerned that the Labor Party and the Democrats are prepared to proceed with the male-dominated superannuation that we have had for as long as superannuation has existed in this country. Not the slightest attempt has been made to give decent retirement income proposals to women so that they can look forward to a retirement with better than 26 per cent of average weekly earnings, which is the best that the Labor Party is prepared to offer them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Superannuation Legislation (Consequential Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill 1992, the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992, the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill 1992 and the Superannuation Guarantee (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992. Occupational superannuation in the form of a Federal award entitlement dates from a decision in 1986 in the national wage case to include a superannuation component in Federal awards. That component, of course, was 3 per cent. In the 1990-91 national wage case, the ACTU argued for a further 3 per cent round of award contributions, and the Government supported the ACTU's claims noting:

SPEECH.PARA: Occupational superannuation is a key element in the Government's retirement income policy of encouraging retirement provision by employees during their working lives to achieve adequate living standards . . . and the key to providing better income for the growing number of old people in the future is to increase savings now. Improved access to superannuation is the best way of achieving this.

The Industry Commission then proposed that a national conference should take place and the Government, faced with that, decided to legislate. The Senate has heard Senator Alston tonight talk about the Business Council's opposition. I am reminded of the employers who opposed award superannuation in 1986. It is as well to remember their opposition. They opposed award superannuation in 1986, just as the Opposition opposes it today and, of course, as many employer organisations still do. I quote from the transcript of the 1986 award case when the CAI, the leading employers organisation, stated:

Whatever the reasons for the government's inaction, it may be clear to us that the question of retirement incomes and in particular the structure of the superannuation system is one which squarely lies within the legislative responsibility of the government.
It went on further:

Having taken those steps, it is within its power to go further and legislate for the superannuation structure that it wishes to see operate within the community and, in our strong submission, it is the parliament which is the appropriate forum to determine the question of national superannuation coverage and it is for the parliament to make those decisions and not this commission.

So that is what the CAI, the leading employers organisation in this country, said when in 1986 it faced award superannuation. Of course, this Government is making that decision in the legislation before us tonight. Still, the major employer organisations oppose this proposal and the coalition, as usual, supports it.

PARA.TAB: The superannuation guarantee Bills introduce compulsion in a system that, as far as I am concerned, has failed ordinary wage and salary earners until this point. The employer often gave only to the elite in any particular workplace. It is the higher paid minority which historically has received superannuation in this country. The chiefs always got it; the Indians always missed out. That is my experience over a long period.

In a former life, I was a trade union secretary and I can see the people to this day who missed out because of the voluntary system that we had, particularly under countless Liberal regimes in previous years. Because the schemes were usually based on an enterprise or a group of companies, the employer always had the key on the employee. When employees had accumulated a certain amount of superannuation, they found that their salary did not move quickly enough because they were locked into that employer. If they wanted to either move their employment to gain a promotion or to improve their salary position, they found that they had a conflict because, as soon as they moved to leave, the employer deducted so much from the superannuation that had been accrued that there was a financial loss for the employee. In other words, the message was clear: `Move from that particular employer's establishment and you will be punished'.

That is the system of voluntarism that we have had in this country. That is the system that has torn people apart and made them sick with worry because in their individual cases they had to make this terrible decision. Often, even when they left the employment, if they finally took the decision to leave, they were filled with resentment and anger because they had not received a fair return for the years they had invested with that particular company. Of course, in those days the employer invariably dominated the trustees of the company fund, so the employee usually did not even have a voice at the trustee level.

I have seen voluntarism work in real life, not as some theoretical, dry formula. I have seen the people punished by that system. That is why I strongly support the Government's legislation—because it sets out to redress the voluntary system that existed in which there were endless tax incentives. If it were to work with money being thrown at it, it would have worked. But it did not work. So many people were punished by it that it deserves to be relegated to the scrap heap of history. It is no wonder that the Australian Council of Trade Unions supports the SGL proposals.

In relation to compulsion, the ACTU noted that award superannuation has meant that 79 per cent of the work force is covered by superannuation, including 72 per cent of all women workers. I want to take up what Senator Reid was saying about women. Women will not be excluded, particularly as there has been a great increase in the number of women participating in the work force. When we project that into the next 20 or 30 years, we face for the first time—not what Senator Reid has been saying about women being neglected—women being able to be treated absolutely equally. As those figures that I mentioned earlier of the percentages of women who are now covered by superannuation in the work force indicate, and as the ACTU concluded before the Superannuation Committee, for women and the lower paid workers, compulsion has worked and delivered benefits where a system based on incentives has failed.

Of course, there is failure in every level of the existing system. I have a short example of a particular attempt to gain redress under the award system. Without going into the confidential details, I will give some idea of the sorts of problems people have in chasing up an entitlement. This was a breach. A letter was sent on 28 August 1990; a follow-up letter was sent on 24 September; 10 phone calls were made; three letters were sent to the employer; two letters were received from the employer; there were 12 phone calls with the employers association; there were 16 phone calls with the superannuation fund; and then finally there was the need to prosecute. That is very typical of some of the weaknesses that we have had—even though there has been improvement—where we do not have the power of the law enforcing superannuation rights for people in this country. So that is why I certainly support compulsion.

I believe that there is a need to create economic security. It is part of the process of empowering people to have that security for their retirement. Economic security is the first thing that citizens in a modern state demand from government. They are getting that in this legislation today. This package extends the economic security of older Australians into the future.

I was strengthened in my resolve—I do not usually quote Treasury—when Mr Cole, the Secretary to the Treasury, came before the Superannuation Committee. He talked about the need for this legislation and said:

SPEECH.PARA: First, the current levels of self-provision in retirement are far too low.
Secondly, the present low average levels of superannuation support in the work force, particularly in the private sector, hold out little promise of significant improvements for future retirees.
Thirdly, the long period that it typically takes to accrue retirement benefits necessarily means a correspondingly greater urgency for action now.

Fourthly, the demographic structure of the Australian population is going to age markedly . . . and delays in increasing the present inadequate levels of superannuation support will exacerbate the difficulties in meeting the retirement income needs of an ageing population.
Finally, . . . it is also my judgment—
that is Mr Cole's judgment—
that the pace of adjustment towards the SGL's interim target is calibrated pretty well, having regard to the current economic position and prospective developments.
Mr Cole added:
. . . the SGL will be of greatest benefit to those principally low paid workers who currently have no superannuation support, or whose only superannuation is provided under an industrial award . . .
He further said:

. . . the impact of the SGL on retirement incomes is very progressive, with the greatest proportion of increases going to low income earners with the lowest levels of existing superannuation support, and absolutely nothing going to those who are already adequately covered by existing superannuation arrangements.

We have a major proposal. It is a compromise to some extent, but it is achieving agreement on a long term strategy. I think the Government can be very proud of that. Senator Sherry has pointed out that the financial drain will continue until the year 2019. Senator Kernot pointed out that if we do not act now the real crisis will occur in 2020.

PARA.TAB: While we are talking about the time when our grandchildren will probably be affected, it is proper for us not just to think of the next election, with which the Opposition is fixated, but to look at the long term needs of the community. To this extent we have to act tonight. We cannot bludge on our grandchildren. That is what we will be doing if we do not face up to this decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —We provide for them. I have provided for my grandchildren; you have provided for yours.

—I say to Senator Panizza, as I have pointed out, that the time is never right for people like some in the Opposition and most of the major employer organisations. Senator Kernot dealt with some historic background to this matter. It reminded me of my own experience. In the early 1950s, as a teenager, I went to a meeting of an organisation that supported the Chifley Government's national welfare fund. From memory, it was called the national welfare fund association. In those days the Chifley Government had imposed a levy on personal income tax which, with an additional amount from payroll tax, formed a national welfare fund.
—There was no Chifley Government in the 1950s.

—No. Between 1945 and before its defeat on 10 December 1949, the Chifley Government introduced this fund which was the basis for the future superannuation scheme, and probably a couple of other schemes. In the early 1950s Sir Arthur Fadden from the Country Party, the Treasurer of the day, clouted that money and put it into Consolidated Revenue. Although the fund continued until 1985, effectively the coalition Government put the resources that had been built up for a superannuation fund into Consolidated Revenue.

PARA.TAB: I remind honourable senators that we moved from a situation in the early 1950s when the Menzies Government and subsequent conservative leaders at election time said `Five bob for the pensioners' to the introduction of indexation when the Labor Government came to power. It is not good enough. We have to change the past practices of coalition governments by allowing this legislation. Although I would prefer to go back to the Chifley model, I understand that is not realistic. Today we have something that is realistic.

The compromise that has been worked out is the compromise of all reasonable people in this chamber and one which will be welcomed by the Australian people. The legislation before us will undoubtedly be a great boon to wage and salary earners in particular. The Government has a process in place to change the whole superannuation industry. From what I said earlier, I believe the jury is still out on the superannuation industry. I hope that by the time the Committee has finalised its three reports and the Government has reacted to them we will have cleaned up the superannuation industry and made it sufficiently answerable to the needs of the Australian people, bearing in mind that this legislation will impose great pressure on the industry to clean up its act and gain the probity and the trust that the Australian people require from it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I have to do in this debate is declare my interest. I will be helping to pay superannuation for six employees, give or take one or two. I have not heard any declaration of interest from the Government in this matter. I wonder how many Government senators have ever made up one pay package, let alone six or seven, 100, 1,000 or 2,000. I am waiting for someone to declare his interest in the same way that I have.

PARA.TAB: The Superannuation Legislation (Consequential Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill, the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill, the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill and the Superannuation Guarantee (Consequential Amendments) Bill ask this Senate and the people of Australia to accept a basket of proposals of great complexity that most of the country cannot possibly understand. The Government does not understand it and I am sure the Australian Democrats do not understand it, in spite of the attention it has been given in the media.

This proposal does not define the benefit that might accrue to individuals at the end of the day. It results in tax gains for the Government, it strengthens the ACTU and it provides an enormous bundle of new and continuing business to life offices. This package will not result in significant increases in savings, as claimed by the Government. Even the Democrats, in their minority report published in the second report of the Select Committee on Superannuation, acknowledged that. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's position is that this legislation simply attempts to create a much larger pool of retirement savings. The fundamental design of the retirement incomes framework is a separate and distinct issue which must be dealt with in isolation.

In other words, the Government is saying, `Pass this legislation and trust us to deal with other outstanding issues'. The Democrats said that they did not agree with that kind of approach. That did not stop them acting as another faction of the Labor Party, as they usually do, and as they did last night by doing a deal. Their consciences do not stretch that far and it does not worry them. I wonder how they can sleep at night knowing about the people they are putting out of work.

PARA.TAB: The coalition agrees that there can be little doubt that most Australians aspire to a higher level of retirement income than is enjoyed by the current generation. I have said in this place time and time again that superannuation in Australia has been neglected. But this is not the way to go about fixing it. I have always used the Italian system as an example. Earlier I asked Senator Childs whether he had looked at that system, but either he did not hear me or he did not care to listen to my interjection. The Italian system is pretty good. It is contributed to by both sides—employer and employee—and has been going since 1947, to my knowledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —More than 70 per cent of it is from the employer.
—Employer and employee.
—More than 70 per cent of the contribution is by the employer.

—Yes, and it is different in different categories of work. Senator West cannot tell me that she knows more about that one than I do, because I have studied it. I have said that I believe there should be a better retirement income than what is around at present. The major arguments put forward by the Government to justify a compulsory system are the need to boost national savings and the need to curb the rising cost of age pensions. The reality is that this country cannot achieve permanent increases in national savings and retirement incomes unless they are financed by a faster growing economic situation. Unfortunately, we are in exactly the opposite situation at present. The result will be a high number of job losses, which no-one on the Government side of the chamber or on the Democrats benches wants to hear about.

PARA.TAB: These are not simply retirement issues; they are national economic issues. The Government simply does not know how to address that issue. The bumbling we have had to date relates to how to cope with the increasing unemployment, especially youth unemployment, while the population is getting older.

The growth of the Budget deficit from the time the One Nation statement was released to the recent Premiers Conference illustrates exactly what I have said. Can the Minister who represents the Treasurer in this chamber assure us that that will not blow out further? It has been mooted to be $9.6 billion; it will be much more.

Compulsory superannuation will only result in a limited, if any, increase in national savings. I will come to that later. The most likely change will be a drift from savings in banks to superannuation funds. That is all. The figures that were quoted earlier this evening about the increase in national savings, even in the next 20 or 30 years, were very minimal. Even I, sceptical about what would happen, thought that they would be greater than that. It will result in a large increase in unemployment, as has been pointed out this evening. That is not understood by the Democrats or the Government. Businesses and organisations will simply not be able to afford it and will have to make further reductions.

As I have said, I believe that superannuation should be shared, but no-one from the Government wants to listen to that. The sharing system—whether it is half and half or some other arrangement—is in place in Germany, Japan, Singapore and Italy, to mention just a few. The Government and the Democrats will undoubtedly say that the employees will be sharing the cost of the superannuation levy by obtaining smaller wage increases than might otherwise be the case. I could believe that, but can honourable senators opposite tell me that when these employees at the end of the week, the end of the month or the end of three months see their diminishing purchasing power at the supermarket they will not go for a wage rise? If they go for a wage rise when they have less and less disposable income they will be granted further increases. They have to be. They will get them. Wage rises will be granted all around and the figure of 100,000 job losses will go up further.

What if the CPI continues to be modest? Could circumstances arise where a reduction in an award might be appropriate? I have not seen a reduction in an award yet, as far as I can remember. One day, if we keep inflation down—which this Government says it has done by killing off Australia and killing off the jobs—we might arrive at that situation. What will happen then? The answer is that we in the Opposition do not know, the Government does not know and the Democrats do not know. But we have a fair idea of what will happen.

The time available to me in this debate is limited, so I will address just a few particular problems. As I said earlier, superannuation funds are efficient. I will use as an example one that I pay into for one of my employees. Of the 3 per cent contribution that my company made on his behalf last year, 11.62 per cent went towards insurance costs—I presume that means life cover—16.06 per cent went towards administration fees, and 10.84 per cent went towards contribution tax. A total of 38.52 per cent of the contribution went to other than increasing his savings. Taken as a percentage of his already built up savings in the fund, insurance costs are 3.03 per cent; administration fees, 4.2 per cent; and contribution tax, 2.84 per cent. That means that 10.07 per cent of his total benefits in the fund are being slowly drained away.

I also looked at the conditions whereby an employee could collect his superannuation. Death cover starts at $16,000 and moves up. I looked at the conditions for a casual employee or someone who may decide to take 12 months off work and travel overseas. If an employee has not worked and has not contributed for six months and is killed he has no death cover. Even though insurance and death cover have been taken out of his contributions every year, he is not covered.

TALK.START.PARA: —What insurance company?
—It is one of the approved national occupation superannuation plans. It is not a union dominated company, that is for sure. Senator West's arrangements will be no different from those of anyone else.
—Tell me the name.

—The national superannuation plan used to be owned by the Federation company and is now owned by Switzerland Superannuation and Life Ltd. Can Senator West tell me whether any of hers are any different. I believe that superannuation schemes should be contributed to equally by employer and employee. What is wrong with an employee doing some saving? Can anyone tell me that? No, everything has to be loaded onto the employer as another tax. It is treated like the fringe benefits tax—someone gets a benefit, it is taxed and the employer has to pay.

PARA.TAB: I heard Mr Dawkins speaking on the radio this morning. He told us how this superannuation will make up a pool of funds which will increase manufacturing and production around Australia. He forgets that that money will come out of small business which is producing already. Those small businesses are the most efficient businesses we can get. The superannuation is coming out of small businesses. Small businesses will be closed down so Mr Dawkins can put in a big union controlled enterprise.

I have seen where these funds were going to improve production and manufacturing in Australia. In Western Australia the Government employees superannuation scheme was ripped off by the State Government. The SGIO was ripped off by the State Government. Will this scheme be the same? I know that Mr Dawkins plans to build up something and even take over BHP. The Government has as much chance of taking over BHP as Chiang Kai-shek had of taking over mainland China again. Mr Dawkins will be shutting down efficient businesses and we will have union controlled outfits.

Business cannot afford an increase of 5 per cent, let alone 4 per cent. Treasury has said that 100,000 jobs are on the line—Senator Kernot does not know that—and that does not include the 35 jobs that the Democrats helped unload last night. The worst case scenario is the loss of 100,000 jobs, supported by the Democrats. The Democrats do not worry about their conscience; they do not have a conscience when it comes to jobs. They unloaded 35 jobs in Western Australia last night and tonight at least another 80,000 jobs will be lost, on 4 per cent; 100,000 will be lost on 5 per cent.

I repeat: Government senators are making decisions in matters with which they have never had experience. None of them, from I have heard, has ever paid a wage packet out in his or her life. How many wage packets has Senator West paid out? How many has Senator Tate paid out? I asked him that this afternoon by interjection, but he did not reply. I do not know one Government senator who has paid out one pay packet, yet those opposite have the audacity to come in here telling us what small business should and should not do—that it should keep continually paying whilst being taxed out of business. As an employer I am sick and tired of it.

I will go halfway with any employee, as I have done for 20 years. For 20 years I have set up superannuation funds for my employees. I would meet an employee halfway on anything he wanted to contribute. When he left my employ—he did not have to stay with me—he got his entire entitlement and I said good luck to him. I told him, `If I can give you any advice from now on, I will do so and help you in your new job'. By working in that way, I have picked up virtually unemployed people and made citizens out of them. I can read out some recommendations just like those that Senator Evans reads out.

I leave the issue there, except to repeat that there are 100,000 jobs on the line. Treasury has said that if this cost were to be completely added on to the unit labour cost we would lose 100,000 jobs. Can those opposite tell me how that cost is not going to be added on to the unit labour cost? I cannot see how with most jobs these days we get better productivity through the action of the employee. If there is any better productivity achieved, it is through better machinery, better technology and better managed technology. That is how it is going to be. I cannot see any employees' actions whatsoever going to increased productivity; therefore the superannuation guarantee levy will be a tax totally on the employer, and I can see those 100,000 jobs quite easily going out the door within a very few years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight, as has been said before, we are debating one of those watermark issues in the history of Australian politics and in the history of the provision of services and assistance to enable people to have a standard of living after their retirement which is above and beyond the poverty line.

PARA.TAB: I must correct some of Senator Panizza's aspersions and comments in quoting Treasury figures. The Hansard of 6 May for the hearing of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation records Mr Cole as having said:

SPEECH.PARA: The material provided was not really Treasury analysis of the likely impact of the SGL on unemployment. The material provided was simply a simple exercise of modelling using assumptions that were provided in the question placed by Senator Alston.
The simple analysis goes with the simple minds that thought up the assumptions, I would suggest. He went on:

PARA.TAB: It has long been known that, with economic modelling or indeed, any sort of modelling, with anything that uses computers to generate lots of numbers, garbage in produces garbage out.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the same as statistics: if we are dealing with figures, we have to start off with the right assumptions. Mr Cole continued:

On this occasion, the assumptions, as I say, were specified in the question, and the answers that came out were no more reasonable as an analysis of the likely effects of the superannuation guarantee levy on employment and unemployment, than the assumptions that were used in the question.
He further said:

PARA.TAB: We pointed out in the answer that we were analysing and we were modelling the assumptions that were specified in the question. We pointed out that they were unreasonable and therefore that the result was not reasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: Those were the qualifications that Senator Panizza should have added when he was talking about what he alleges will happen. He continued:

I think it was quite clear to any person who actually read the material. I am surprised that so many people, including economically literate journalists, have managed to misconstrue what was answering specific questions, which is what we were asked to do.

Those are the qualifications that should be always taken into consideration when assessing what the Opposition claim to be the facts relating to the effect of the SGL. It is very important to always do that and to pay those qualifications the respect they are due. We heard earlier tonight of the effect of ageing upon this community, of the dependency ratios, and that 21 per cent of people by something like the year 2025 will be of retirement age. We also know that we are encouraging young people to stay on longer at school. Therefore, it is obvious that with the declining population, but with the bulge of those of us who are baby boomers at the retired end, there must be fewer people actually in the work force providing income to the Government from which it then has to pay pensions. That is a fairly simple and straightforward piece of commonsense logic, I would have thought.

PARA.TAB: The other question one must ask from the way Opposition senators are acting by not wanting this type of thing to be introduced is whether they want an either/or situation. Do we pay to have our children educated—and we know that is something in the `Frightback' package—or do we pay to have our aged cared for and provided with services? One must assume they want us to make that choice, which I do not think is an appropriate choice to have to make.

There have been many issues raised tonight in this debate, one about women. In `Frightback' we are told that spouses will be able to make contributions on behalf of their non-working spouse or partner, which is usually, on the part of the Opposition, said to be a woman. The maximum contribution is $12,000 each. I ask those opposite: how many families in this country can afford to put aside $24,000 each year for their superannuation? It is just typical of everything that this Opposition does. Those opposite are not living in the reality of what the average person has to live with, has to work with and has to exist on out there in the world; they are working on the assumption that everybody is getting at least average weekly earnings, and a heck of a lot more.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we are not.

—If those opposite put the figure of $12,000 as the maximum contribution, it would indicate to me that that is pretty much out of touch with reality, pretty much out of touch with what is really going on out there and what people are living on. The sum of $24,000 out of a salary package is enormous. For some families it is the whole salary package. Senator Panizza is making assumptions, like a number of people have made assumptions in this debate, that people can afford to do things. We are aiming for a situation where people are able to afford to do more things with their incomes at the end of their lives when they are able to enjoy some part time occupation or to participate in activities which require a little more money than that provided by the pension.

PARA.TAB: I have been reminded by Senator Giles, as she like me is a former nurse, that it was not until the late 1970s, early 1980s, that nurses in Western Australia were able to take out superannuation. They were not eligible for some of the State superannuation schemes. Often, the older women may be single and may not have moved out of nursing homes. Those opposite really would be putting these people behind the eight ball if they were not going to offer them alternatives and options.

TALK.START.PARA: —They may have been saving in another way.
—I do not think Senator Panizza is very well aware of what things were like in the nursing profession. It was jolly well low paid work. That does not appear to matter to Senator Panizza.
—Nothing matters to him.

—What Senator Faulkner said is probably quite true. I now deal with the fact that the Opposition announced in, I think, February that it was going to review its superannuation policy. Members of the Opposition are here tonight espousing what it definitely is, but I have not seen the results of this review announced or outlined. This review is headed by Professor Knox and he actually appeared before us—
—Finetuning.

—It is reviewing. Perhaps Senator Panizza wants to review it more after he has been reminded of what Professor Knox had to say to us. Professor Knox said, `The hypothetical question is: so should we proceed with SGL?' In reply to his own question, Professor Knox said, `I suggest we should'. He then went on to talk about a couple of areas that we should look at. He thought that, to improve the cost efficiency of the SGL, two areas needed to be looked at. One was an increase in the threshold, which is part of the Government amendments that we will be moving.

PARA.TAB: The other area relates to the frequency with which contributions are paid. Professor Knox's suggestion was 12-monthly. We have not agreed to that, but we have certainly looked at six- and three-monthly. I suggest that obviously there has been accommodation there. Basically, as Professor Knox said, we should proceed. He said that we should not remove the option for low income earners to have access to superannuation.

Professor Knox also dealt very well with compulsion. He thought that there was a need for a compulsory core and an optional extra. He put the compulsory core of the employer contribution in the range of 7 per cent to 12 per cent. He thought that, if it were appropriate for there to be an employee contribution, employees would need a tax incentive. That is almost straight Government policy, but the Opposition chooses not to take note of it.

Professor Knox is not the only person who has said that there is a need for compulsion. The Business Council of Australia informed the Senate Select Committee that there is an emerging consensus across the industry and employer groups that some form of compulsory payment is necessary. The Metal Trades Industry Association, in its original submission, also supported the general principle of compulsion.

Mr O'Sullivan from Noble Lowndes also supported a minimum contribution of 10 per cent, including member contributions. Mercer, Campbell, Cook and Knight support maximum employer and employee contributions. Mr Davis from the Small Business Association thought that there should be mandatory employer and employee contributions, as did Mr Mansfield. It is not as though the Government is out on its own in thinking that there should be compulsory superannuation. That is very important for people to realise.

Senator Panizza mentioned the superannuation system in Italy in his address. I hasten to add that in Italy the employer contribution ranges between 14.8 per cent and 30.43 per cent. The employee contribution is 6.1 per cent to 10.79 per cent. That means that in some areas about 66 per cent of the employees' total contributions are made up of compulsory employer contributions. They end up with 80 per cent of their final career earnings as their pension. That is a very significant contribution by the employers. Obviously, they get the benefits at the end of it.

As has been said before, New Zealand is the only country of those that we surveyed in this Committee that does not have some employer contribution. It has none and it is obviously striking some major financial problems.

The Opposition has said that we should enable people to have freedom of choice. I wonder what would happen if people had freedom of choice to opt in and out of the superannuation insurance field as they chose. Like all those people who take out optional extra superannuation insurance, they would be badgered and harassed by sales persons from all the life insurance companies who, carefully on some occasions, do not fully explain things, or do not leave their possible future clients with a full understanding of their fees and charges. We have heard some comment from the Opposition about administrative charges on the SGL. I suggest that we would have to address this problem for not only the SGL people but everybody involved in superannuation.

An annoyed self-employed gentleman—a farmer—rang me last week. He had been paying into a superannuation fund, which he had set up late in life in 1981, for about 10 or 11 years. He was planning to retire in the near future. He thought, when he was seeking to set up this fund, that he had given adequate instructions so that he would be able to maximise his money.

This gentleman has made a contribution of just over $18,000 since 1981. In the account balance late last year there was just over $26,000. If he had taken the $1,200 which he contributed each year—plus in the two years he had a good wool clip he contributed an extra $1,800 twice—invested it in the banks and paid tax, he would have had a greater amount of money on which to plan his retirement income.

Administrative charges, fees and costs are not just a problem for the SGL people. They are a problem that the Select Committee will be addressing in its third report. To me this highlights the problems that this aspect brings to it and that is one of the reasons why we have suggested that quarterly payments into the funds will reduce the number of transactions which are made, and therefore reduce some of the administration costs.

This is a very important issue. We keep hearing that there should be freedom of choice and that it is not the right time to make changes. I suggest to some people that it is never the right time to make changes to anything such as this. It is never the right time to make changes to things that are of importance and significance to people. It should always be voluntary. If that were the case, we would still have slavery and children working down the mines and in factories. We would still be working 80 hours a week and that type of thing. Those reforms were fought for very hard and were only accomplished when they were made compulsory reforms.

I suggest that in this case, if we are going to do something about people's retirement incomes, we have to have an element of compulsion to make sure that people do have something to look forward to in their retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The great writer and the first of the Westminster Hansard reporters, Charles Dickens, has rightly urged:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the bringing together of employers and employed . . . whose interests are identical, who depend on each other, (should) never be in unnatural antagonism without deplorable result.

The unnatural antagonism of the ACTU towards employers in this country will be at the expense of its own members; those very members whom Treasury has openly admitted will ultimately pay for the scheme with reductions in real wages.

PARA.TAB: The Superannuation Legislation (Consequential Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill, the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill, the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill and the Superannuation Guarantee (Consequential Amendments) Bill before us tonight reflect a government driven by an ACTU agenda. The ACTU failed to secure a second round of 3 per cent award superannuation. However, it has achieved its purpose using another formula and another forum—a sympathetic Labor Government.

The superannuation guarantee levy is a compulsory scheme to pander to the ACTU, giving it what the IRC denied. The Government and the ACTU are telling businesses and the Parliament that the levy will be paid for from wage increases not claimed and granted. Yet, behind the backs of their hands they are telling employees that employers will pay for the extra superannuation.

While some Government members tell us that the extra super will be in lieu of wage rises, ACTU Assistant Secretary, Iain Ross, has confirmed that there would be room for a national wage rise in 1992-93, over and above the wage rises taken in the form of superannuation as a result of the superannuation guarantee levy. He expects inflation to stay down and to have SGL and 5 per cent and pay rises.

On the bottom line someone must pay for the $122m cost to business, and taxpayers will have to fund the $500m-plus for the extra social security costs and the cost of personal taxation revenue forgone in the rising unemployment. Not only will there be rising unemployment as a result of this levy, but also there will be a drain out of savings from business into superannuation funds, certainly during the short to medium term.

Treasury has now done its arithmetic. It seems to have progressed from the back of the envelope stage to predicting an increase in national savings of one per cent of GDP by the year 2005 and 1.5 per cent in 40 years. So it is a long wait. In fact, it was interesting to listen to the Treasury officials before the Committee. When they first appeared it was fairly evident that this scheme had been prepared by the Government without a great deal of Treasury support and backing. But at a late stage they were forced to come in and defend the indefensible. We felt a tinge of sadness for them.

I put it to the chamber that this levy will not be sufficient to foot the bill for the extra unemployed. We also need to know whether this figure takes into account cessation of double dipping, because if it does not the result is entirely false. While it is possible for employees to take their lump sum and spend it and then apply for the aged pension—and this will continue—there will be little appreciable difference to national savings.

Some of the matters which ought to be addressed instead of applying this crippling blanket legislation are the raising of the preservation age to 60 years; restricting access to lump sums; gradually aligning the aged pension for men and women; encouraging employees to contribute to the cost of their own retirement; allowing part time and casual employees to have access to low cost alternative superannuation arrangements; abolishing the compulsory retirement age; and providing for deferred pensions.

The SGL is to be added to the award superannuation provision and will further add to inequities and complexities as far as the overall picture is concerned. The whole regime is built on an inequitable foundation and will tend to exacerbate poverty and hardship in both the short and the longer term.
The levy requires no direct employee contribution and as such is quite fairly unique in the world. In fact, representatives from Coles Myer put to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation that:

SPEECH.PARA: Until superannuation becomes a joint responsibility and is included in adjustments to labour costs, employees will have no commitment to providing for their own retirement. Whilst superannuation is seen as an input based on workforce participation rather than attempting to quantify an appropriate end benefit we cannot say that there is an effective and workable retirement incomes policy in Australia.

The imposition of the levy will not lead to efficient investment, contrary to that stated by the Government members. It has a bias to one form of savings and it erodes individual freedom of choice. In contrast to this, the coalition's Fightback superannuation package preserves freedom of choice and tackles the problem of national savings by generous concessions which will greatly encourage personal retirement savings.

PARA.TAB: From the proposed start-up date of 1 July, employers with annual payrolls of over $1m will be asked to contribute 4 per cent of each employee's earnings up to a maximum of $80,000 to any complying fund. This means, on average, $4,000 per employee. The bill for the nation's employers for all this is estimated at $122 billion: $22 billion for small businesses and $100 billion for major companies. The contributions will rise progressively to 9 per cent by the year 2002. Extra to these employer contributions, a further 3 per cent is to be negotiated on a wage tax trade-off. According to the newspapers, a possible deal on those figures has occurred with the Democrats, and I look forward to viewing the Government's amendments.

Although some negotiation has resulted in amendments and we now have a situation in the Bills where employees who earn less than $450 a month will be exempt, unfortunately there is no general exemption from the charges for an employer whose annual national payroll is less than a certain specified minimum. We, as a coalition, suggest that employers whose income is exempt from income tax and whose annual national payroll is below the training guarantee threshold, for example, should be exempt. This would cover the situation of small charitable organisations, in particular, which are in a poor position to meet these proposed requirements.

Another suggested improvement is that proposed section 61 should be altered to delete the words `is under 55 but'. An employee who retires because of illness above the age of 55 should not be in any worse position. I put it to the Senate that, despite the fact that this legislation has gone to a committee, it still has lots of imperfections and technical problems.

The levy will be payable by employers who fail to meet the minimum level of contribution. It is to be paid to the Taxation Office as a non-deductible levy to be redistributed to employees. In addition, an administrative charge by the Taxation Office must first be met by the employers in respect of each employee.

I wish to contrast the situation which I have been examining with a letter from Quentin Gomes of Harquep Enterprises in Perth. I hope he is listening tonight. He expresses succinctly the agony which has been voiced in many of the submissions which came to members of the Committee. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite working 60 to 70 hours a week only to survive in the current economic climate, we just never seem to be able to make a quid. We are simply exhausted just fighting to stay alive and the only thought the Government has, is to extract more and more taxes squeezing the last drop of blood out of the small business community.
Those are the words of a small businessman. He continues:

In the face of huge unemployment, is this how the Government expects us to create new jobs by sending the very job creators to the wall? If we, the small businesses die, so will many of our employees. [There will] be none of us left to retire.

The ACTU has claimed that the reason for its hurry is the demographic projection that the ratio of Australians of working age to those over 65 years will fall from 5 : 1 at present to 3 : 1 by 2031. However, these figures are very flawed. They do not allow for a reduction in the cost of maintaining the young or the capacity of the Australian economy to enable people to save more and therefore provide for their own retirement.

PARA.TAB: There are many problems with the legislation which will also add to the confusion. The law is too complex for employers to administer, especially when they are required to do so on a monthly basis. Not all funds are award based and the legislation presumes that all superannuation comes under schemes run by large insurance companies.

Additionally, it is envisaged—despite the protestation of Government members—that the super funds' costs will rise. In fact, I am most concerned about a comment from the Taxation Office made in relation to the Taxpayers Association submission about the need to pay monthly contributions. It says that all the funds would need to do is change their methods and trust deeds and pay monthly. In other words, according to this communication, high costs and administrative problems appear to be of no concern to the Australian Taxation Office.

Another area of concern is that the legislation is not clear in respect of wages and salaries. In fact, I foresee much litigation arising from this problem. With regard to fringe benefits, the then Treasurer, the Hon. John Kerin, in a 1991 information paper said:

SPEECH.PARA: Salary or wages for purposes of the SGL will not include eligible termination payments, retiring allowances, pension annuity payments, fringe benefits and some education and training allowances.

I think we need to be given a definite indication of whether this is still the case. It must be made clear that ordinary time earnings in proposed section 6(1) do not include fringe benefits in the same way that this is made clear for salaries and wages in proposed section 11(3). Further, the guidelines contain no exemption in respect of the employee if the employer is prohibited by the RBL rules or otherwise from making further contributions, although there are some small amendments in this area.

PARA.TAB: Definitional problems also occur with what constitutes a resident. A definition is needed to cover visiting employees to Australia by overseas companies. I also perceive problems in the charge for interest. In fact, it is for a flat 58 weeks, regardless of the period of the year in which the shortage occurred. Although guaranteed payments would not be due until, say, 14 August after the end of the financial year, the employer would be required to calculate interest rates from the beginning of the year in question until the date on which the superannuation guarantee charge in relation to the total would be payable. Such a draconian provision leaves me speechless.

Problems with the definition of an employee also occur. The Bill defines employees as covering the executive bodies of companies, people engaged under contract where the contract is wholly or principally for the supply of labour, members of Parliament, performers or presenters of entertainment or sport and members of local government councils. No wonder the Government is moving on the independent contractors area. It wants to try to rope them into this legislation as well. In other words, the levy is going to have an adverse effect on people such as solicitors who act as executive directors of companies. The levy requires that employers must make contributions in respect of persons who act as non-executive directors of companies.

Because the legislation exempts the self-employed, it is going to cause a rush into the small contractor situation as subcontracting of labour is closed off as an option by the imposition of the SGL. This will also backlash against unions by costing them membership as unemployment increases. This is what the Keating Government is desperately trying to cover up by forcing its proposed draconian contractor legislation through the Senate.

There are of course problems in respect of subcontract labourers with this levy. Many trades and professions already operate with a large subcontractor work force or the hiring out of skilled labour. In fact, we have seen an increase in the number of canvas workers because of anomalies in the sales tax legislation. Problems arise with plumbers and electricians. These are one-man businesses which will all remain outside the legislation, as will the self-employed, Government employees, non-residents and those over 65 or under 18. All of these groups will be exempt from the superannuation guarantee levy.

Those businesses which continue to subcontract labour will be in an obscure and very difficult position. There will be an increase in self-employment by people who have little or no expertise in business as those who have been subcontracting labour can no longer afford to do so because they are forced to pay the levy, and they will stop using the services of subcontractors. Where additional cost can be carried, it will quickly be passed on to the consumers of the services, increasing the cost of living for all Australians.

Legislation to stop independent contractors from operating is a most iniquitous assault on private enterprise and personal freedom and will not solve the Government's or the unions' problems. In fact, it will exacerbate the problems created by this levy and hamstring small scale private enterprise.

Another major concern is the need to amend trust deeds to make the funds comply from 1 July to requirements such as the vesting provisions. There have been real concerns as to whether trust deeds must be changed before the law is passed and proclaimed. The penalties for non-compliance are severe. The possibility of inadvertent errors is great with unclear situations.

It is regrettable that the Bill lacks transitional arrangements. An example of this is the New South Wales Coal Association, which has a very long established fund which now does not comply with the provisions relating to funding and vesting. In closing the old fund, it has had to make top-ups because of the need for additional funds so that the scheme can provide the entitlements outlined by the deed. But with this changeover, it will not be able to avoid having to pay a charge under the charge provisions, even though its contributions are substantially in excess of the specified rate. It is an iniquitous situation.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS AND TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1992SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1992SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE CHARGE BILL 1992SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will also be considerable costs in moving from non-complying to complying funds in cases such as this. There are other organisations paying well in excess of the levy which will end up paying twice because of the complexities of complying and non-complying funds. It is a most iniquitous situation.

PARA.TAB: An employer should not incur the superannuation guarantee charge through contributions it makes to a non-complying fund, if at the time of making them it had reasonable grounds to believe that the fund would receive complying status for the year in question. Again, I think the Government has moved slightly in this regard by way of a recent amendment. But it has done absolutely nothing to provide for transitional arrangements.

It is likely that many employers will provide superannuation guarantee benefits by contributing to externally managed superannuation funds, whether established by a union, an industry body or a financial organisation. In some cases, employers will agree to contribute to whichever fund an employee may select. It would be grossly unjust if the employer incurred the charge because the fund was later classified as non-complying.

I also raise a technical problem for predecessor funds under proposed sections 13 and 14. These provisions will operate as a disincentive for the amalgamation of superannuation funds. It seems that the successors to the schemes that were in existence as at 30 August 1991 with an earnings base no narrower than the original scheme was, under the information paper released in December 1991, given the same treatment in relation to their earning bases as funds in existence as at that date. So many employers would have proceeded on the basis that successive schemes were to be given the same treatment. Again, this charge and change is inequitable. One cannot rely on early Government information and proceed on that basis.

A further problem with the SGL levy is the affordability of voluntary organisations and associations, for example, in the disability area. Where these organisations are currently in receipt of government support, they will need to be assured of additional funds in the government contribution to cover the levy or the charge, otherwise their services will be curtailed. I appeal to the Minister, Senator Tate, to give the Senate the assurance that the Government will maintain the real level of funding benefit to enable the payment of the guarantee levy by these organisations.

The legislation will extend provisions for retirement savings, yet there has been no consideration of people who are not in the work force or who work part time. The small amount of part time work situation includes mostly women who, for at least part of their lives, are not in the paid work force and can have a break of only a few years. This aspect of the legislation is especially disturbing in the light of the trend towards job sharing and the desirability of this trend in helping to offset rising unemployment and family and social problems.

A vast majority of almost three million women are outside the paid work force. They have no access to superannuation, and they are especially vulnerable in their old age and in the event of widowhood or divorce. Of the 1.3 million casual workers in Australia, 63 per cent are women, and a high proportion are migrant women who are already subject to heavy discrimination from union executives. Eighty per cent of the 1.9 million Australians of working age who are not in the work force are women. There is no protection for these people under the legislation. In addition, there are many ways in which these people will bear the brunt of escalating costs as businesses raise prices to try to pay for the scheme.

By requiring 3 to 4 per cent contributions for everyone earning more than $3,000 a year, most of the savings, if not all at the lower levels, will be taken up by charges and the employee will be forced to go without increases that the employer could otherwise have afforded to pay. The guarantee legislation increases discrimination against women by widening the gap and by its blatant failure to address such a problem. In order to address this discriminatory problem, the coalition has a provision to allow workers to contribute up to $6,000 a year on a tax concessional basis for non-working spouses.

A further problem with the SGL is its effect on State governments. In fact, the head of the South Australian Treasury, Mr Peter Emery, told the Australian Financial Review that the introduction of the levy would cost South Australia $35m and could jeopardise an estimated 1,000 public sector jobs. Similar figures have come in from other States, indicating that there has to be some adjustment in this area. In Tasmania the cost will be about $12m.

It is unfortunate that at this late stage of the parliamentary sitting this legislation is being rushed through with complete disregard for the many good submissions received and tabled by the Select Committee. It is disastrous in its fundamental philosophy of removing the right of individuals to plan for retirement in their chosen way, placing the onus on employers who cannot afford it, who will be looking for ways to pass on the cost. I would like to end with the concluding remarks of a letter which I quoted from earlier by Quentin Gomes from Perth:

SPEECH.PARA: We strongly object to the Guarantee Tax and implore you not to pass it through the Senate. Your rejection will mean giving us, the drowning small businessman, a hand to stay afloat, who in turn will keep at least those who have a job in employment and avoid the soul destroying exercise of lining them up on the dole queue.
Please, once again, we appeal to you that good sense will prevail.
This is the plea that I make to the Senate on behalf of the work force, the disadvantaged and the great proportion of the business community in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of my colleague Senator Watson and the very great concerns expressed by other colleagues on this side of the chamber in this debate on the Superannuation Legislation (Consequential Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill 1992 and related Bills.

PARA.TAB: These superannuation Bills are before the Parliament because they represent ACTU policy. A key component of the ACTU accord mark VI is superannuation. As we all know, the IRC failed to agree with the Keating-Kelty push for compulsory superannuation. Instead the IRC recommended a national conference on retirement incomes. As a result the Government has now decided on compulsion through legislation.

Why is the ACTU so obsessed with superannuation? I would suggest to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the ACTU is not noted for its long term perspective on so many other aspects of industry policy. We have seen how vigorously the ACTU and its cohorts have fought over the years to prevent the very real productivity improvements which could have been made in this economy and which could have sustained higher living standards than we now have. Why is it that suddenly this organisation has decided that it has to address the central issue of the ability of a government of any complexion, some 20 to 30 years out, to pay the pension bill? Why is it that Mr Keating and Mr Kelty have suddenly focused on this issue and are ramming this legislation through the Parliament this evening?

The reality is that the ACTU, having presided over a real cut in living standards—an astonishing thing under a Labor government—believes that compulsory superannuation will assist in signing up members. As we all know, the membership of unions is falling. It has fallen over the period of this Labor Government, despite all the attempts of the Government to bolster the power and privileges of unions.

The funds accumulated in these union controlled funds will provide the unions with a source of political power and influence over industry and the direction of investment funds. I remind the Senate of what Mr Keating said at the ACTU Congress in 1989. I think this quotation from Mr Keating lays the basis for and gives the reason why we have this legislation before us this evening. Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the trade unions at any time are placed in a more hostile political environment, they will face it not only with their negotiating power in the labour market, they will face it being a significant controlling element in the $600 billion savings.

These Bills are not focused on concern for the problems that some future government may have in funding retirement incomes. It is not concern about the living standards of Australian workers. It is not concern about the comparatively poor levels of national savings in this country. These Bills are basically about one thing—union power.

PARA.TAB: These Bills help fulfil the ambitions outlined in perhaps one of the most reactionary documents ever brought into the public arena, certainly in the last 20 years: Australia Reconstructed. One of the thrusts of that document was to develop union influenced and union controlled superannuation funds. The union movement wants compulsorily required savings of employees as a vehicle to maintain its influence and power in the Australian economy.

We know why the Labor Government and the ACTU support this legislation. What is surprising to me is that it is also supported by the Australian Democrats. I suggest that the question before this Parliament is why the Australian Democrats have been suckered into supporting this disgraceful deal. I do not recall any survey of Australian workers to see whether they would prefer compulsory superannuation arrangements, which would limit their choice of savings options and, effectively, in some industries result in the loss of jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they weren't asked.

—As Senator Alston has confirmed, basically the workers were not asked. There was a very good reason for that. If the workers had been told that there may be some trade-off in wage increases, in living standards and in the ability of workers to decide what to do with their savings rather than to allow a union controlled or union influenced fund to decide what to do with their savings, the union officials may have been met with a resounding no.

PARA.TAB: In the last week or so, Senator Spindler discovered that jobs are the real issue in this Parliament. So each day in this chamber he has taken almost every opportunity to let us know about his new discovery that jobs are important. It is somewhat ironical that the Democrats, who have opposed all major mining developments, fought all forestry developments, sought to tie up the rural industry in green tape and supported virtually all major legislation to increase union power, now show some concern for jobs.

How fair dinkum is this newly found concern of the Australian Democrats for jobs? We have all read about the hard-fought negotiations between Senator Kernot, Treasurer John Dawkins and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan. What happened after all the headlines and all the photographs in the newspaper? There were some changes; that is true. The Government got only 90 per cent of what it wanted, rather than 100 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was an ambit claim.

—As Senator Reid said, the Government probably got 100 per cent of what it wanted because basically it was an ambit claim. Senator McMullan is smiling. So he should, because on the basis of what he aimed to achieve I suggest that he did pretty well. On the basis of what Senator Kernot and the Democrats aimed to achieve, I suggest that, at least measured by the standards of the national interest, they did pretty badly. The essence of the Bill remains unchanged: compulsory superannuation raised effectively via a payroll tax.

PARA.TAB: This Bill will impose an additional tax on employers of between $2 billion and $3 billion per year. It is worth recording—Senator Reid drew this to our attention—that we had a Bill before the chamber this morning which concerned the training guarantee levy. This levy imposes some $700m to $800m on employer payrolls. I thought Les Hollings in the Sunday Telegraph of 21 June summed it all up rather well. Let me refresh your memory, Mr Acting Deputy President, as I know you are a keen reader of that newspaper, as to what Les Hollings said:
The timing of a superannuation levy has to be the most heartless, hypocritical, mindless act in a recession that is continuing to bring misery and despair to more and more of our citizens.
The prize for the most cynical act must go to the Democrats for enabling the levy to be passed in the Senate at a rate of four per cent instead of five.
How callous can politicians get?

SPEECH.PARA: I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President: how callous can Senator Kernot and the Australian Democrats get? It is clear that Senator Kernot is acutely sensitive about the jobs issue and about how this particular legislation will cut employment. This is what Senator Kernot said of her handiwork:
We do not accept that no jobs will be lost as a result of this legislation.
You will notice that that is a double negative, Mr Acting Deputy President. She went on to say:
We are asking the Government to negotiate on reasonable proposals to minimise the impact on business and jobs in the short run.
Perhaps we will not lose 100,000 jobs; perhaps Senator Kernot would be content with the loss of 60,000 or 50,000 jobs. That is what Senator Kernot said in the Canberra Times recently.

PARA.TAB: I listened very carefully to Senator Kernot's speech. I came into the chamber particularly to listen to it. I say to her and to her fellow Democrats: how many jobs has this particular effort of theirs cost? What is their estimate? Employers, who after all have to pay the money, believe that the job losses will be substantial. The Confederation of Australian Industry estimates that job losses will be between 60,000 and 180,000. Mr Ian Spicer said that the deal done was `an incomprehensible decision' that would reduce investment prospects, boost inflation and make the economy less competitive.

Returns of a survey of some 824 firms undertaken by the CAI indicated that, of those which indicated the superannuation guarantee levy would lead to an increase in costs, three out of four firms will respond to the levy by employing fewer people. The General Manager of the Queensland Confederation of Industry said that the Democrat deal would `force manufacturing industries to go off-shore and place jobs in countries other than Australia'. Other industry groups make the same point. In my own State, the Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce indicates that there will be lost jobs and lost job opportunities as a result of this measure.

Senator Spindler, like many in this chamber, has expressed concern about the state of the car industry. This industry is suffering very low margins and, in many areas, serious losses. This new found concern of Senator Spindler came as a bit of a surprise to me. Senator Spindler strongly favours public transport over road transport; he supports additional fuel taxes and transport taxes in an attempt to encourage people to forgo their cars and use public transport. The Senate will recall that yesterday Senator Spindler and his colleagues strongly supported an additional tariff on imported used cars in order to protect the local car industry. Today Senator Spindler and his colleagues reverted to type and decided to support an extra tax on the car industry—the superannuation levy. Senator Spindler has also expressed concern about the state of the textile, clothing and footwear industries; today he decided to help them along a little by agreeing to impose an extra tax on them. The superannuation guarantee levy is an extra payroll tax.

The tax increases will not end there. State governments around Australia will have to find an extra $300m over the next year to fund the increase imposed by the Keating Government. According to estimates that I have read, the $300m will rise to over $1.5 billion by the end of the century. Where will State governments get this money from? Mr Acting Deputy President, you will know that the Government in your home State of Tasmania is particularly strapped for funds. I suggest that the governments will get the money through additional State taxes and charges, some of which will undoubtedly fall on industry—particularly if it is a Labor government—including the car industry and the TCF industries.
