Even on the most conservative estimates, the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill will cost tens of thousands of jobs. The Australian Democrats and the Government have the cheek to suggest that they are concerned about jobs. Time is short, so I will conclude.

TALK.START.PARA: —Take as long as you like.

—Senator Crichton-Browne wishes to make a very important contribution so, in view of the heckling I am receiving from him, I will cut my remarks short. The Australian Democrats have made a particular point of building up links with welfare lobbies. Much of the rhetoric of the Australian Democrats emphasises their alleged concern for the underprivileged. The coalition of welfare groups, led by the Australian Council of Social Service and including the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, has said that the superannuation deal would make low income earners, women, and casual and part time workers forgo wage increases now and in the future for little or no long term gain. In short, there was a howl of rage from the welfare lobby groups about the deal that Senator Kernot and her colleagues have done with the Government.

PARA.TAB: This Bill represents perhaps the most significant deal the Democrats have done with the Government since their support for the ban on political advertising and the amalgamation of trade unions. This Keating-Kelty-Kernot Bill will not add to national savings, it will not add to employment and it will slow the recovery in the economy. In proposing this superannuation scheme, the ALP and the Australian Democrats are serving their own narrow political interests; they are certainly not serving Australia's national interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the hour is 10.55 p.m. We have but 50 minutes until the guillotine. We also have an exhaustive committee stage. To me this is one of the most fundamental pieces of legislation to come before this chamber, but to the extent that it is not possible to have the sort of debate that is necessary I seek leave to incorporate the speech I would have normally given in these circumstances.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: PROPOSED SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE LEVY
. . . this is one of the greatest social advances by this Government or any other government in the history of the federation of Australia.
Senator Cook (Hansard, 21/8/91), on the proposed superannuation guarantee levy.
In contrast to Senator Cook's grandiose characterisation, the Keating Government's proposed compulsory employer contributions superannuation scheme will;
(a) reduce economic growth,
(b) add to unemployment,
(c) create inflationary pressures,
(d) reduce savings,
(e) reduce living standards, and
(f) lead to lower retirement incomes.

The superannuation guarantee legislation, an attempt by the Government to circumvent the Industrial Relations Commission's refusal to deliver a second 3 per cent superannuation in last April's national wage case, is the product of a deal struck in a meeting at the Lodge between former Prime Minister Hawke, two of his ministers, and the ACTU secretary Bill Kelty, and president, Martin Ferguson.

The effect of the legislation is to establish a compulsory minimum level of employer contributions of between 9 and 12 per cent. The mandatory contribution level was originally to be set at 3 per cent for businesses with annual payrolls of $500,000 or less, and at 5 per cent for all other employers, with both minima rising to at least 9 per cent by the year 2000.

However, after pressure from the Democrats the Government has agreed that the mandatory contribution level will initially be set at 3 per cent for businesses with annual payrolls of $1 million or less, with both minima rising to at least 9 per cent by the year 2002.

The superannuation guarantee levy is intended to work in a similar way to the training guarantee levy. Where an employer makes contributions at a rate lower than the compulsory level, a tax will be imposed on the employer. The total tax payable in each case will consist of; (a) the difference between the amount of contributions payable at the legislated minimum rate and the amount of contributions actually made, (b) an interest component based on the rate for underpayments and overpayments of income tax (currently 14.026% per annum), and (c) an administration charge, consisting of a flat amount of $50 plus an amount of $30 for each affected employee.
(a) ECONOMIC GROWTH

In a recent speech made in Perth, Professor Ross Garnaut, an economist at the Australian National University, and author of "Australia and the Northeast Asian Ascendancy" (a 1989 report, loudly acclaimed by the Government), argued that the key to sustained economic growth is improved international competitiveness. Three of the five elements he identifies as being vital to Australia's competitiveness will suffer a negative impact under the Government's proposed scheme: (a) economy-wide costs and prices relative to international costs and prices, (b) the relative cost of capital, especially interest rates, and (c) the capacity to lift labour productivity in individual workplaces.

I will outline the likely effects of the SGL legislation on each of these elements in more detail below, but at this point it can be noted that; (a) Treasury forecasts have indicated that the introduction of the scheme will boost inflation by two percentage points, (b) the interposition of an additional layer of intermediation in the financial markets (required because of the conservative investment programmes of the swelling superannuation funds) between major lenders and small to medium-sized borrowers will result in increased interest rates, and (c) the legislated increase in contributions (purportedly in lieu of wages growth) significantly reduces the scope for productivity based negotiations.

Thus, the Government plans to proceed with legislation which clearly ignores the policy implications of its own apparent concurrence with Garnaut's position. They have been bullied into this self-contradictory and pathetic position by the ACTU. The threat from Bill Kelty that the Accord would be "dead" if the Government failed to deliver increased compulsory superannuation is clearly the driving force behind the Government's proposed reforms.
(b) UNEMPLOYMENT

As the shadow Minister for Social Security, Child Care and Retirement Incomes, Senator Richard Alston, has pointed out, the Government's employer paid superannuation scheme amounts to a $4 billion payroll tax, and is "the last thing business needs if it is to be able to get up off the floor".

The legislated superannuation increases will, in all likelihood, represent a simple "add-on" to existing labour costs. Increased unit labour costs will, in turn, lead to a reduction in business retained earnings. The distressing but inevitable outcome will be higher unemployment.

Results from the Murphy Model indicate that implementation of the proposed scheme will cost more than 100,000 Australians their jobs over the next three years, an increase in unemployment of one quarter of a percentage point by the second quarter of 1994. This painful employment effect will be associated with a relative decline in production by one half of a percentage point during the same period.

The Government's claim that the cost of superannuation contribution increases will be off-set by wages restraint is not to be believed. As the former Treasurer John Kerin admitted of the Government's wages policy, "We don't exactly know where we're going". The Government has now agreed, under duress, to put the principle of absorbing the cost of the SGL into wage demands over the next 10 years into legislative form, but it is doubtful that this Government's legislative guarantees can withstand the power of the ACTU. Indeed, regardless of the Government's statements of intent, the first scheduled increase in superannuation to apply from 1 July 1992 will unavoidably constitute a simple add-on to the current price of labour.

The timing of the scheme's introduction exacerbates its negative impact on employment. In the existing, already weak, labour market, any cost increases on employers can be expected to affect employment even more. Likewise, the arbitrary and inflexible timetable for future increases in minimum employer contributions during the 1990s, has the potential to play havoc with the economy, and will almost certainly have continuing, significant, deleterious effects on the level of employment.

Which raises the question of whether or not the ACTU really cares about the 10.4 per cent unemployed in this country. The much vaunted wages trade-off for superannuation is either a delusion or a ruse. In reality what the ACTU and the Government have devised is an uncaring, irresponsible, short-sighted, "jobs for super" trade-off.
(c) INFLATION

As noted above, reducing economy-wide costs and prices relative to international costs and prices is essential if Australia is to improve its international competitiveness and thereby achieve sustainable economic growth. In this respect, the SGL legislation is the opposite of what is actually required. It places a huge burden on business which will, in part, have to be passed on in the form of higher prices.

Results from the Murphy Model of the Australian economy indicate that the increase in unit labour costs to be brought about by the SGL legislation will lead to an increase in inflation by one third of a percentage point by the second quarter of 1993, rising over the subsequent 12 months to an increase of more than two percentage points.

Senator Button has previously argued in the Chamber that compulsory increases in employer contributions will take the place of, rather than be in addition to, substantial wages growth, and that this is a position the Government shares with the ACTU. However, although the ACTU Executive has announced a decision to "defer consideration of the timing and quantum of a claim for a National Wage adjustment", following its February meeting it emphasised its on-going commitment to press for further inflation-linked wages growth, and it is now clear that the ACTU expects to secure real wage increases in 1992-3. With inflation running at 2 per cent, it is thought that a nominal wage increase of 3 per cent will be the ACTU's likely target.
Obviously then, the claim that unit labour costs, and thus prices, will not be boosted by increases in the minimum level of compulsory employer contributions, is fantastical.
(d) SAVINGS AND INVESTMENT

One of the main arguments advanced by the Government in support of the proposed scheme is that it will lead to an increase in the pool of national savings upon which Australian industry can draw for investment purposes. Indeed, Senator Cook has described the SGL legislation as "a significant investment boon to the economy". Unfortunately, for the Government, this claim is yet to be substantiated. On 15 April 1992, just ten weeks before the Government intended for the scheme to commence, Treasury officials told the Senate select committee on superannuation that they had not yet calculated the impact of the SGL on aggregate national savings. That is, they could not say with any degree of certainty what the savings/investment effect of the scheme would be. Several weeks later however, Treasury was arguing in its submission to the Senate Committee that the SGL would lead to an increase in national savings, by three per cent of GDP over the period to 2020.
However, as the minority report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation states:

the Treasury remains deeply sceptical concerning. . . [the SGL] proposal about which it was not consulted and to which it had no policy input. It was simply required to take on board an Accord deal and massage it through the Parliament. (p 89)

In fact, overseas experience suggests that the net effect on national savings from superannuation schemes is negligible, but that there is a significant effect on the composition of savings and investment. The implications of this compositional change are important and will be examined below. But first, it is worth considering arguments in favour of the CAI's assertion that rather than acting to raise the level of national savings, the SGL legislation will actually lead to a fall in the pool of funds available for business investment.

The CAI has argued that there are "strong reasons to believe that aggregate savings in the Australian economy will diminish" as a result of the introduction of the scheme contained in the SGL legislation. The argument is that superannuation payments made by employers will act as a drain on business retained earnings, the very funds which profitable businesses draw on to invest in their own expansion. As well as reducing business savings, lower levels of profitability discourage the establishment of new enterprises. Thus, in opposition to Senator Cook's claim, in the view of Australian industry, the SGL legislation is far from "a significant investment boon".
Furthermore, as Senator Alston argued recently in the "Australian Financial Review":
Forcing employers to provide a minimum level of superannuation without any commensurate employee contribution is likely to lead workers to vacate the field. . .
The OECD has already warned of the principle at work here:

Increased institutional saving, in the absence of more general improvements in the incentive to save, may result only in the substitution of increased superannuation savings by lower saving in other forms.

Even the Treasury was forced to acknowledge the effect of the potential operation of this substitution or "switching" on its projections for an increase in national savings as a result of the SGL legislation:
Some substitution can be expected, however,. . . there is unlikely to be complete substitution. No estimate of the likely magnitude of this effect is available. (p 88 Sen Com)
As the minority report of the Senate Committee noted:

. . . there is likely to be a very considerable switching effect. . . Therefore it cannot be said with any degree of confidence that there will be any particular increase in savings as a result of the SGL scheme. (P 88)

The obvious point is, that to legislate for a given level of savings is ineffective. To improve savings, what the Government must do is implement policies which increase the incentive to save. National Mutual has estimated that given the Government's over-reliance on compulsory superannuation contributions, its proposed rate of 9 to 12 per cent will fall well short of the 15 per cent rate needed to even begin to counter the growing constraint on public sector savings formed by the increasing social welfare bill.

The broader implications of a continued poor level of national savings, or of a further reduction in the same, which the SGL legislation looks set to achieve, are extremely serious. The ANZ Bank has estimated that national savings must be increased to 21 or 22 per cent of GDP simply in order to stabilise our level of foreign debt. And, to begin to reduce foreign debt, savings must reach a rate of at least one quarter of GDP.

The inadequacy of Government savings/investment policy was highlighted recently in comments made by Anthony Berg, the Managing Director of Macquarie Bank. He stated that the Government's existing focus on superannuation is not sufficient to build Australia's domestic savings up to a level which would enable the restructuring and expansion of the country's manufacturing industry, and noted that the likely, but undesirable, outcome was that investors will be forced offshore for capital, thereby further adding to Australia's existing, excessive $144 772 billion net foreign debt.

Now, I would like to return to the important question of the likely effects of the SGL legislation on the composition of national savings (as opposed to the aggregate level of national savings), and its further consequences for the general pattern of investment in Australia. The ANZ Bank, supported by the Industry Commission, has pointed out that compulsory superannuation has the potential to "distort national savings in favour of super funds, causing the cost of bank funding to rise". At the proposed mandatory levels of 9 to 12 per cent, the potential impact of this distortion is inevitably greater. The massive transfer of capital from the banks to superannuation funds which will occur under the Government's scheme will operate to disadvantage borrowers, through at least two different mechanisms.

First, the conservative investment policies of superannuation funds mean that they customarily invest only in secure, long term projects. They typically place funds into equities, property and fixed interest securities. Medium-sized and small businesses have accordingly tended to rely on banks as a source of finance. Thus, the SGL legislation will cause the pool of funds available to borrowers from banks to shrink, thereby increasing the difficulty of obtaining finance for medium-sized and small businesses.

Second, even if, as the Treasury has argued, superannuation funds begin to provide finance to these borrowers through intermediaries (who are already expert direct lenders), the extra layer of intermediation required, is likely to add to the cost of borrowing. Either way, small to medium-sized borrowers are sure to lose out.
(e) LIVING STANDARDS

It is axiomatic that superannuation increases do not help maintain current living standards. Understandably, low income earners especially will always prefer pay rises in the form of wages. If the Government's claim that increased compulsory employer contributions will significantly reduce "wage growth from other sources" does turn out to be accurate, the SGL legislation clearly poses a threat to current living standards.

Low-income earners, as those most unable to afford any kind of "disposable income for savings" swap, thus have most reason to fear the Government's proposed scheme. On the other hand, if inflation-linked wages growth is simply awarded on top of increases in the level of compulsory employer contributions, both savers and consumers can expect to see the value of their earnings eaten away by price increases.
(f) RETIREMENT INCOMES

The Government's plans regarding the future of the age pension and the role of the SGL legislation in these plans, are sketchy, and to the extent that they can be made out, appear to hold no great promise for either future retirees, or the ever-shrinking section of the population who will generate the income required to support them.

Even if the pressure on expenditure caused by the age pension bill is relieved by the Government's scheme as the Treasury predicts, what will this mean for individual retirees? As superannuation goes up, entitlements to the age pension will go down. On the face of it, individual retirees will certainly not be better off, and given the broader economic consequences of the scheme, those on fixed incomes will be particularly vulnerable.
CONCLUSION

It has been argued above that the SGL legislation will jeopardise; (a) economic growth, (b) employment, (c) price stability, (d) national savings, (e) current living standards, and (f) future retirement incomes. Perhaps most importantly, it will reduce the capacity of Australian industry to compete internationally, adding as it does, to the inflexible nature of our labour market. Clearly, the proposed superannuation guarantee levy legislation is yet another threat to Australia's future economic prosperity. In itself, the proposed scheme exemplifies the inability of the Government to implement the structural reforms so desperately required if we are to achieve sustainable economic growth. Hamstrung by its relationship with the ACTU, the Government finds itself unable to take on the policy actions it knows are needed.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—I call Senator Bishop.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret to say that Senator Bishop is not with us tonight. We are therefore proposing to adjourn. Could I just have it confirmed from the Manager of Government Business that we were at one stage proposing to sit even later but that, because the Democrats have a more important engagement in the form of a corridor party, we have decided to adjourn prematurely.
—I will call the Minister, in which case the debate is closing.

—in reply—The Government intends to adjourn at the conclusion of the second reading, which I think most people would consider appropriate. There will be a committee stage tomorrow morning to take up such issues as people wish to raise at that time.

PARA.TAB: Many issues were raised in the second reading debate. I thought the contributions from those honourable senators who were members of the Select Committee on Superannuation were very substantial. Quite clearly, I could not agree with all their contributions, but that is not the point. The point is that I thought each of them made substantial contributions and it was a debate of some substance. I thought it fell away a little at the end, but that is perhaps as might be expected.

We are dealing today with major and long term reform. Politicians as a professional group do not rate highly in public esteem. The opinion polls rank us very low. There are a variety of reasons for that, and it is to some extent an international trend, but I think one of the reasons is that it is all too common for people to perceive members of parliament as acting in a knee-jerk way in response to issues immediately before them—recent and very well publicised events in New South Wales would reinforce this view—and acting in a way that fails to distinguish between party interest and national interest.

We have here a proposal that is not going to change Australia fundamentally today or on July 1, or even January 1 next year. In the next 30 to 40 years, the proposal will make a very major change to the culture of this country, a very major change to the economy of this country, and a very major change to our society. It will make a contribution in three or, if one wants to subdivide it, four important ways.

Firstly, it is going to make a substantial contribution to the necessary retirement incomes task that Australia will face going into the next century. There have been interesting discussions by some about whether it is correct that the dependency ratio will increase, which is a very interesting arithmetical exercise. What is clear is that the burden on future generations of taxpayers to meet even the existing levels of retirement incomes for the burgeoning number of retirees in relation to the body of taxpayers will be a very substantial burden that we will impose upon our children if we do not act now to do something about retirement incomes. So this is a major response to that problem. All the parties in the Parliament seek to make a major response to that problem. The Opposition has a different response, but it recognises the problem and advocates its course of action—a course of action which I think will not solve the problem, but at least it is a recognition of the problem.

This proposal will also make a fundamental change to our economy because of its contribution to national savings. People have indicated that, because the expectations data indicates that it will not be a one-for-one relationship, every extra dollar going into superannuation will not be a net extra dollar of savings; there will be no contribution to national savings. That is a very poor argument. It is true that one simply cannot say there will be X billion dollars of superannuation savings, therefore the national savings will go up by X billion dollars. It is quite clearly true that one cannot say that because there will be some impact on the other savings activities of citizens. It is not possible to prove how much, but it would be extraordinary if that were not so. But if only half the money that is put into superannuation is an increase in national savings, that will be a very fundamental change to the nature of our economy.

One of the major and continuing problems in the Australian economy is the inadequacy of national savings. This proposal will give us the capacity to fund the investment which the economy of the next century will require without relying upon the savings of people overseas, without blowing out our overseas debt. If we do not enhance our national savings, we have two choices: less investment or more debt. There is no third route. So this is a very fundamental contribution to the future of the economy.

This measure also will enable the pension to be maintained and enhanced for those who have not had the opportunity to contribute to superannuation. That is the next important element. If we do not do something about retirement incomes, if we do not do something towards self-provision for retirement by those in the work force now, when those people who have not been able to make self-provision come to retire, the burden of taxes will either have to be enormous or the society will not be able to provide the level of retirement income support that Australians have come to expect. We wish to see that support not merely maintained but also enhanced, and this is a necessary step in that process.

This is a fundamentally redistributive mechanism. That is the reason why, as a package, it is a very major reform. It will stand as one of the major reforms of the decade. Everyone says that it needs to be done. Senator Sherry outlined quite clearly why alternative approaches of voluntarism have never worked anywhere. This compulsory mechanism is necessary. Nobody is arguing that some such mechanism should not be introduced. We are confronting the perennial argument of employers and conservatives since Federation and before—but since Federation in the Australian nation—that now is not the right time.

I have been involved in negotiating in one way or another for improvement of working conditions since 1968. I have never met a conservative politician or an employer who thought that any time since 1968 was the right time for any improvement of any condition of the workers I represented. I am happy to say they have not always prevailed in those debates, but that has always been their view and it remains their view.

The one thing that is consistent is that it is never the right time. In fact, there is a very straightforward economic argument that would contend that as one emerges from a recession there is no better time, but let us not worry about that. It is quite clear that these people would never ever agree to an increase and they will not now. It is simply an argument of convenience to say, `Now is not the right time'. There would never be a right time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop setting up straw men.

—If Senator Alston thinks there is no-one arguing that now is not the right time, he has been as remote from the debate as he is from the facts. There has been one concern in this debate that seems to me to have been strangely quiet. We have in Australia a very large number of good corporate citizens who already make superannuation contributions beyond the level that this legislation requires. These citizens have been at a competitive disadvantage for decades because of their social responsibility, because of their progressive employment practices.
—What hypocrisy.
—What a hypocrite.
—Order! The Parliamentary Secretary is summing up.

—They are both making extraordinary unparliamentary remarks, but I am not quite as sensitive about that as they would be if I were to say those statements about them. I expect them to reflect the significant distinction between their words and actions the next time they are interjected upon. But I would not call them hypocrites, because it would be unparliamentary.

PARA.TAB: It is true that a large number of good corporate citizens are already paying extra superannuation. For the first time this legislation will mean that they will not get hit twice—that is, paying superannuation and then paying tax to fund the retirement incomes of those who work for employers who have not been so responsible. Such people will be on an equal footing for the first time. They may not know who those people are, so they may think this is some stunning revelation. But it is the oldest issue in the book that a large number of good corporate citizens are paying extra superannuation.

Senator Watson and Senator Kernot raised questions to which I will respond fairly briefly. Senator Watson raised a concern about the funding of charities that might be affected by having to provide superannuation for their employees. There is a response to that in the paper released by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). There was also a concern about whether ordinary time earnings included fringe benefits. The answer is no.

There was a concern about resident overseas executives. The Government will be acting to deal with that in the course of the debate. There was also some concern about people who have flat rate schemes. I will make a comment about that in response to a question that was also put to me by Senator Kernot. Other questions were raised by Senator Watson, but I think that answer goes to the heart of his problem. I do not want to take as much time as one normally would in responding to such a major debate because we do want to have some time for the committee stage later.

One point is very important to emphasise. There has been accurate publicity about the amendments which the Government proposes to move. There is apprehension that one of those amendments may be misunderstood. It relates to the proposal to increase the minimum monthly threshold at which a payment obligation is activated for employees from $250 to $450.

It is fundamental to the Government's view of the way this scheme should work and its interrelationship with the existing award arrangements that the $450 threshold should not override existing award provisions nor be seen as a mandate to change existing award provisions. We do not wish to see people who are gaining a benefit at the moment lose; we are simply trying to put in place a scheme for all those who are not benefiting or not benefiting adequately. It is fundamental that that neither overrides awards nor is seen as a mandate to change awards. That would be entirely contrary to the Government's intention.

With regard to the concern about flat rate payment schemes, several industries have concerns, particularly the transport industry, the textile, clothing and footwear industry and the coal industry. There is sympathy for the circumstance of those industries. There have been some proposals in circulation and discussion to meet those problems. As drafted, they fail to meet those problems. They would neither solve the problem of the industry nor provide an adequate basis for security of retirement income for those and other people.

The Government intends to continue to work to find a form of words which will maintain the fundamental integrity of the scheme and meet the legitimate concerns of employers and employees in those three industries without in any way penalising people who are paying the amount of money required by the legislation but under a different formula. So the current formulae that are in circulation are not acceptable. However, it is a legitimate concern which we intend to address.

Senator Kernot also raised a question about the cap on administration fees. The Treasurer made it clear that the Government is not attracted to requiring superannuation funds to cross-subsidise members by placing a cap on their administration fees. That remains our situation.

There are a lot of other things that one would refer to in the normal course of summing up a second reading debate, but I will confine myself to commending the Bill to the Senate. It is a long term reform. Such reforms always meet resistance. It is never the right time for them, but it is important that Australia put this scheme in place now. If we are to be criticised about the timing, we should have done it 20 or 40 years ago. However, it is fundamental that we do it now, and I think the Australian people will regard the passage of this legislation as a major discharge of the obligations of the Government and the Parliament. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to follow up a matter that I raised in a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on 4 May 1992. I drew to his and the Senate's attention the fact that the annual inflation rate had dropped to 1.7 per cent for the year to the end of the March quarter 1992, that the average weekly earnings increased by only 2 per cent in the year to the end of the December quarter 1991, and that interest rates on savings investment accounts had almost halved. I asked: will the Government introduce legislation to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to calculate the increase in provisional taxpayers' income at a more just and realistic level than the current 10 per cent?

PARA.TAB: I raised that matter because of the number of people who contacted me who now find that the 10 per cent rate is unreasonable, to put it mildly. A lot of people now have to pay provisional tax who have not had to do so previously and whose income has dropped dramatically in the last 12 months or so. I heard one radio interview in Canberra when a man rang in to say that when he had retired two years ago he had calculated that the income for him and his wife would be $18,000 a year. That, they had concluded, was a most adequate income and they were very happy with the arrangements. But he said that his income had now dropped—I do not remember the precise figure but it was around $9,000 and less than $10,000. He recognised that he was in a mess as a consequence of this. But he, of course, still had income from which tax had not been taken and he was required to pay provisional tax, which was still being levied at 10 per cent notwithstanding the drop in his income. Other people have made representations to me about this very matter.

Businesses pay provisional tax, and I can only conclude that the Government's attitude to this matter is that businesses have plenty of money and can pay. If there is an advantage to the Treasurer that is fine, and if small people are hurt in the process it is just too bad. The answer I received from the Minister representing the Treasurer, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), which he tabled on 18 June, indicates that the Government has no intention of doing anything about this massive injustice.

The answer itself is bizarre. In taking so many words to say so little, one can only conclude that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) knows that he is wrong and is trying to cover it up. I also invite him to take a course in plain English. I shall not read all of the answer, but part of it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The provisional tax uplift factor was set at the rate of 10 per cent to reflect broadly the expected long term growth in incomes subject to provisional tax.

I will pause there. I would have thought that the Treasurer was one person who ought to know exactly what long term growth in incomes was likely to occur. `Uplift' is a word with which I have been familiar for a long time, and I had a certain view as to what its meaning might be. But I had to make inquiries as to what it meant in this context. I asked whether there was any definition of it in taxation terms and I finally found that it is tax jargon which means `to increase'—in other words, to take more from taxpayers. The answer goes on to reflect on the fact that inflation and interest rates are components of provisional tax income, but they are not the only tax components. It does not bother to mention what the others are. It continues:
Incomes subject to provisional tax may be expected to exhibit quite a sharp proportional rise during the emergence from an economic downturn.

I am glad the Treasurer thinks there will be one. In the meantime, the people on the incomes which I am referring to are having a very hard time of it. The next paragraph of the answer really indicates the extent to which the Treasurer is out of touch with the impact of the Income Tax Assessment Act on these people. It states:

If a taxpayer considers that the amount of provisional tax assessed in any year is more than his or her expected tax liability for the year, the taxpayer is able to vary the provisional tax liability to the amount of the expected lesser tax liability.

However, to do that he or she would have to go to a tax accountant. People then get into a situation of paying the fees involved in that. If honourable senators have seen the tax Act lately they would have some idea of why it is very costly to do so. The answer then states:
This self-assessment option is available to those who believe their incomes for the year will not rise by 10 per cent.

That means that one can make an assessment of what one thinks one's income will be. That may sound reasonable—one can work it out from last year's income and so on—but, if one makes a mistake and finishes up with more income than one has assessed, the penalties are horrendous. Who can risk doing this? Who can risk not paying the 10 per cent in light of the consequences that will be visited upon people by the Taxation Office and the Treasurer if that is in fact the outcome? We get this magic word again when it goes on to state:
The 10 per cent uplift factor was set in legislation with a view to making the provisional tax system—
Wait till you hear this, Mr Deputy President—
more simple and certain by avoiding the need to adjust the rate annually.
The only person for whom it might have been more simple and certain is the Treasurer. It is certainly not the taxpayers that he is supposed to be looking after. It goes on:
Nevertheless, the Government is monitoring the experience with the current uplift factor—
It is definitely hooked on it—
and would introduce amending legislation, if it believed that alteration of the uplift factor was warranted in future years.
That phrase appears four times in this. It has happened now: people's incomes have dropped dramatically.

PARA.TAB: I am not the first person to raise this. Senator Watson has spoken on it several times. I am certain that the Treasurer's representative in this place understands exactly what we are talking about. If one were to go to an accountant to have it calculated in an attempt to reduce one's tax in that fashion, one would be paying as much as if one paid the 10 per cent in advance as provisional tax in any event.

Of course, that is not the only way that the Treasurer will rip off taxpayers. I know of two incidences recently in which people are in credit with the Tax Office. When they have asked for a refund, the Treasurer has virtually laughed at them and said, `You will be owing us more sooner or later. We will keep it on account'. The Tax Office does not pay interest on it; it just keeps it on account. But if you, Mr Deputy President, happen to owe the Treasurer some money through tax and do not pay it on time, you are likely to be pursued and charged penalties on the money.

I ask the Treasurer again: why will he not adjust this 10 per cent? The only conclusion I can come to is that he does not care about those who are involved in having to find and pay this money and that he enjoys getting the extra money that he is not entitled to and that he will not adjust. It ought to be adjusted annually. To try to hide behind words suggesting it is more simple and certain is totally unacceptable. It is unconscionable that this should be allowed to go on. I conclude from the Treasurer's answer that he is quite happy, and in fact is determined, to allow it to continue because of the benefit he sees in the money that the Government gets in from this totally unworthy source.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 August 1978, I rose in this chamber to give my first speech. In the course of that contribution I said that one of the most disturbing features of our statute book with regard to the matter of conscientious objection and the waging of war was the failure of the National Service Act to protect the conscience formed by the rules of the just war. I went on to indicate how the Act had provided, of course, for the person who was a total pacifist, but did not provide for the ordinary person whose conscience allows him to distinguish between a just and an unjust war. There was no adequate provision for recognition of that conscience at all. I went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We as legislators ought to be reinforcing the individual conscience as that which culturally makes us what we are—a society where the common good cannot be secured by means which destroy the individual personality.

I am very pleased of course that only today the Senate has passed a Bill which in fact deals with those very important and vital matters to our democracy which I mentioned in my first speech in this chamber 14 years ago.

PARA.TAB: Those remarks of course came out of my experience during the time of the Vietnam war when I recall, having returned to lecture at the University of Tasmania, being at one of the university colleges one evening, sitting around a radiogram, listening to the marbles being drawn out of the barrel and seeing young students sitting around with great apprehension wondering whether a marble bearing the date of their birth would be drawn out and therefore they would be conscripted to serve in Vietnam.

I recall very well the blood draining from the face of one young student when his marble was in fact drawn out. Of course he commented that whilst he would be prepared to defend Australia, he would certainly, in conscience, not feel able to participate in the Vietnam war conflict. In other words, he had a conscientious objection to a particular armed conflict to which he was being conscripted.

Not only was his conscience not recognised but also, if he was going to go through any sort of process of protest, he was forced to go to the magistrates court and be involved in a very adversarial proceeding where he would be confronted with the claims of society being advanced by an aggressive lawyer on one side and his trying to explain his conscience to the magistrate on the other. So the whole forum in which his conscience was examined was also totally inappropriate to the fundamental integrity of his conscience, which he may not have been able to articulate in a way which was suitable to the normal processes of our common law adversarial system of arriving at the truth of the matter.

It was very interesting that some seven years later I was able to chair a committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, which prepared a unanimous report entitled Conscientious Objection to Conscripted Military Service. The report was written by three members from this side of the chamber—myself as Chairman, Senator Nick Bolkus and Senator Barney Cooney—and three members from the other side: Senator Robert Hill, the late Senator Alan Missen and former Senator Chris Puplick.

This was the unanimous recommendation of that particular Committee: recognising that conscientious objection to military service was such a fundamental matter to the integrity of a human being, the Parliament should change the National Service Act and the Defence Act to enable recognition of the conscientious objection to a particular war. As I said, that proposal was put by that Committee, to which was added provision for the better manner of assessment of whether that conscientious belief actually existed; the person making the claim that it did bearing the onus of proving that on the balance of probabilities. In answer to the inevitable objection that this might undermine our society, we stated in the report:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the relationship between the Government and the governed in Australia's democratic society requires and allows for the recognition of conscientious belief. In a democratic society, the bounds of tolerance of individual behaviour are not as tightly drawn as in an authoritarian, or totalitarian, society. Dissent from the government's decision or programs is not to be always described as `mere political dissidence.' Recognition that some dissent can be conscientiously based is a mark of a democratic society.
The Committee concluded:

. . . Australia, as a democracy, even when engaged in armed conflict, is well able to accommodate the proposed extension of the recognition of conscientious belief in order to protect the integrity of the individual against the coercive power of the State.

A further seven years later and 14 years after giving my first speech in the Senate, the Senate has today passed amendments to the Defence Act which adopt the recommendations of that Committee as a benchmark against which will be measured this nation's dealing with those whom it decides should be conscripted to perform military service. Of course, the National Service Act itself will be repealed by this particular Bill. For all practical purposes it has been defunct since 1972, but this carries out the formal repeal of that measure which, as I say, governed the conscription of those who went overseas to serve in Vietnam.

PARA.TAB: That leaves the Defence Act, which deals only with the defence of Australia in time of invasion, or threatened or imminent invasion—an apprehended attack by the enemy on Australia itself. In that situation one might very properly predict that there would be very few who would conscientiously object to engaging in that particular defence of the nation itself, but there may be some.

In that situation, the setting of this benchmark is very valuable indeed because it indicates, as can only be done by parliaments such as this in a time of relative tranquility and away from the hysteria of actual warfare or preparation for war, that this Parliament has set down the principles which should govern the protection of the conscience of the individual against the coercive power of the state, even at a time when Australia might require conscription—and I am not against conscription itself at a time when society is threatened. Even in that state of affairs this individual conscience ought to be recognised.

I congratulate Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Defence, for shepherding this very important reform through the Parliament and for gaining support for it amongst members of the Cabinet. I believe it already had a large measure of support in the Caucus and in the Party as a whole. Indeed, the tenor of this Defence Legislation Amendment Bill is to be found in the Party platform as amended at the national conference.

This recognition of the boundary beyond which all organised society cannot go, even in defence of the country and its values, is particularly important in our democracy. It would be paradoxical and very contradictory to the values we would be defending as a democracy in a war if we allowed the overruling of the individual's sense of integrity in relation to such an important core fundamental matter as to whether he or she might be forced to kill another human being in armed conflict. To allow the collectivity to suppress

SPEECH.PARA: the individual in such an important matter of conscience, I believe, would be a very great wrong indeed and, as I have said, completely contradictory to the values of a democratic society which professedly we would be trying to defend in the warfare being engaged in.

PARA.TAB: I greatly welcome this measure that has passed through the Senate today. I wish to thank those Tasmanians, particularly those within the Australian Labor Party who 14 years ago allowed me to represent them, and my fellow Tasmanians in this place. More generally, I thank the electorate of Tasmania for giving me the opportunity, not only then but on subsequent occasions, to come to this Parliament and to be in a position to press this reform.

I also thank all those who have enabled me to fulfil a fundamental promise I made to all those who were so gravely affected by the harsh application of the conscription laws which failed to protect their consciences—a promise I made to many supporters and the electors of Tasmania and, of course, to myself. It has been a most satisfying conclusion to the working of our democratic parliamentary processes to achieve this real change of enduring social significance for the future of Australia as a democratic society where the integrity of the individual is paramount against the coercive power of the state.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Therapeutic Goods Act—Determination No. MP1/1992, 4 June 1992 and Australian Code of Good Manufacturing Practice for Therapeutic Goods—Medicinal Products.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 12 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) When the Minister signed the declaration enabling Ausfern Pty Ltd to harvest Dicksonia antarctica stems in northern Tasmania, what was the advice of the designated authority relating to the adequacy or otherwise of the method proposed for re-establishing the ferns on the logged sites.
(2) What research shows that natural resporing as proposed by Ausfern will be successful and over what time frames.

(3) What were the reasons for rejecting the view expressed in the Monitoring Report that resporing of sites by mature trees either left on site or on adjacent sites will take longer than by planting of stock propagated off site.
(4) Will a considerable cost penalty result from propagating from stock generated off site.

(5) Was a Management Plan approved in 1991, based on a regeneration program using plants propagated in a nursery and the establishment of a laboratory to research and develop the commercial propagation of Dicksonia from spore and tissue culture.
(6) Will the commercial viability of this sustainable harvesting and regeneration program be threatened by the cheaper, but less certain harvesting program based on natural regeneration.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The tree fern management plan submitted by Ausfern Pty Ltd provides for the retention of at least one mature stem every twenty metres as well as spore laden fronds on-site for the purpose of naturally resporing logged sites. Additionally, in accordance with the principles of the Forests Practices Code, Ausfern has undertaken not to harvest Dicksonia antarctica from stream side reserves, thus allowing corridors of native tree ferns along watercourses to be retained.

The Designated Authority recommended that the declaration of D. antarctica as controlled specimens be subject to the initiation of research on the natural regeneration and ecology of tree ferns in plantation areas. This was seen as the most appropriate mechanism to gain further knowledge to ensure conservation of the species while permitting a degree of controlled export. In view of the apparent lack of long-term commitment by the landowners, APPM Forests-Burnie, to allow harvesting of tree ferns on their land, it was not seen as appropriate to request that Ausfern initiate a program of re-establishment of tube stock seedlings for the duration of the current licence which expires on 31 December 1992.

(2) Ausfern has provided some evidence of natural regeneration of D. antarctica in a eucalypt plantation at Lockwood Creek and in a pine plantation on the St John's block north of Lockwood Creek and on block 127 Lapoinya, Land District of Wellington managed by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission.

Little appears to be known, however, of the regrowth rate of D. antarctica. The propagation and monitoring measures proposed by Ausfern which were a condition of the declaration of D. antarctica as controlled specimens will be useful in allowing the gathering of relevant information.

(3) The view expressed in the monitoring report (which is included in the management plan) that planting of tube stock would allow faster establishment of tree ferns than resporing by mature trees left on site, was neither rejected nor accepted.
The Designated Authority was satisfied that Ausfern's decision to re-establish ferns on the logged areas through natural resporing was sufficient in the short term on an experimental basis.
(4) Comparative costs of the different regeneration methods have not been established.

(5) A management program submitted by Australian Native Fern Products was approved on 22 March 1991 to allow the export of tree ferns taken from private land in Tasmania. At the time of approval, the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 did not provide for the unilateral imposition of conditions such as the period of operation of management programs. Under these circumstances, it was necessary to ensure that re-establishment of seedlings would be undertaken on a long-term basis and proposed planting of tube stocks as suggested by Australian Native Fern Products was considered the most appropriate option.

(6) It is a matter for the industry to assess the most cost-effective methods of regenerating tree ferns and these may vary from site to site. However, in the longer term, it is anticipated that tree fern management in Tasmania will be conducted in a uniform manner throughout the State. In this regard preliminary discussions have been held with relevant Tasmanian authorities to facilitate the development of uniform regulatory standards for the industry and management of the resource on an ecologically sustainable basis.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 15 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: Has the Commonwealth been approached to support or approve visits by any vessel to Heard Island and Australian Antarctic stations or other sites within the Australian Antarctic Territory (AAT) during the 1992-93 Antarctic summer; if so: (a) what request has been made; (b) what specific approval or consideration has been given; (c) what stations and/or sites within the AAT are proposed to be visited; (d) who made the request, who chartered the vessel and on whose behalf was the request made; (e) what type of fuel oil will the vessel carry; (f) will the fuel oil be stored next to the outer skin of the vessel; (g) has any tour operator or charterer offered any service to the Australian Antarctic Division during the course of any proposed visits to the AAT or Heard Island; (h) will compliance with Australian environmental practices and international standards (including MARPOL conventions and the Madrid Protocol) be required for any visits; (i) what procedures will be used to minimise the risk of oil or other pollution arising during any such visits; (j) was the Arctic and Antarctic Institute in St Petersberg consulted in relation to any aspect of any proposal; if so, what advice was given to the Institute; and (k) will passengers be permitted to inspect Australian Antarctic facilities and stations; if so, what controls will be applied.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (a-d) The Commonwealth has received three approaches regarding visits to the AAT and Heard Island during the 1992-93 summer season.

Burns Philp Shipping Agencies Pty Ltd sought permission for the vessel MV Caledonian Star to visit Heard Island while en route from Capetown to Fremantle, but subsequently advised that the vessel would not be undertaking this visit.

A request has also been received from a group of amateur radio operators to visit Atlas Cove on Heard Island. They were advised of legal and other conditions applicable to the Territory of Heard Island and McDonald Islands, including indicative conditions of the Management Plan which is expected to be in force at the time of the proposed visit. The group has advised that it is considering travelling to and from Heard Island on board the Quark Expeditions' vessel Kapitan Khlebnikov, going down on the first voyage in November and coming back in December on the second voyage.

Quark Expeditions initially approached the Commonwealth seeking permission for its chartered vessel Admiral Makharov to visit Heard Island, Australia's Antarctic stations and Commonwealth Bay during the 1992-93 summer season. However, the company subsequently has advised that they intend chartering the vessel Kapitan Khlebnikov in place of the Admiral Makharov. In principle agreement has been given, but the company has been advised that there are a number of issues to be considered before the visits can proceed. These include the requirements of Australian law concerning Antarctica and the Territory of Heard Island and McDonald Islands, the need to comply with environmental and safety standards for the proposed activities and the need to minimise disruption to Australia's scientific program.

(e, f) Details of the vessel Kapitan Khlebnikov are not presently available. Quark Expeditions have been advised that they are expected to comply with relevant Antarctic Treaty recommendations and requirements concerning marine pollution.

(g) The suggestion was made that the Kapitan Khlebnikov might be able to assist the Antarctic Division by carrying some expeditioners. The suggestion was not pursued; firstly to avoid being under an obligation to the Company; and secondly because of the need to avoid uncertainties in program planning.

(h) Quark Expeditions have been advised that they are expected to comply with all Antarctic Treaty recommendations including those concerning waste disposal, marine pollution, conservation of fauna and flora, protected areas and tourism and, wherever practicable, with the provisions of the Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty. Annex IV of the Protocol, entitled Prevention of Marine Pollution, relates closely to the obligations of MARPOL 73/78. Quark Expeditions has also been advised of relevant Australian Antarctic legislation.

A permit is required for visits to Heard Island and Quark Expeditions will be expected to observe Australian legislation applicable to the Territory of Heard Island and McDonald Islands, including the conditions of the Management Plan which is anticipated to be completed by the time the visits take place.
(i) Quark Expeditions were requested in April to provide details of the nature and status of contin-

ANSWER.PARA: gency plans for marine pollution emergencies such as accidents or fuel spills. This information has not yet been provided.

PARA.TAB: (j) No.

(k) Passengers will be permitted to visit Australian Antarctic facilities and stations provided Quark Expeditions meets various requirements, including relevant Treaty and legal obligations. Quark Expeditions has also been provided with a detailed list of conditions for station visits which are intended to ensure safety, environmental protection and minimal disruption to station activities including science programs.
